Installation, within any time the Department sets, of the whole or any part of a water supply system or sewerage system for the subdivision that:

subparagraph.text: Conforms to the plans submitted to the Department and to any revision of the plans that the Department approves; and
In the judgment of the Department, is needed for the public health.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies to a residential minor subdivision in a Tier II, Tier III, or Tier IV area.

Except as provided in paragraphs (4) and (5) of this subsection, on or after December 31, 2012, if a tract or parcel of land is subdivided into a residential minor subdivision leaving any remainder parcel or tract of land:

subparagraph.text: The residential minor subdivision may not be resubdivided or further subdivided; and
The remainder parcel or tract of land may not be subdivided.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraphs (4) and (5) of this subsection, on or after December 31, 2012, the subdivision plat of the residential minor subdivision shall state that:

subparagraph.text: The residential minor subdivision may not be resubdivided or further subdivided;
The remainder parcel or tract of land may not be subdivided; and
The subdivision plat is subject to State law and local ordinances and regulations.

paragraph.text: On or after December 31, 2012, if a tract or parcel of land is subdivided into a residential minor subdivision, the residential minor subdivision or the remainder parcel or tract of land may be resubdivided or further subdivided if the subdivision or the remainder parcel or tract of land is:

subparagraph.text: Within a priority funding area as defined in Title 5, Subtitle 7B of the State Finance and Procurement Article; and
Designated for public sewerage service within 10 years in the approved water and sewer plan.

A tract or parcel of land may be subdivided into a residential minor subdivision in Tier II, Tier III, or Tier IV areas over time if each time a new lot or parcel is created, the subdivision plat states the number of new lots, plats, building sites, or other divisions of land that are left with the number of lots, plats, building sites, or other divisions of land allowed as a subdivision.

Except as provided in paragraph (iii) of this paragraph, when the tract or parcel of land that is subdivided over time reaches the total number of lots, plats, building sites, or other divisions of land that are allowed as a residential minor subdivision, the subdivision plat shall state that:

sub-subparagraph.text: The residential minor subdivision may not be resubdivided or further subdivided;
The remainder parcel or tract of land may not be subdivided; and
The subdivision plat is subject to State law and local ordinances and regulations.

subparagraph.text: A remainder parcel or tract of land may be subdivided for nonresidential agricultural purposes, including a farm market, agricultural processing facility, or creamery, and the owner may apply for approval of an on–site sewage disposal system to serve the nonresidential agricultural purposes.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, “agricultural activities” includes:

subparagraph.text: Plowing, tillage, cropping, seeding, cultivating, and harvesting for the production of food and fiber products; and
The grazing of livestock.

paragraph.text: A local jurisdiction may enact a local law or ordinance for the transfer of the right to subdivide, up to 7 lots, by an owner of property used for agricultural activities to the owner of another property used for agricultural activities in accordance with this subsection.
The local law or ordinance shall provide for the recordation of any rights to subdivide that are transferred under this subsection.
A property used for agricultural activities the owner of which receives rights to subdivide under this subsection:

subparagraph.text: Is limited to a total of 15 lots; and
Shall cluster the lots on the property.

paragraph.text: Rights to subdivide may not be transferred from the owner of property used for agricultural activities in a Tier III area to the owner of property used for agricultural activities in a Tier IV area.

subsection.text: In this section, “basic main facility”:

paragraph.text: Includes:

subparagraph.text: A sewage treatment plant;
An intercepting sewer;
An outfall sewer;
A pumping station; and
A force main that is connected with a sewage treatment plant, intercepting sewer, outfall sewer, or pumping station; and

paragraph.text: Does not include a lateral or collector pipe that serves individual properties or developments.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall help counties and municipal corporations of this State and the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission to develop comprehensive master plans for constructing the basic main facilities of sewerage systems for collecting and disposing of sewage or industrial waste from lateral or collector pipes.
If the Secretary considers that regional planning is advisable, the Secretary shall attempt to coordinate on a regional basis:

paragraph.text: The development of master plans under subsection (b) of this section; and
Approval of the construction of sanitary facilities under this subtitle.

subsection.text: This section does not take away any power of the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission.

On request, the Secretary shall consult with and advise the owner, operator, prospective owner, or prospective operator of an existing or planned water supply system, drainage system, sewerage system, or refuse disposal system with respect to the existing and future needs of all persons and communities that may be affected on any of the following aspects of the system:

paragraph.text: The most appropriate source of water;
The best method of assuring the purity of the water; and
The best method of disposing of drainage, sewage, or refuse.

subsection.text: On request, the Secretary shall consult with and advise the owner, operator, prospective owner, or prospective operator of any business that produces sewage that may pollute the waters of this State.
The Secretary may conduct any experiment relating to the purification of water or the treatment of sewage or refuse.
A person need not pay for consultation, advice, or experiments that the Secretary provides under this section.

paragraph.text: Under this section, the Secretary shall give only preliminary information that outlines the best course to pursue.

Unless the Governor or the General Assembly delegates this authority specifically to the Secretary, and unless adequate special appropriation is provided for this purpose, the Secretary need not prepare plans, specifications, or detailed estimates for any improvement.

subsection.text: The applicant shall give notice of the application, the informational meeting, and hearings:

paragraph.text: To the public in compliance with Title 1, Subtitle 6 of this article;

To the board of county commissioners or the county council of any county and the chief executive of any county or municipal corporation that the Department determines may be affected by the incinerator for public use or landfill system, by certified mail;
To the Department of Natural Resources, by certified mail;
To each member of the General Assembly representing any part of a county in which the landfill system or incinerator is located, by certified mail;

To record owners of real property within 1,000 feet of the property line of the proposed incinerator for public use or landfill system, by certified mail to the addresses of record owners as indicated in the records of the State Department of Assessments and Taxation; and
By posting a notice of the application, the informational meeting, and hearings in a conspicuous space on the site of the proposed incinerator for public use or landfill system.

subsection.text: The local officials notified under subsection (a)(2) of this section shall give notice of the application, the informational meeting, and hearings to all interested agencies of their respective jurisdictions.

To the extent practicable, the Department and other units of the State government shall consolidate the informational meeting and hearings concerning permits for the same landfill system or incinerator for public use.

Subject to the provisions of subsection (b) of this section, the Secretary may not issue a permit to install, materially alter, or materially extend a refuse disposal system regulated under § 9-204(a) of this subtitle until the requirements set forth in this subsection are met in the following sequence:

paragraph.text: Except for the opportunity for a public informational meeting, the Department has completed its preliminary phase 1 technical review of the proposed refuse disposal system;

The Department has reported the findings of its preliminary phase 1 technical review, in writing, to the county’s chief elected official and planning commission of the county where the proposed refuse disposal system is to be located; and
The county has completed its review of the proposed refuse disposal system, and has provided to the Department a written statement that the refuse disposal system:

subparagraph.text: Meets all applicable county zoning and land use requirements; and
Is in conformity with the county solid waste plan.

subsection.text: Upon completion of the requirements of subsection (a)(1) and (2) of this section, the Department shall cease processing the permit application until the requirements of subsection (a)(3) of this section are met.

paragraph.text: The Secretary may not issue a permit for a rubble landfill under § 9-204(a) of this subtitle unless the county in which the rubble landfill is located has specified the types of waste that may be disposed of in that rubble landfill in its county solid waste management plan under Subtitle 5 of this title.
The types of waste that a county may allow to be disposed of in a rubble landfill under this section include:

subparagraph.text: Trees;
Land clearing debris that is not a controlled hazardous substance as defined in Title 7, Subtitle 2 of this article;
Demolition debris that is not a controlled hazardous substance as defined in Title 7, Subtitle 2 of this article; and
Construction debris that is not a controlled hazardous substance as defined in Title 7, Subtitle 2 of this article.

paragraph.text: The following types of waste may be disposed of in a rubble landfill subject to the regulations adopted under this subtitle if the disposal of these wastes is expressly approved by the county in its county solid waste management plan:

subparagraph.text: Asbestos, if:

sub-subparagraph.text: The asbestos is wet or otherwise in accordance with federal national emission standards for hazardous air pollution when delivered to the landfill; and
The owner or operator of the landfill retains a record that clearly delineates where the asbestos has been deposited;

subparagraph.text: White goods; and
Subject to § 9-228(f) of this subtitle, scrap tires.

paragraph.text: Except for a sanitary landfill that is subject to § 9-211.1 of this subtitle, and as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, before the Secretary issues a permit for a landfill, incinerator, or transfer station to any private person, the applicant for the permit shall:

subparagraph.text: File with the Department a bond on the form that the Department provides; or

Deposit with the governing body of the local jurisdiction where the landfill, incinerator, or transfer station will be located cash, negotiable bonds of the federal government or this State, or any other security that the Department approves.

paragraph.text: The Secretary may adopt regulations to exempt any legitimate recycling or reclamation facility from the requirements of this section.

The obligation of a bond filed under this section shall be so conditioned as to be void on the closing of the landfill, incinerator, or transfer station in a manner that prevents erosion, health and safety hazards, nuisances, and pollution.

The local governing body that receives a deposit of cash or other security under this section shall hold the security in trust in the name of the local jurisdiction to assure the closing of the landfill, incinerator, or transfer station in a manner that prevents erosion, health and safety hazards, nuisances, and pollution.

subsection.text: A bond filed under this section shall be payable to the governing body of the political subdivision where the landfill, incinerator, or transfer station will be located.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, for a landfill:

subparagraph.text: Unless otherwise required by federal law or regulation, a bond filed under this section shall be in the amount of $10,000 for each acre of land to which the permit applies, but not less than $250,000;
Cash deposited under this section shall be not less than the amount specified in paragraph (1)(i) of this subsection; and
The market value of other security deposited under this section shall be not less than the amount specified in paragraph (1)(i) of this subsection.

paragraph.text: For an incinerator or transfer station, the Department shall establish the amount of the security required by this section.

subparagraph.text: This paragraph does not apply to a rubble landfill.

For sanitary landfills that are restricted to acceptance of land clearing debris specified in regulations of the Department, a bond filed under this section shall be in the amount of $2,000 for each acre of land to which the permit applies, with a minimum amount of security of $25,000.

subsection.text: Both the applicant for a permit and a corporate surety licensed to do business in this State shall execute any bond filed under this section.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the term of any bond filed under this section and the time during which cash or other security must remain on deposit under this section is:

subparagraph.text: The duration of the operation of the landfill, incinerator, or transfer station; and
An additional 5 years after the closing of the landfill, incinerator, or transfer station.

paragraph.text: If the Department has assurances that the landfill, incinerator, or transfer station has been closed in a manner that prevents erosion, health and safety hazards, nuisances, and pollution, the Department may release the security filed or deposited under this section before the end of the 5-year period specified in paragraph (1)(ii) of this subsection.

The obligation of the holder of a permit for a landfill, incinerator, or transfer station and of any corporate surety under the bond shall become due and payable and any cash, securities, or bond proceeds shall be applied to payment of the costs of properly closing a landfill, incinerator, or transfer station only if the Department:

subparagraph.text: Notifies the permit holder and any corporate surety on the bond that the landfill, incinerator, or transfer station has not been closed in a manner that prevents erosion, health and safety hazards, nuisances, and pollution;
Specifies in the notice the deficiencies in the closing that must be corrected;

Gives the permit holder and the corporate surety a reasonable opportunity to correct the deficiencies and to close the landfill, incinerator, or transfer station in accordance with the regulations of the Department; and
Authorizes the local governing body to close the landfill, incinerator, or transfer station in accordance with the regulations of the Department.

paragraph.text: The local governing body shall use bond proceeds, cash, or the proceeds of other security to pay the cost of properly closing the landfill, incinerator, or transfer station.
The Department shall adopt regulations governing financial assurance for sanitary landfills that accept municipal solid waste.

For municipal solid waste landfills, the regulations shall be consistent with and may not exceed the requirements of federal regulations governing financial assurance (40 C.F.R. § 258.70 through 258.74).

A regulation adopted under this section which is applicable to municipal solid waste landfills may not take effect until after the effective date of federal regulations governing financial assurance adopted pursuant to 40 C.F.R. § 258.70 through 258.74 and shall cease to be effective whenever those federal regulations are suspended or repealed.

subsection.text: Before the Secretary issues a permit for a sanitary landfill, the applicant for the permit shall provide proof of financial assurance in accordance with the regulations adopted by the Department under this section.

Until the regulations adopted by the Department under subsection (a) of this section are effective, or if those regulations cease to be effective, sanitary landfills that accept municipal solid waste shall comply with the requirements of § 9-211 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: As a condition precedent to the issuance by the Secretary of a permit for a landfill under this subtitle, the county or municipal corporation with jurisdiction over the landfill may require the owner of the site where the landfill is to be located to grant an option for the county or municipal corporation to purchase the site for open space or recreational purposes.
An option required under this subsection expires on the earlier of:

subparagraph.text: The date specified in the option; or
The date when the landfill ceases to be actively used.

paragraph.text: If the county or municipal corporation with jurisdiction over the landfill does not require an option under subsection (a) of this section, the State may require an option for the State to purchase the site for open space or recreational purposes.
If the county or municipal corporation with jurisdiction over the landfill requires but will not exercise an option under subsection (a) of this section, the State may exercise the option.

subsection.text: Any option granted under this section is binding on any heir, representative, successor, or assign of the grantor.

section.text: The Department may deny an application for a permit for a sanitary landfill system to any nongovernmental person if:

paragraph.text: The owner of the land, the operator, or the applicant has violated:

subparagraph.text: Any law of this State or any other state concerning sanitary landfills; or
Any regulation or permit condition of this State or any other state concerning sanitary landfills; or

paragraph.text: The Department finds that operation of the sanitary landfill system would harm public health or the environment.

subsection.text: A permit for a landfill system expires on the 5th anniversary of its date of issue, unless the permit is renewed for a 5-year term as provided in this section.
Before a permit for a landfill system expires, the permit holder may renew it for an additional 5-year term, if the permit holder:

paragraph.text: Submits to the Department a renewal application on the form that the Department requires;
Gives notice, by certified mail, of the renewal application to each member of the General Assembly in whose district the landfill system is located; and
Obtains the written approval of the Department.

section.text: The Department may refuse to renew a permit for a landfill system if:

paragraph.text: The permit holder violates any provision of this subtitle, any regulation adopted under this subtitle, any condition of the permit, or, if operating a landfill in another state, any statute, regulation, or permit of that state concerning landfill systems;
The Department finds that continued operation of the landfill system would be injurious to public health or the environment; or
The Department finds that there is any other good cause.

subsection.text: When landfill operations end, the holder of a permit issued under this subtitle for a landfill system shall close and cover all of the land for which the permit was issued in a manner that prevents:

paragraph.text: Erosion;
Health and safety hazards;
Nuisances; and
Pollution.

subsection.text: The Department shall adopt regulations that set standards for the closing and covering of landfill systems.
In the coastal plain physiographic province of this State, a person may use any of the conventional, on-site sewage disposal systems identified in subsection (b) of this section if:

paragraph.text: The system is recommended by the Department as being the most appropriate; and
The Secretary does not determine that the installation of the specific proposed system would be prejudicial to public health, safety, and welfare.

subsection.text: Systems that may be used under subsection (a) of this section are:

paragraph.text: A septic tank or aerobic treatment system with:

subparagraph.text: Standard trench or deep trench subsurface irrigation;
A seepage pit; or
A sand mound disposal system; and

paragraph.text: Any other on-site sewage disposal system that the Department in its regulations states is conventional.

subsection.text: The Department may adopt regulations to carry out this section.

section.text: Notwithstanding any provision of this title or any regulation of the Department that prohibits the installation of a specific on-site sewage disposal system, at the request of a person who owns a lot that was legally established on November 17, 1985, the Department shall test and evaluate the lot for an on-site sewage disposal system as if the person had applied to the Department and the Department had acted on the application on November 17, 1985.

subsection.text: After July 1, 1999, every person engaged in the business of inspecting an on-site sewage disposal system for a transfer of property must certify to the Department of the Environment that the person has completed a course of instruction, approved by the Department, in the proper inspection of on-site sewage disposal systems.

Every person engaged in the business of inspecting an on-site sewage disposal system for a transfer of property shall make available to persons contracting for the inspection service evidence of completion of the course of instruction.
The Department shall adopt regulations to implement the provisions of this section.
There is a Sanitary Facilities Fund.
The Department may use the Sanitary Facilities Fund to finance planning for water and sewerage facilities and for solid waste disposal facilities and solid waste acceptance facilities.

paragraph.text: The Department also may use funds appropriated in the State budget for general local health services to finance planning under this section.

If the Department uses a general local health services appropriation to finance planning under this section, State, county, and local funds shall be provided in the same proportions as they would be provided to pay for minimum health services.

subsection.text: The Department and any county, or the Department and the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission, jointly may finance planning under this section.
The Department and any local government may make a joint financing agreement to use any available federal grant for the planning under this section.
Any county or municipal corporation may appropriate its general funds to participate in the planning under this section.

If a special government agency is charged with providing sanitary facilities in a county or municipal corporation, the Department, the county, or the municipal corporation may make general funds available to that agency for the planning under this section.
This section does not apply if the State would lose or be denied any federal assistance or other funds because of its application.

paragraph.text: If federal grants, loans, or other funds are available for sewerage systems in the Patuxent River Watershed area, the Department shall use them to upgrade and floodproof existing sewerage systems, collector lines, or facilities in the area to meet standards currently in effect under this subtitle.

If available funds can be used to upgrade and floodproof any existing sewerage systems, collector lines, or facilities in the Patuxent River Watershed area, the Department may not use the funds to construct any new sewerage system, collector line, or facility in the area.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding subsection (b) of this section, the Department may use available funds to construct a new sewerage system, collector line, or facility that does not discharge into a river, including a new sewerage system that incorporates land disposal of treated sewage effluent.

The Secretary shall order the owner or person in charge of a water supply system, sewerage system, or refuse disposal system to correct the following improper conditions, if, after investigation, the Secretary determines that, because of incompetent supervision or inefficient operation, the water supply system, sewerage system, or refuse disposal system:

paragraph.text: Is not producing reasonable results from a sanitary viewpoint;
Is a menace to health or comfort; or
Is causing a nuisance.

subsection.text: The order shall require that the water supply system, sewerage system, or refuse disposal system produce specific, reasonable results within a time that the Secretary sets.

paragraph.text: If the water supply system, sewerage system, or refuse disposal system does not produce the required results within the time that the Secretary sets, the Secretary may order the owner or person in charge to appoint, within a time that the Secretary sets, a person approved by the Secretary to take charge of and operate the system in a manner that will secure the results demanded by the Secretary.
The person who is served with an order under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall pay the salary of the person who is appointed in compliance with the order.

subsection.text: If, after investigation, the Department determines that any water supply system, sewerage system, or refuse disposal system is a menace to health or comfort or is causing a nuisance, and that conditions cannot be improved sufficiently only by changing the method of operation, the Department may order the owner:

paragraph.text: To alter or extend the water supply system, sewerage system, or refuse disposal system; or
To install a new water supply system, sewerage system, or refuse disposal system.

subsection.text: An order under subsection (a) of this section shall state a reasonable date for completion of the work.
The Secretary may authorize a health officer:

paragraph.text: To investigate refuse disposal systems; and
To enforce any regulation of the Department concerning refuse disposal systems.

subsection.text: The Secretary may issue an order under subsection (b) of this section, if, after investigation, the Secretary determines that the absence or incompleteness of a public water supply system, public sewerage system, or refuse disposal system in a county, municipal corporation, sanitary district, subdivision, or locality:

paragraph.text: Is sufficiently prejudicial to the health or comfort of that or any other county, municipal corporation, sanitary district, subdivision, or locality; or
Causes a condition by which any of the waters of this State are being polluted or could become polluted in a way that is dangerous to health or is a nuisance.

subsection.text: An order under this section may require:

paragraph.text: The installation, alteration, extension, utilization, operation, or the completion of a public water supply system, public sewerage system, or refuse disposal system in a county, municipal corporation, sanitary district, subdivision, or locality within a time that the Secretary sets; or
The installation of any device, the establishment of any method, or the enforcement of any measure or regulation that the Secretary considers proper under the circumstances.

subsection.text: If a water supply system that serves the public or a sewerage system that serves the public is directly available to service any property on which there is a spring, well, cesspool, privy, sink drain, or private sewage disposal system that is or could become prejudicial to health or the environment, the Secretary may order that:

paragraph.text: The property be connected with the water supply system or sewage disposal system; and
The spring, well, cesspool, privy, sink drain, or private sewage disposal system be abandoned in a condition that will prevent it from being used or harming health.

subsection.text: If the Secretary determines that a proposed well, cesspool, privy, sink drain, or private sewage disposal system would be prejudicial to health, the Secretary may prevent construction of the well, cesspool, privy, sink drain, or private sewage disposal system.

paragraph.text: This subsection does not apply to:

subparagraph.text: The construction of a new dwelling; or
Any addition to or renovation of an existing dwelling.

paragraph.text: The Secretary shall allow the owner of a dwelling unit to install an on-site sewage disposal system for the dwelling unit if:

subparagraph.text: The dwelling unit is owner-occupied;
The dwelling unit is legally situated on a property and legally occupied; and

The Secretary finds that the on-site sewage disposal system would be a reasonable solution to sewage problems on the property and would not be an undue risk to the environment or to public health, safety, or welfare.

paragraph.text: A person may not build a privy in this State unless the privy will, in the judgment of the Secretary, prevent:

subparagraph.text: The soil from coming in contact with any fecal matter; and
Flies from gaining access to any fecal matter.

paragraph.text: If the Secretary finds that a person has built a privy in violation of paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Secretary shall:

subparagraph.text: Condemn the privy; and
Order any change sufficient to bring about compliance with paragraph (1) of this subsection.

paragraph.text: This section does not authorize the Secretary to prohibit a bona fide religious group from the free exercise of their religious beliefs by constructing a shallow well or a privy, if the well or privy:

subparagraph.text: Is built in accordance with specified standards; and
Is not prejudicial to health or to the environment.

subsection.text: On request of the Secretary, the owner or operator of an industrial establishment shall submit to the Secretary any plan, information, or record concerning the waste disposal methods the industrial establishment uses.

paragraph.text: If the Secretary finds that public health or comfort is or may be threatened because the wastes of an industrial establishment have polluted or are polluting the waters of this State or because of the waste disposal methods an industrial establishment uses, the Secretary shall order the owner or operator of the industrial establishment:

subparagraph.text: To stop polluting the body of water into which the industrial establishment discharges its waste; or
To alter the waste disposal methods of the industrial establishment in any way that the Secretary considers necessary to protect public health and comfort.

paragraph.text: The owner or operator of an industrial establishment shall comply with an order issued under paragraph (1) of this subsection within the time set by the Secretary.

subsection.text: A person who is subject to an order issued under this section shall have a permit issued by the Secretary under § 9-204 of this subtitle before the person may change the waste disposal methods used by an industrial establishment.

section.text: Unless a person applied for the permit before October 1, 1981, the Secretary may not issue a permit for a proposed landfill that would be within one-half mile of any hospital.
If a landfill system for hazardous wastes does not qualify for a certificate of public necessity under § 7-405(d)(2) of this article, the Secretary may not issue a permit for the system.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.

subparagraph.text: “Infectious waste” means any waste that comes from a hospital, laboratory, or other health care facility as defined in § 19-114 of the Health - General Article and that is known or suspected to be contaminated with organisms capable of producing disease or infection in humans.
“Infectious waste” includes:

sub-subparagraph.text: Contaminated disposable equipment, instruments, and utensils;
Contaminated needles, scalpels, and razor blades;
Human tissues and organs that result from surgery, obstetrics, or autopsy;
Feces, urine, vomitus, and suctionings;
Live vaccines for human use;
Blood and blood products; and
Laboratory specimens, such as tissues, blood elements, excreta, and secretions.

subsection.text: A hospital, laboratory, or other health care facility as defined in § 19-114 of the Health - General Article may not dispose of infectious waste, or cause infectious waste to be disposed of, in a landfill system in this State.
The Secretary is responsible with law enforcement personnel in this State for monitoring and enforcing subsection (b) of this section.

In this section, “approved facility” means a facility located in or outside of the State for collecting, recycling, or otherwise processing scrap tires that is approved or licensed by the Department in accordance with regulations adopted by the Department.

A person may not store scrap tires in the State unless the person demonstrates to the satisfaction of the Department that, within 90 days of the time that the person stores the scrap tires, the scrap tires will be:

paragraph.text: Returned to the marketplace;
Used as fuel in an approved resource recovery incinerator;
Used as a tire derived fuel in an approved facility; or
Transferred, by means of a scrap tire hauler, to any facility within the scrap tire recycling system established under subsection (c) of this section.
The service shall establish a scrap tire recycling system that includes scrap tire collection facilities, scrap tire haulers, and in the following order of priority:

subparagraph.text: Scrap tire recyclers; and

sub-subparagraph.text: An approved resource recovery facility that uses tires as a fuel substitute; or
An approved facility that uses tires as a tire derived fuel.

paragraph.text: A person may not incinerate tires except in:

subparagraph.text: An approved resource recovery facility that uses tires as a fuel substitute; or
An approved facility that uses tires as a tire derived fuel.

paragraph.text: A facility that processes scrap tires for use as a fuel in an incinerator, boiler, or resource recovery facility or a facility that burns or incinerates scrap tires may not be approved or licensed under this subtitle, unless:

subparagraph.text: There is no reasonable and economically available opportunity to process the tires and return them to the marketplace for reuse; and
The burning or incineration meets all federal and State air quality standards.

subsection.text: Scrap tire collection facilities, haulers, or recyclers may be publicly or privately owned and operated.

paragraph.text: After consultation with other State agencies, representatives of the tire industry, and representatives of local government, the service shall place in operation a scrap tire recycling system:

subparagraph.text: By January 1, 1993 for any county with a population of 150,000 or more according to the most recent projections by the Department of Planning; and
By January 1, 1994 for any county with a population of less than 150,000 according to the most recent projections by the Department of Planning.

paragraph.text: The service may establish a scrap tire recycling system required under paragraph (1) of this subsection on a regional basis.
In establishing the scrap tire recycling system, the service:

subparagraph.text: Shall give preference to existing private or public scrap tire collection, processing, or recycling programs or facilities that meet the requirements of this subtitle; and
May include in-State facilities licensed by the Department as well as out-of-state facilities approved by the Department.

paragraph.text: Each scrap tire recycling system established under this subsection shall:

subparagraph.text: Meet all zoning and land use requirements of the county or municipal corporation in which the system is to be located; and
Be provided for in the county plan required under § 9-503 of this title.
Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, after January 1, 1994 scrap tires may not be disposed of in a landfill.

The Secretary may waive the requirements of subparagraph (i) of this paragraph under such terms and conditions and for such periods as the Department considers appropriate if the Department determines that a scrap tire recycling system:

sub-subparagraph.text: Does not exist; or
Has insufficient capacity to accommodate the amount of scrap tires generated in the State.

paragraph.text: A person may not dispose of scrap tires except through a licensed scrap tire hauler or by delivering the tires to an approved facility.

subparagraph.text: Beginning on February 1, 1992, a tire recycling fee shall be imposed on the first sale of a new tire in the State by a tire dealer, including new tires sold as part of a new or used vehicle, trailer, farm implement, or other similar machinery.
A county, municipal corporation, or any agency of a county or municipal corporation may not impose any tax, fee, or other charge on the first sale of a new tire by a tire dealer.

paragraph.text: The tire recycling fee:

subparagraph.text: May not exceed $1.00 per tire; and
Shall be established by the Board of Public Works.

paragraph.text: For a sale made by a tire dealer to a person who resells tires, the tire dealer shall separately state its recycling fees paid by the tire dealer on the invoice or other document of sale.
Each tire dealer shall:

subparagraph.text: Pay the tire recycling fee; and

Complete and submit, under oath, a return and remit the fees to the Comptroller of the Treasury on or before the 21st day of the month that follows the month in which the sale was made, and for other periods and on other dates that the Comptroller specifies by regulation, including periods for which no fees were due.

paragraph.text: A tire dealer who timely files a tire recycling fee return and pays the tire recycling fees due is allowed, for the expense of administering and paying the fee, a credit equal to 0.6% of the gross amount of tire recycling fees that the tire dealer is to pay to the Comptroller.

If the amount of the tire recycling fee is separately stated in a retail sale, the tire recycling fee is not subject to any tax under Title 11 of the Tax - General Article or Title 13 of the Transportation Article.
At the end of each quarter, the Comptroller shall forward all tire recycling fees to the Used Tire Cleanup and Recycling Fund, less the costs of administration.

Except to the extent they are inconsistent with this subsection, the provisions of Title 13 of the Tax - General Article applicable to the sales and use tax shall govern the administration, collection, and enforcement of the tire recycling fee under this subsection.
The Comptroller:

subparagraph.text: Shall administer the tire recycling fee; and
May adopt any regulations that are necessary or appropriate to administer, collect, and enforce the tire recycling fee.

subsection.text: Beginning on July 1, 1992, each scrap tire hauler shall:

paragraph.text: Be licensed by the Department to transport scrap tires from scrap tire collection facilities to scrap tire recyclers;
Apply for a scrap tire hauler’s license on a form provided by the Department; and
Transport each load of scrap tires to the scrap tire recyclers in accordance with regulations adopted by the Department.

subsection.text: Beginning on July 1, 1992, each scrap tire collection facility shall:

paragraph.text: If located in the State, be licensed by the Department to receive tires from a consumer or a scrap tire hauler;
Apply for a license on a form provided by the Department;
Meet all zoning and land use requirements of the county or municipal corporation in which the tire collection facility is to be located;
Manage scrap tires in accordance with regulations adopted by the Department;
By means of a scrap tire hauler, transfer scrap tires to:

subparagraph.text: A scrap tire recycler; or
Another scrap tire collection facility; and

paragraph.text: In accordance with regulations adopted by the Department and on forms provided by the Department, provide:

subparagraph.text: The Department with:

sub-subparagraph.text: A record of the destination;
The name of the hauler that is registered with the Department; and
The quantity of each shipment of scrap tires; and

subparagraph.text: Each hauler with:

sub-subparagraph.text: A record of the destination; and
The quantity of each shipment of scrap tires.

paragraph.text: Beginning on July 1, 1992, a person may not operate as a scrap tire recycler in the State unless the person is licensed by the Department.
To apply for a license an applicant shall submit:

subparagraph.text: An application to the Department on the form that the Department requires; and
Any document or other information required in regulations adopted by the Department.

paragraph.text: The Department shall adopt regulations necessary to administer the provisions of this section, including:

subparagraph.text: Minimum standards for the operation, maintenance, monitoring, reporting, and suspension of each scrap tire recycling system;
Requisite evidence of financial ability to properly establish, operate, and maintain a scrap tire recycling system, including the posting of bonds and other securities; and
The forfeiture of bonds and other securities for noncompliance with the requirements of this section or any applicable regulation.

paragraph.text: The Department may require the delivery of scrap tires in this State to 1 or more facilities, in the State or outside of the State, designated by the service as part of the tire recycling system.
A scrap tire hauler or scrap tire collection facility may not transport or transfer scrap tires to any place other than a facility designated under paragraph (2) of this subsection.

subsection.text: A requirement in this subtitle that a document be under oath means that the document shall be supported by a signed statement made under the penalties of perjury that the contents of the document are true to the best of the knowledge, information, and belief of the individual making the statement.
The oath or affirmation shall be made:

paragraph.text: Before an individual authorized to administer oaths, who shall certify in writing to have administered the oath or taken the affirmation; or
By a signed statement that:

subparagraph.text: Is in the document or attached to and made part of the document; and
Is expressly made under the penalties for perjury.

subsection.text: If the procedures provided in subsection (b)(2) of this section are used, the affidavit subjects the individual making it to the penalties for perjury to the same extent as an oath or affirmation made before an individual authorized to administer oaths.
A document made under oath shall be signed:

paragraph.text: For a corporation, by an officer of the corporation authorized to do so;
For a sole proprietorship, by its owner; or
For a partnership, by a partner authorized to do so.

subsection.text: Unless the Secretary determines that a removal and remedial action will be done properly and in a timely manner by the owner or operator of a site where used tires are stored or disposed of, if used tires are stored or disposed of at a site in a manner that may present a threat to the public health or environment, the Secretary may:

paragraph.text: Act to remove or arrange for the removal of the used tires and provide for remedial action necessary to restore any natural resources; or
Take any other response measure that the Secretary considers necessary to protect the public health or welfare or the environment.

subsection.text: Nothing in this section shall prohibit the Secretary from abating a nuisance under the provisions of Title 10 of this article, regardless of the volume of used tires stored.

paragraph.text: The Department of the Environment shall adopt regulations to carry out this Part III of this subtitle.
The Department of the Environment may not adopt a regulation or part of a regulation that deals with the land application of sewage sludge without the approval of the Department of Agriculture.

subsection.text: In adopting regulations under this Part III and §§ 9-269 and 9-270 of this subtitle, the Department of the Environment shall consider:

paragraph.text: Alternative utilization methods;
Pathogen control;
Advertising requirements for public hearings and public information meetings;
Performance bonds, liability insurance, or other forms of security;
Procedures for notifying units of local government and other interested parties; and
Adequate standards for transporting sewage sludge, including requirements for enclosing or covering sewage sludge during transportation.

subsection.text: In addition to the considerations under subsection (b) of this section, in adopting regulations for the land application of sewage sludge, the Department of the Environment shall consider:

paragraph.text: Methods for calculating loading rates that:

subparagraph.text: Will assure nondegradation of the groundwater supply; and
For agricultural land, shall be limited by the nutrient requirements of crop or cover vegetation, as recommended by the Department of Agriculture;

paragraph.text: The crops that are to be grown on land on which sewage sludge may be applied;
The nature of any nearby surface water or groundwater;
The character of any affected area;
The character of nearby existing or planned land uses and transport routes;
The nearness of the land on which sewage sludge may be applied to sensitive areas, including flood plains, wetlands, and areas of critical concern;
The definitions of:

subparagraph.text: Sewage sludge that is unsuitable for application to agricultural land;
Agricultural land;
Marginal land; and
Compost;

paragraph.text: Acceptable cumulative loading rates, including rates for nitrogen and heavy metals;
Special requirements of land used for producing tobacco; and
Reasonable buffer areas to separate any home or other property from land on which sewage sludge may be applied.
The Department shall adopt regulations to establish a mechanism for determining annual generator’s fees.
The regulations shall provide for public input into the development of fee schedules.
The fee schedules shall take into account:

subparagraph.text: The volume of sewage sludge generated by a sewage sludge generator;
The method by which the sewage sludge is utilized;
The anticipated costs of monitoring and regulating sewage sludge utilization sites;
The anticipated needs of the State’s sewage sludge regulation program; and
The potential hazard of the sewage sludge generator’s activities to public health, safety, or welfare or to the environment.

subsection.text: A person shall have a sewage sludge utilization permit before the person utilizes sewage sludge in this State.
A person shall have a separate sewage sludge utilization permit for each site where the person utilizes sewage sludge.
An applicant for a sewage sludge utilization permit shall:

paragraph.text: Submit an application to the Department on the form that the Department requires;
Certify by signature the truth and accuracy of the completed application;
Pay the application fee set by the Department to cover the cost of processing the application;
Obtain the written consent of the owner of the land where the sewage sludge will be applied, including an agreement that the owner will not violate the permit; and
Agree to permit or secure access to the sewage sludge utilization site for the purpose of any inspection permitted under § 9-243 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Before a sewage sludge utilization permit is issued, the applicant for the permit shall:

paragraph.text: File with the Department acceptable evidence of a bond or other security that the Department requires under § 9-240 of this subtitle; and
Satisfy every other requirement of this Part III of this subtitle.

section.text: The Department may not issue a permit to install, materially alter, or materially extend a sewage sludge composting facility or a sewage sludge storage facility until:

paragraph.text: The sewage sludge composting facility or sewage sludge storage facility meets all zoning and land use requirements of the county where the sewage sludge composting or storage facility is to be located; and

In the case of a sewage sludge composting facility, the Department has a written statement that the board of county commissioners or the county council of the county where the sewage sludge composting facility is to be located does not oppose the issuance of the permit.

subsection.text: When the Department receives an application for a permit to utilize sewage sludge at a site, the Department immediately shall mail a copy of the permit application:

paragraph.text: To the legislative body and any elected executive of a county and to the elected executive of any municipal corporation where the sewage sludge utilization site is to be located; and
To the legislative body and any elected executive of any other county within 1 mile of the sewage sludge utilization site.

subsection.text: For a permit to apply sewage sludge on marginal land or to construct a permanent facility that is designed primarily to utilize sewage sludge, the Department shall:

paragraph.text: Publish notice of the application in a local newspaper having a substantial circulation in the county where the sewage sludge is to be applied or the facility is to be constructed;
Mail a copy of the notice to:

subparagraph.text: The local health official;
The chairman of the legislative body and any elected executive of the county where the sewage sludge is to be applied or the facility is to be constructed;
The elected executive of any municipal corporation where the sewage sludge is to be applied or the facility is to be constructed; and
Any other county within 1 mile of where the sewage sludge is to be applied or the facility is to be constructed.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in § 9–234.1 of this subtitle, within 15 days after receiving a copy of the permit application, the executive or the legislative body of the county, or the executive or the legislative body of the municipal corporation, where the sewage sludge is to be applied or the facility is to be constructed may request that the Department hold a public hearing.

If the Department receives a request under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Department shall hold a public hearing in the affected subdivision in accordance with the Administrative Procedure Act.
If the executives or legislative bodies of more than 1 county or municipal corporation request a hearing under this subsection, the Department may hold a consolidated hearing in 1 county.

subsection.text: For a permit to apply sewage sludge on land other than marginal land, the Department shall mail a copy of the permit application to:

paragraph.text: The local health official;
The chairman of the legislative body and any elected executive of the county where the sewage sludge is to be applied; and
The elected executive of any municipal corporation where the sewage sludge is to be applied.

Within 10 days after receiving a copy of the permit application, the executive or the legislative body of the county, or the executive or the legislative body of the municipal corporation, where the sewage sludge is to be applied may request that the Department conduct a public information meeting.
If the Department receives a request under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Department:

subparagraph.text: Shall conduct a public information meeting in the affected subdivision;
May consolidate the public information meeting with 1 or more public information meetings for other applications in the same county; and
Shall notify the applicant for a permit and give the applicant the opportunity to present information at the public information meeting.

paragraph.text: If the executives or legislative bodies of more than 1 county or municipal corporation request a public information meeting under this subsection, the Department may hold a consolidated public information meeting in 1 county.

subsection.text: The Department shall provide each county and municipal corporation that receives a copy of any application under this section with an opportunity to consult with the Department about the decision to issue, deny, or place restrictions on a sewage sludge utilization permit.
This section does not apply to the storage or distribution of sewage sludge at a sewage treatment plant.

Before the Secretary issues, amends, or renews a permit to an applicant or permit holder under § 9-232 or § 9-238 of this subtitle to install, materially alter, or materially extend a structure used for storage or distribution of any type of sewage sludge, the Department shall hold a public hearing on the application, amendment, or renewal.
The Department shall hold a public hearing in the affected subdivision in accordance with the Administrative Procedure Act.
If more than 1 county or municipal corporation will be affected by the granting of the sludge storage permit application, the Department may hold a consolidated hearing in any affected subdivision.

section.text: The Department shall send to the local health official and the local soil conservation district:

paragraph.text: A copy of any sewage sludge utilization permit issued in the county;
Notice of the denial of an application in the county for a sewage sludge utilization permit;
Notice of the suspension, revocation, modification, or termination of a sewage sludge utilization permit issued in the county;
A copy of any notice, complaint, or order that the Department issues in the county under Part III of this subtitle; and
A copy of any report filed with the Department pursuant to a condition of the permit.

section.text: The Department shall issue a sewage sludge utilization permit to an applicant who meets the requirements of this Part III of this subtitle.

subsection.text: A sewage sludge utilization permit authorizes the permit holder to utilize sewage sludge according to the terms of the permit.

Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, if the utilizer is unable to utilize the sewage sludge as defined in the permit, the utilizer may return the sewage sludge to the generator provided that the utilizer obtains a new comprehensive analysis of the sewage sludge to be returned that indicates that:

paragraph.text: The sewage sludge meets all applicable permit requirements; and
The sewage sludge may be utilized in the same manner, without additional treatment, as the sewage sludge that is generated by the generator.

subsection.text: If the utilizer returns the sewage sludge within 96 hours of the departure from the generator, the utilizer may not be required to obtain a new analysis of the sewage sludge.
A sewage sludge utilization permit expires on the date the Department sets at the time of issuance or renewal, unless the permit is renewed for another term as provided in this section.
Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, the Department may renew a sewage sludge utilization permit if the permit holder:

paragraph.text: Is in compliance with the permit and all appropriate regulations of the Department;
Submits to the Department a renewal application on the form that the Department requires; and
Pays the renewal application fee that the Department requires.

subsection.text: The Department may not renew or amend a permit to install, materially alter, or materially extend a structure used for storage or distribution of any type of sewage sludge unless the Department holds a public hearing on the renewal or amendment, as provided in § 9-234.1 of this subtitle.

section.text: A sewage sludge utilization permit in effect on July 1, 1984 remains in effect until the expiration date of the permit.
To keep a sewage sludge utilization permit, a person shall:

paragraph.text: Maintain a performance bond or other security in the amount that the Department considers sufficient to guarantee the fulfillment of any requirement related to the permit; and
Comply with each other requirement that the Department sets.

section.text: To allow the public to identify every permit that the Department issues for a particular tract of land, the Department shall maintain a permanent public record of all sewage sludge utilization permits issued under § 9-236 of this subtitle.
The Department shall require each holder of a sewage sludge utilization permit to:

paragraph.text: Keep records, including daily records of the source and amount of sewage sludge for each truckload delivered to the site;
Make reports, including reports of sewage sludge analysis, as often as necessary to assure that the sewage sludge meets permit requirements;

Have a copy of the report of sewage sludge analysis that is required under item (2) of this section available on the vehicle transporting the sewage sludge while the sewage sludge is being transported in the State;
Install, calibrate, use, and maintain monitoring equipment or methods, including biological monitoring methods and well monitoring, if appropriate;
Take samples in accordance with the methods, at the locations, at the intervals, and in the manner that the Department requires; and
Give to a representative of the Department or the local health official any information that the Department reasonably requires.

subsection.text: To enforce this Part III of this subtitle and to insure compliance with each sewage sludge utilization permit, a representative of the Department, the local health official, or the local health official’s designee may enter and inspect, at any reasonable time, any site where sewage sludge is utilized.
A sewage sludge utilizer may not:

paragraph.text: Refuse access to a sewage sludge utilization site to any representative of the Department, to a local health official, or to the local health official’s designee, who requests access under this section; or
Interfere with any inspection under this subtitle.

subsection.text: A local health official or the local health official’s designee may inspect, monitor, and investigate any sewage sludge utilization site in the county where the official is employed.

paragraph.text: With the concurrence of the Department, a local health official may:

subparagraph.text: Issue a stop work order to stop utilizing sewage sludge at a site; and
Suspend a sewage sludge utilization permit.

paragraph.text: If a local health official recommends issuance of a stop work order and the Department does not concur, the Department shall inspect the sewage sludge utilization site within 24 hours after it receives the recommendation.

After inspecting the site and if necessary, the Department shall issue a stop work or other order to obtain compliance with State law, departmental regulations, or the sewage sludge utilization permit.
A county may seek injunctive relief or other appropriate remedies in circuit court if:

subparagraph.text: A local health official is not satisfied that the enforcement measures of the Department are adequate to protect public health and safety in the county; or
The Department does not make the inspection required by paragraph (2) of this subsection.

paragraph.text: A local health official shall:

subparagraph.text: Give the Department prompt notice of any inspection made by the local health official; and
Report promptly in writing to the Department:

sub-subparagraph.text: The time and place of the inspection;
A summary and findings of the inspection;
Any enforcement action that the local health official takes or recommends; and
Any permit modifications or other modifications that the local health official recommends.

paragraph.text: The Department:

subparagraph.text: May delegate to the local health official any inspection, monitoring, or enforcement authority of the Department under this Part III of this subtitle; and
Shall adopt regulations that establish standards for delegating authority under this subsection.

paragraph.text: The regulations adopted under this subsection shall include:

subparagraph.text: Procedures for submission, review, and approval or disapproval of any application for delegation of authority;
Provisions requiring that any application for delegation of authority be approved by the county;
Provisions for oversight by the Department, including program evaluations and financial audits; and
Provisions for revocation of a delegation, if the local health official fails to comply with the terms of a delegation agreement.

paragraph.text: If the Department finds that an application for delegation of authority meets all applicable requirements of this section and the regulations adopted under this section, the Department shall enter into a written delegation agreement.

The Department shall establish performance standards for grants to provide reasonable reimbursement to counties, to the extent funds are available, for costs local health officials incur when they undertake authority delegated under this subsection.
A local health official may act through a designee under this subsection in accordance with an approved delegation agreement.

section.text: The Department shall credit all sewage sludge generator’s fees, permit application fees, funds that the Department collects under this Part III and §§ 9–269 and 9–270 of this subtitle, and any civil or administrative penalty or fine imposed by a court under the provisions of this subtitle to the Maryland Clean Water Fund established under § 9–320 of this title.
The Department shall deny an application for a sewage sludge utilization permit if the Department finds that:

paragraph.text: The applicant cannot utilize sewage sludge without:

subparagraph.text: Causing an undue risk to the environment or public health, safety, or welfare; or
Otherwise violating this Part III, § 9-269, or § 9-270 of this subtitle;

paragraph.text: The sewage sludge generator from which the sludge originated has not paid applicable generator’s fees; or
The sewage sludge has been generated in a state in which the laws or application of those laws do not result in the land application of sewage sludge in that state.

subsection.text: The Department may suspend, revoke, or modify a sewage sludge utilization permit in accordance with the Administrative Procedure Act if the Department finds that:

paragraph.text: The permit application contained false or inaccurate information;
There has been a substantial deviation from:

subparagraph.text: The plans, specifications, or other documents approved by the Department; or
Any requirement established by the Department;

paragraph.text: A representative of the Department has been refused entry to any area covered by the permit for the purpose of inspecting the area to ensure compliance with the conditions of the permit;

There is or has been a violation of this Part III, § 9-269, or § 9-270 of this subtitle, any regulation adopted under this Part III, § 9-269, or § 9-270 of this subtitle, or any condition of the permit; or
There is any other good cause.

subsection.text: The Department may refuse to renew a sewage sludge utilization permit if:

paragraph.text: The permit holder violates this subtitle, any regulation adopted by the Department under this subtitle, or any condition of the permit;
The Department determines that continued operation of any area covered by the permit would be injurious to public health or the environment; or
The Department determines that there is any other good cause.

subsection.text: Any person who owns land that adjoins land for which an application to apply sewage sludge is filed, or for which a permit to apply sewage sludge is issued, has standing:

paragraph.text: To sue the State, the applicant, or the permit holder to require compliance with this Part III, § 9-269, or § 9-270 of this subtitle and any permit issued under § 9-236 of this subtitle; and
With respect to the sewage sludge utilization site, to intervene in:

subparagraph.text: Any civil court proceeding; and
Any contested administrative case.

subsection.text: Any county or municipal corporation in which there is land for which an application to apply sewage sludge is filed, or for which a permit to apply sewage sludge is issued, has standing:

paragraph.text: To sue the applicant or the permit holder to require compliance with this Part III, § 9-269, or § 9-270 of this subtitle and any permit issued under § 9-236 of this subtitle; and
With respect to the sewage sludge utilization site, to intervene in:

subparagraph.text: Any civil court proceeding; and
Any contested administrative case.

section.text: In addition to any other remedy authorized under this subtitle, the Department may bring an action to enjoin the violation of any law, regulation, or order concerning the utilization of sewage sludge under this Part III, § 9-269, or § 9-270 of this subtitle.
A person may not utilize sewage sludge in this State except in accordance with this Part III, § 9-269, or § 9-270 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: To prevent or correct pollution of the waters of this State, the Secretary may:

subparagraph.text: Adopt and enforce regulations; and
Order works to be executed.

paragraph.text: The Secretary may:

subparagraph.text: Require any public water supply system, public sewerage system, or refuse disposal system to be operated in a manner that will protect public health and comfort; and
Order the alteration, extension, or replacement of any public water supply system, public sewerage system, or refuse disposal system.

subsection.text: The Secretary:

paragraph.text: Has supervision and control over the sanitary and physical condition of the waters of this State to protect public health and comfort;
Shall investigate:

subparagraph.text: All sources of water and ice; and
All points of sewage discharge;

paragraph.text: Shall examine all public water supply systems, public sewerage systems, and refuse disposal systems; and
Shall approve or disapprove the design and construction of any public water supply system, public sewerage system, or refuse disposal system that is to be built in this State.

subsection.text: The powers and duties of the Secretary under this section are in addition to the powers and duties set forth elsewhere in this subtitle.
For purposes of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, the Secretary is the State water pollution control agency in this State.
The Secretary has all powers that are necessary to comply with and represent this State under the Federal Water Pollution Control Act.
Another unit of the State government may not exercise any power given to the Secretary under this section.

section.text: Within the limits in the State budget, the Secretary may employ and set the compensation of any expert, engineer, clerical assistant, or other assistant that the Secretary considers necessary to carry out this subtitle.

The Department of the Environment and the Department of Natural Resources shall each make any test of water or wastewater that it considers necessary to determine the adequacy of performance of a water supply system, sewerage system, or industrial wastewater treatment plant.

subsection.text: If the Secretary serves an order on the State or any county, municipal corporation, or public water supply, sewerage, or sanitary district, the appropriate official or department of the State, county, municipal corporation, or district shall raise any funds that are necessary to comply on time with the order of the Secretary.

If the Governor and the Attorney General approve, a county, municipal corporation, or public water supply, sewerage, or sanitary district may raise funds under subsection (a) of this section by issuing bonds, stock, or notes without legislative authority other than this section.
The question of whether to issue bonds, stock, or notes under this section need not be put to a referendum of the voters.
The proceeds of any bonds, stock, or notes issued under this section:

paragraph.text: Constitute a sanitary fund; and
May be used only to carry out the order of the Secretary.

The total amount of all bonds, stock, and notes being issued at any time under this section, together with all bonds, stock, and notes then outstanding from prior issues under this section or any predecessor of this section, may not exceed 5% of the total value of all property that, at the time of issue, is listed and assessed for taxation in the county, municipal corporation, or district.
The indebtedness authorized by this section is in addition to the total indebtedness otherwise permitted by law.
Bonds, stock, and notes issued under this section are:

subparagraph.text: Forever exempt from State, county, and municipal taxation;
A lien on all property in the jurisdiction that issues the bonds, stock, or notes; and
Payable in the same manner as bonds issued by municipal authorities under Part II of Subtitle 7 of this title.

subsection.text: Unless the Secretary approves the expenditure, including the amount of the expenditure, neither the State nor any county, municipal corporation, or public water supply, sewerage, or sanitary district may spend any public money for any of the purposes of this subtitle.
Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section:

paragraph.text: If the Secretary finds that the water or ice from any source is or is likely to become dangerous to health, the Secretary shall order that the source of water or ice be closed; and

If the Secretary finds that any discharge of sewage or any method of disposal of sewage or refuse is or is likely to become prejudicial to health or comfort, the Secretary shall order that the point of sewage discharge be abandoned or the method of disposal be discontinued.

subsection.text: If the Secretary finds that the conditions found under subsection (a) of this section can be remedied sufficiently and practicably by installing any work or device or by taking any other remedial measure, the Secretary may order that:

paragraph.text: The work or device be installed; or
The remedial measure be taken.

subsection.text: If the Secretary condemns a water supply system, sewerage system, or refuse disposal system, the Secretary may order the owner to make arrangements that will prevent the operation of the system.
Any order issued under this section shall set a reasonable time for compliance.

section.text: If any lot or parcel of land in Garrett County is used as a site for a trailer park, motel, mobile motel, condominium, apartment house, or other facility with multiple bedrooms, and if any resulting sewage is disposed of underground on the lot or parcel, the lot or parcel shall have:

paragraph.text: An area of at least 20,000 square feet for each 6 bedrooms or fraction of 6 bedrooms in the facility; and
A width of at least 100 feet for each 6 bedrooms or fraction of 6 bedrooms in the facility.

subsection.text: The following sanitary districts and persons shall keep any record that the Secretary requires:

paragraph.text: Any sanitary district or person who supplies water, ice, sewerage, or refuse disposal service to the public;
Any person who owns an industrial establishment; and
Any person who owns a private water supply system or private sewerage system.

subsection.text: Any sanitary district or person who keeps a record under subsection (a) of this section shall make the record available to the Secretary on request.

paragraph.text: To determine compliance with any regulation, permit, or order of the Secretary, a representative of the Secretary may:

subparagraph.text: Enter any private property;
Enter any building, structure, or land owned by a sanitary district or person who supplies water, ice, sewerage, or refuse disposal service to the public; and
Collect samples, records, and information.

paragraph.text: To determine compliance with pretreatment requirements of this title, a representative of the Secretary may:

subparagraph.text: Enter any building, structure, or land of an industrial establishment that is or may be subject to pretreatment requirements; and
Collect samples, records, and information.

subsection.text: The Secretary may bring an action for an injunction to enforce this section without showing lack of an adequate remedy at law.
This section does not apply to the expiration, revocation, or modification of a sewage sludge utilization permit.
The Secretary may revoke or change any permit issued under this subtitle after the Secretary gives the permit holder notice of the proposed revocation or change.
If the term of a permit issued under this subtitle is stated in the permit, the permit expires at the end of the stated term.

section.text: Any county, municipality, legally constituted water, sewerage or sanitary district, institution, or person dissatisfied with any order, rule, or regulation of the Secretary under this subtitle may commence, within 10 days after the service of the order, rule, or regulation, an action in the circuit court for any county to vacate and set aside the order, rule, or regulation on the ground that the order, rule, or regulation is unlawful or unreasonable, or that the order is not necessary for the protection of the public health or comfort, in which action a copy of the complaint shall be served with the summons. The answer of the Secretary shall be filed within 10 days, whereupon the cause shall be at issue, and stand ready for trial upon 15 days’ notice to either party. Any action under this section shall have precedence over any civil cause of a different nature, except appeals from an order of the Public Service Commission. The courts shall always be deemed open for trial of an action under this section and any action under this section shall be tried and determined as other civil actions. Either party to an action under this section may appeal to the Court of Special Appeals.
The provisions of §§ 7-256 through 7-268 of this article shall be used and shall apply to enforce violations of § 9-227(b) of this subtitle.

Except for violations of Part III of this subtitle and violations enforced under §§ 9–229(b), 9–267, and 9–268.1 of this subtitle, the provisions of §§ 9–334 through 9–344 of this title shall be used and shall apply to enforce violations of:

paragraph.text: This subtitle;
Any regulation adopted under this subtitle; or
Any order or permit issued under this subtitle.

subsection.text: In addition to other penalties authorized under this subtitle:

paragraph.text: A person who violates § 9-228(f)(2) of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000, or imprisonment not exceeding 30 days or both;

A person who violates § 9-228(f)(2) of this subtitle for monetary or financial gain is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $25,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 5 years or both; and

A person who violates § 9-228(b), (h)(1), (i)(1), or (j)(1) of this subtitle, or a regulation, order, or permit adopted or issued under § 9-228(b), (h)(1), (i)(1), or (j)(1) of this subtitle, is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $10,000.
The Attorney General shall represent the State in every case arising under § 9–228 of this subtitle.
This subsection may not limit or affect the power of State’s Attorneys under § 15–102 of the Criminal Procedure Article.

A person who violates any provision of Part III of this subtitle or any rule, regulation, order, or permit adopted or issued under Part III of this subtitle is liable to the State for civil penalties.
These civil penalties are:

subparagraph.text: A basic civil penalty not exceeding $10,000; and
An additional penalty not exceeding $10,000 a day for each day that the violation continues, up to a maximum of $50,000.

paragraph.text: The State shall recover the civil penalties under this section in a civil action.

In addition to any other remedies available at law or in equity and after an opportunity for a hearing which may be waived in writing by the person accused of a violation, the Department may impose a penalty for violation of any provision of Part III of this subtitle or any regulation, order, or permit adopted or issued under Part III of this subtitle.
The penalty imposed on a person under this subsection shall be:

subparagraph.text: Up to $1,000 for each violation, but not exceeding $50,000 total; and
Assessed with consideration given to:

sub-subparagraph.text: The willfulness of the violation, the extent to which the existence of the violation was known to but uncorrected by the violator, and the extent to which the violator exercised reasonable care;
Any actual harm to the environment or to human health, including injury to or impairment of the use of the waters of the State or the natural resources of the State;
The cost of cleanup and the cost of restoration of natural resources;
The nature and degree of injury to or interference with general welfare, health, and property;

The extent to which the location of the violation, including location near waters of the State or areas of human population, creates the potential for harm to the environment or to human health or safety;
The available technology and economic reasonableness of controlling, reducing, or eliminating the violation; and
The extent to which the current violation is part of a recurrent pattern of the same or similar type of violation committed by the violator.

paragraph.text: Each day a violation occurs is a separate violation under this subsection.
Any penalty imposed under this subsection is payable to the State and collectible in any manner provided by law for the collection of debts.
If any person who is liable to pay a penalty imposed under this subsection fails to pay it after demand, the amount, together with interest and any costs that may accrue, shall be:

subparagraph.text: A lien in favor of the State on any property, real or personal, of the person; and
Recorded in the office of the clerk of court for the county in which the property is located.

paragraph.text: Any penalty collected under this subsection shall be placed in the Maryland Clean Water Fund under § 9–320 of this title.

Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, in addition to any other penalties set forth in this section, if any sewage sludge utilizer violates the terms of the permit by any action or inaction of the utilizer that results in the return of the sewage sludge to the generator, the utilizer is liable to the State for civil penalties.
The civil penalty imposed under this subsection may not exceed $100 for each wet ton of sewage sludge returned to the generator.
The provisions of this subsection do not apply if the violation is not caused by any action or inaction of the utilizer.
