subparagraph.text: Shall not exceed 75 percent of all eligible costs; and
Shall not exceed $500,000.

paragraph.text: In addition to cost sharing funds provided under Title 8, Subtitle 7 of the Agriculture Article, grants may be awarded for projects to implement best management practices to prevent or control agriculturally related nonpoint sources of water pollution on State land or to governmental entities in other areas in which the potential for water pollution from agriculture is substantial. When cost sharing funds are provided under Title 8, Subtitle 7 of the Agriculture Article, the procedures and requirements of that law rather than § 9–345 of this subtitle apply.

Grants awarded under this subsection to governmental entities or for use on State land may be awarded for up to 100 percent of the total cost of a project. However, in awarding such grants, the applicant’s financial capability to cost share and any resultant economic benefit shall be considered in determining the extent of any required matching dollar amount.
All grants awarded under this subsection shall be made after prior consultation with the Secretary of Agriculture.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall report on or before January 15 of each year to the Governor and, subject to § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, the General Assembly on the status of the Water Pollution Control Fund.
The Secretary’s report shall include:

paragraph.text: The total amounts of funds expended;
The total amounts of funds committed;
The total amount of funds remaining;
A list of projects for which funds have been expended or are committed;
A projection of projects to be constructed in the near future for which grants, loans, or loan guarantees will be made;
An evaluation of the program’s effectiveness; and
Projections as to future funding requirements.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Administrator” means the Administrator of the United States Environmental Protection Agency.
“Community water system” means a public water system that:

paragraph.text: Serves at least 15 service connections used by year–round residents of the area served by the system; or
Regularly serves at least 25 year–round residents.

subsection.text: “Contaminant” means any chemical, biological, or radioactive substance that is harmful to health if in the water.
“Federal Act” means the federal Safe Drinking Water Act.
“Federal agency” means any department, agency, or instrumentality of the United States.
“National primary drinking water regulations” means the primary drinking water rules or regulations that the Administrator adopts under the federal Act.
“Noncommunity water system” means a public water system that is not a community water system.
“Nontransient noncommunity water system” means a public water system that is not a community system and that regularly serves at least 25 of the same individuals over 6 months per year.
“Person” includes:

paragraph.text: The Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission;
Any State, county, municipal corporation, or federal agency;
Any special taxing area or district that operates a public water system; and
Any officer, agent, or employee of any of these.

subsection.text: “Primary drinking water regulation” means a rule or regulation that:

paragraph.text: Applies to public water systems;
Specifies contaminants that, in the judgment of the Secretary, would have an adverse effect on the health of human beings;
Specifies for each contaminant either:

subparagraph.text: A maximum contaminant level if, in the judgment of the Secretary, it is economically and technologically feasible to determine the level of the contaminant in water in public water systems; or

If, in the judgment of the Secretary, it is not economically or technologically feasible to determine the level of the contaminant, each treatment technique known to the Secretary that leads to a reduction in the level of the contaminant sufficient to satisfy the requirements of this subtitle; and

paragraph.text: Contains standards and procedures:

subparagraph.text: To ensure a supply of drinking water that dependably complies with the maximum contaminant levels, including quality control and testing procedures for compliance with those levels;
To ensure proper operation and maintenance of the system; and
To establish requirements as to:

sub-subparagraph.text: The minimum quality of water that may be taken into the system; and
Siting for new facilities for public water systems.

paragraph.text: “Public water system” means a system that:

subparagraph.text: Provides to the public water for human consumption through pipes or other constructed conveyances; and

sub-subparagraph.text: Has at least 15 service connections; or
Regularly serves at least 25 individuals.

paragraph.text: “Public water system” includes:

subparagraph.text: Any collection, treatment, storage, or distribution facility that is under the control of the operator of the system and is used primarily in connection with the system; and
Any collection or pretreatment storage facility that is not under the control of the operator of the system and is used primarily in connection with the system.

subsection.text: “Supplier of water” means any person who owns or operates a public water system.
“Transient noncommunity water system” means a noncommunity water system that does not regularly serve at least 25 of the same individuals over 6 months per year.
“Tamper” means to:

paragraph.text: Introduce a contaminant into a public water system with the intention of harming a person; or
Otherwise interfere with the operation of a public water system with the intention of harming a person.

section.text: The purpose of this subtitle is to ensure that this State has the primary enforcement responsibility for drinking water standards under the federal Safe Drinking Water Act.

subsection.text: This subtitle does not affect any other express powers conferred by statute on the Department of the Environment or the Department of Natural Resources.

The powers, duties, and authority of the Department under this subtitle supplement and are ancillary to any other provisions of this article and the Health - General Article that relate to the Secretary’s authority and responsibility to assure the purity and sanitary condition of the water supply.

section.text: To carry out the provisions of this subtitle and in addition to the powers set forth elsewhere in this subtitle, the Secretary may:

paragraph.text: Perform any act necessary to carry out the provisions of this subtitle that relate to adopting or enforcing State primary drinking water regulations;
Administer the provisions of this subtitle and all rules, regulations, and orders adopted, issued, or effective under this subtitle;
Enter into agreements, contracts, or cooperative arrangements, under appropriate terms and conditions, with any person or governmental entity;
Receive financial and technical assistance from the federal government or other public or private agencies;
Participate in related programs of the federal government, other states, interstate agencies, or other public or private agencies or organizations;

Establish adequate fiscal controls and accounting procedures to assure proper disbursement of and accounting for funds appropriated or otherwise provided for the purpose of carrying out provisions of this subtitle;
Delegate any responsibilities and duties the Secretary considers appropriate for administering the requirements of this subtitle;
Set and collect fees for conducting necessary inspections and laboratory analyses; and
Adopt rules and regulations that are necessary or appropriate to carry out the Secretary’s functions under this subtitle.

subsection.text: In this section, “dangerous contaminant” means a contaminant that, if present in a public water system, would present an imminent and substantial danger to the health of individuals.

paragraph.text: On receipt of information that a dangerous contaminant is present in or likely to enter a public water system, the Secretary may take any action necessary to protect the health of the individuals whose health is or would be endangered by the dangerous contaminant.
The actions that the Secretary may take under this section include:

subparagraph.text: Issuing any order necessary to protect the health of individuals who are or may be users of the public water system; and
Suing for injunctive or other appropriate relief.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall adopt an adequate plan for providing safe drinking water under emergency circumstances.

If, in the judgment of the Secretary, emergency circumstances exist with respect to a need for safe drinking water, the Secretary may take any action necessary to provide safe drinking water where it otherwise would not be available.

paragraph.text: Notwithstanding § 9-407(b) of this subtitle, the Secretary may adopt and enforce regulations for a contaminant if the Secretary determines that the contaminant poses a significant risk to public health and for which complete interim or revised national primary drinking water regulations are not in effect.
As part of the Secretary’s determination under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Secretary shall prepare a report that includes:

subparagraph.text: 1 year of statewide monitoring data for the contaminant, which identifies locations in the State where the contaminant level may pose a significant risk to public health;
Peer reviewed assessments, methodologies, and data concerning the particular contaminant; and
A cost/benefit analysis of implementing the proposed standard for the contaminant conducted by the Department that includes:

sub-subparagraph.text: Review and comment by the Department of Business and Economic Development; and

After the Department provides notice of the analysis and a reasonable opportunity to comment to the affected public water systems, any submitted written statements from public water systems affected by the proposed standard.

paragraph.text: Nothing in this subsection affects the Department’s authority to adopt and enforce complete interim or revised national primary drinking water regulations.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall:

paragraph.text: Adopt and enforce State primary drinking water regulations; and
Adopt and implement adequate procedures for enforcing the State primary drinking water regulations.

subsection.text: The State primary drinking water regulations may not:

paragraph.text: Be more stringent than the complete interim or revised national primary drinking water regulations in effect at the time; or
Require the addition of any substance for preventive health care purposes unrelated to contamination of drinking water.

subsection.text: The enforcement procedures shall:

paragraph.text: Include monitoring and inspection procedures; and
Comply with all rules and regulations adopted by the Administrator under the federal Act.

subsection.text: As the Administrator requires by rules or regulations adopted under the federal Act, the Secretary shall keep records and make reports with respect to the Secretary’s activities under this section.
Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, and subject to § 9-409 of this subtitle, State primary drinking water regulations shall apply to every public water system in this State.
The State primary drinking water regulations do not apply to a public water system that:

paragraph.text: Consists only of distribution and storage facilities, and does not have any collection and treatment facilities;
Obtains all of its water from, but is not owned or operated by, a public water system to which the State primary drinking water regulations apply;
Does not sell water to any person; and
Is not a carrier that conveys passengers in interstate commerce.

section.text: The Secretary may authorize variances or exemptions from the rules and regulations issued in accordance with § 9–407 of this subtitle, under conditions and in a manner necessary and desirable. However, the variances or exemptions are permitted only under conditions and in a manner that is not less stringent than the conditions under, and the manner in which, variances and exemptions may be granted under the federal Act.

subsection.text: Each supplier of water shall give notice to the Department and the persons served by the system and shall give written notice to noncollegiate educational institutions, public schools, family child care homes, and child care centers whenever the system:

paragraph.text: Fails to comply with an applicable maximum contaminant level, treatment technique requirement, or testing procedure prescribed by a drinking water regulation or fails to perform required monitoring;
Is subject to variance granted for an inability to meet a maximum contaminant level;
Is subject to an exemption;
Fails to comply with the requirements set by a variance or exemption; or
Has concentration levels of an unregulated contaminant for which the State may require notice due to the risk to public health.

subsection.text: Each notice shall:

paragraph.text: State the nature and possible health effects that may result;
Be provided to the persons served by the water system;
Be issued in a timely manner by means of radio, television, newspaper of general circulation, written notice, or other means acceptable to the Department; and
Be in a form readily understandable by the affected population.
By rule or regulation, the Secretary shall adopt notice requirements to meet the requirements of this section.
The rules and regulations shall establish notification standards and procedures that include the manner, frequency, form, and content of the notices.

subsection.text: For violations with the potential to have serious adverse effects on human health as a result of short–term exposure, the supplier of water shall provide notice as soon as practicable, but not later than 24 hours after the occurrence of the violation.

For violations other than the violations described in subsection (d) of this section, the supplier of water shall provide written notice to each person served by the system in an annual report, or by mail not later than 1 year after the violation.

paragraph.text: Each nontransient noncommunity water system, including those systems that primarily provide bottled water, shall:

subparagraph.text: At a frequency determined by the Department, test the water provided by the system for the presence of methyl tertiary butyl ether; and
Report the test results to the Department.

paragraph.text: If a test conducted under this subsection indicates that the level of methyl tertiary butyl ether in the drinking water exceeds the State advisory level, as determined by the Department, the water system shall give notice of that fact to:

subparagraph.text: The persons regularly served by the water system; and

If the water system serves a child care center, an elementary or secondary school, or any other facility that regularly serves minors, the parents or legal guardians of all minors regularly served by the water system.

section.text: In addition to any other remedy authorized under this subtitle, the Secretary may bring an action to enjoin any violation of any rule, regulation, or order adopted or issued under this subtitle.

subsection.text: A supplier of water may not:

paragraph.text: Fail to comply with § 9-410 of this subtitle;

Disseminate any false or misleading information in or about any notice required under § 9-410 of this subtitle or about any remedial action being undertaken to achieve compliance with State primary drinking water regulations;
Knowingly make any false statement, representation, or certification in any application, record, report, plan, or other document filed or permit adopted or issued under this subtitle;
Fail to comply with the rules and regulations adopted under § 9-407 of this subtitle; or
Fail to comply with any conditions for variances or exemptions authorized under § 9-409 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: A person may not:

paragraph.text: Fail to comply with any order issued by the Secretary under this subtitle; or
Falsify or knowingly render inaccurate any monitoring device or method required to be maintained under this subtitle or any rule, regulation, order, or permit adopted or issued under this subtitle.

subsection.text: A person may not tamper, attempt to tamper, or make a threat to tamper with a public water system.

paragraph.text: The Department may bring a civil action against any person who tampers, attempts to tamper, or makes a threat to tamper with a public water system.
The court may impose a civil penalty of not more than $50,000 for actual tampering, or not more than $20,000 for each attempt to tamper.

subsection.text: A person who willfully violates § 9–412(a)(4) or (5) of this subtitle is subject to a civil penalty of up to $5,000 for each day on which the violation exists.

A person who violates § 9–412(a)(1), (2), or (3) of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $5,000 for each day on which the violation occurs or failure to comply continues.

In an action brought in the appropriate court to enforce the order, a person who willfully violates or fails or refuses to comply with any order issued by the Secretary under this subtitle may be fined not more than $5,000 for each day on which the violation occurs or failure to comply continues.

paragraph.text: In addition to any other remedies available at law and after an opportunity for a hearing, which may be waived in writing by the person accused of a violation, the Department may impose a penalty for violation of any provision of this subtitle or any order, regulation, or plan adopted or issued under this subtitle.
The penalty imposed on a supplier of water serving a population of more than 10,000 under this subsection shall be:

subparagraph.text: Up to $1,000 per day for each violation, but not exceeding $25,000 total for each violation; and
Assessed with consideration given to:

sub-subparagraph.text: The willfulness of the violation, the extent to which the existence of the violation was known to but uncorrected by the violator, and the extent to which the violator exercised reasonable care;
Any actual harm to the environment or to human health, including injury to or impairment of the use of the waters of this State or the natural resources of the State;
The cost of cleanup and the cost of restoration of natural resources;
The nature and degree of injury to or interference with general welfare, health, and property;

The extent to which the location of the violation, including location near waters of this State or areas of human population, creates the potential for harm to the environment or to human health or safety;
The available technology and economic reasonableness of controlling, reducing, or eliminating the violation;
The degree of hazard posed by the particular pollutant or pollutants involved;
The extent to which the current violation is part of a recurrent pattern of the same or similar type of violation committed by the violator; and
Whether or not penalties were assessed or will be assessed under other provisions of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: The penalty imposed on a supplier of water serving a population of 3,301 to 10,000 under this subsection shall be:

subparagraph.text: Up to $500 per day for each violation, but not exceeding $12,500 total for each violation; and
Assessed with consideration given to the factors set forth in paragraph (2)(ii) of this subsection.

paragraph.text: The penalty imposed on a supplier of water serving a population of 501 to 3,300 under this subsection shall be:

subparagraph.text: Up to $250 per day for each violation, but not exceeding $6,250 total for each violation; and
Assessed with consideration given to the factors set forth in paragraph (2)(ii) of this subsection.

paragraph.text: The penalty imposed on a supplier of water serving a population of 500 or less under this subsection shall be:

subparagraph.text: Up to $100 per day for each violation, but not exceeding $5,000 total for each violation; and
Assessed with consideration given to the factors set forth in paragraph (2)(ii) of this subsection.

paragraph.text: Each day a violation occurs is a separate violation under this subsection.
Any penalty imposed under this subsection is payable to the State and collectible in any manner provided at law for the collection of penalties.
All penalties collected under this subtitle shall be paid into the Maryland Clean Water Fund created under § 9–320 of this title.

subsection.text: The Department may issue an order or notice if the Department has reasonable grounds to believe that a person to whom the order or notice is directed has violated:

paragraph.text: This subtitle;
Any rule or regulation adopted under this subtitle; or
Any order or permit issued under this subtitle.

subsection.text: An order or notice issued under this subtitle shall:

paragraph.text: Specify the provision that allegedly has been violated;
State the alleged facts that constitute the violation;
State the actions necessary to correct the violation and the time allowed for corrections; and
State the procedure for requesting a hearing to respond to the violation alleged in the order.

subsection.text: If the person served with an order does not request a hearing within 30 days, the order becomes a final order.
Any notice or order issued by the Department under this subtitle may be served on the person to whom it is directed:

paragraph.text: In accordance with § 1–204 of this article; or
By publication.

subsection.text: The Department shall give notice and hold hearings under this subtitle in accordance with the Administrative Procedure Act.

paragraph.text: Within 30 days after service of the order under this subtitle the person served may request in writing a hearing before the Department.

subparagraph.text: If a person served with an order under this subsection makes a timely request for a hearing, the Department shall give the person written notice of the date, time, and place of the hearing, at least 10 days before the hearing date.
The order becomes final when the Department renders its decision following the hearing.

subsection.text: The Department may make a verbatim record of the proceedings of any hearing held under this subtitle.

paragraph.text: In connection with any hearing under this subtitle, the Department may:

subparagraph.text: Subpoena any person or evidence; and
Order a witness to give evidence.

paragraph.text: A subpoenaed witness shall receive the same fees and mileage reimbursement as if the hearing were part of a civil action.
If a person fails to comply with a subpoena or order issued under this subsection, on petition of the Department, a circuit court, by order may:

subparagraph.text: Compel obedience to the Department’s order or subpoena; or
Compel testimony or the production of evidence.

paragraph.text: The court may punish as contempt any failure to obey its order issued under this section.

Any person aggrieved by a final decision of the Department in connection with an order or a permit issued under this subtitle may take judicial appeal in accordance with the Administrative Procedure Act.

subsection.text: The Department may bring an action for an injunction against any person who violates any provision of this subtitle or any rule, regulation, order, or permit adopted or issued by the Department under this subtitle.
In an action for an injunction under this section, any finding of the Department after a hearing is prima facie evidence of each fact the Department determines.

section.text: Each new community and nontransient noncommunity water supply system that commences operation after October 1, 1999 shall demonstrate to the Department that it has the technical, managerial, and financial capacity to operate the proposed water system in accordance with the drinking water regulations in effect, or likely to be in effect, on the date of the commencement of operations.

subsection.text: For the purposes of this Part II, a “water supply facility” includes a source, treatment, storage, or distribution facility.
There is a Water Supply Facilities Financial Assistance Program consisting of moneys made available under water supply loan authorizations and funds appropriated in the State budget.

The Board of Public Works, upon the recommendation of the Secretary, may award financial assistance to State and local governmental entities for the acquisition, construction, equipping, rehabilitation, design, and improvement of water supply facilities.

Grants and loans may be awarded to any State or local governmental entity responsible by law for the provision of water supply systems in order to finance eligible costs of those systems that are necessary to satisfy State drinking water standards and policies or to protect the public health and comfort.
State assistance under this Part II of this subtitle, may not exceed 87.5 percent of eligible costs for each project or part of a project.

In the case of a project to be operated by a State–owned institution or facility, State financial assistance shall equal the total cost of the project less the amount of any federal grant made therefor.

For financial assistance over $500,000 awarded under the Fund, the applicant shall demonstrate, to the satisfaction of the Department, that steps were taken to include small business enterprises, minority business enterprises, and women’s business enterprises by:

paragraph.text: Placing qualified small business enterprises, minority business enterprises, and women’s business enterprises on solicitation lists;
Assuring that small business enterprises, minority business enterprises, and women’s business enterprises are solicited whenever they are potential sources;

Dividing total requirements, when economically feasible, into small tasks or quantities to permit maximum participation of small business enterprises, minority business enterprises, and women’s business enterprises;
Establishing delivery schedules, where the requirement permits, that encourage participation by small business enterprises, minority business enterprises, and women’s business enterprises; and

Using the services and assistance of the Maryland Department of Transportation and the Governor’s Office of Minority Affairs in identifying and soliciting small business enterprises, minority business enterprises, and women’s business enterprises.

subsection.text: If the steps required under subsection (d) of this section are not demonstrated to the satisfaction of the Department, the Department may withhold financial assistance for the project.

paragraph.text: Before any loan is made, the applicant shall execute an agreement specifying the purpose, amount, and manner of repayment of the loan.
The agreement shall be signed on behalf of the State by the Department of the Environment and shall be approved by the Board of Public Works.

To the extent not inconsistent with this Part II of Subtitle 4, a grant, loan, or loan guarantee agreement shall contain those conditions that the Secretary requires by regulation and that the Board of Public Works requires on a specific application for financial assistance.

subsection.text: A State loan extended under this subtitle:

paragraph.text: May not exceed $500,000 principal amount for each project or part of a project in any calendar year except as provided in subsection (c) of this section;
May not exceed the eligible cost of the project less the total of federal and State grants and federal loans;
Shall bear at least the same rate of interest as the most recent State general obligation bond sale preceding the date of approval by the Board of Public Works; and
Shall be repaid within 30 years.

subsection.text: The aggregate principal amount of all loans for each project or part of a project in any calendar year may not exceed $500,000 unless the Board of Public Works determines that extraordinary circumstances exist.

With the approval of the Board of Public Works, the Secretary shall adopt regulations that establish application procedures and criteria for the award of financial assistance under this Part II of Subtitle 4. The criteria shall provide the basis for project priority rankings and shall include, as appropriate:

paragraph.text: The water quality for public health impacts caused by existing circumstances;
Previous efforts expended to correct any existing problem;
Financial capability of the applicant;
The problem prevention aspects of a proposed project;
Cost effectiveness of a proposed project;
Planning requirements;
Provisions for monitoring and review; and
Measures to assure accountability for all funds awarded under this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall establish project priority systems.

A loan guarantee of the principal of or interest on any commercial loan or obligation to finance the eligible cost of a project under this subtitle may only be made if the applicant certifies that it is unable to obtain on reasonable terms sufficient credit to finance its actual needs without the guarantee and if the Board of Public Works determines that there is a reasonable assurance of repayment of the loan obligation.
A loan guarantee may not exceed $500,000 for each project or part of a project in any calendar year unless the Board of Public Works determines that extraordinary circumstances exist.

section.text: The eligible cost of a project for State financial assistance under this subtitle may include the costs of reports, plans, specifications, legal and administrative services, equipment, construction, rehabilitation, or improvement, and may include land, easements, and rights-of-way.
To receive financial assistance from the Fund, the project must be included in the county water and sewer plan approved by the county governing body and the Maryland Department of the Environment.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Community sewerage system” means a publicly or privately owned sewerage system that serves at least 2 lots.
“Community water supply system” means a water supply system that serves at least 2 lots.

paragraph.text: “County plan” means a comprehensive plan for adequately providing throughout the county, including all towns, municipal corporations, and sanitary districts in the county, the following facilities and services by public or private ownership:

subparagraph.text: Water supply systems;
Sewerage systems;
Solid waste disposal systems;
Solid waste acceptance facilities; and
Systematic collection and disposal of solid waste, including litter.

paragraph.text: “County plan” includes a revised or amended county plan.

subsection.text: “Individual sewerage system” means a sewerage system that serves only 1 lot.
“Individual water supply system” means a water supply system that supplies water to only 1 lot.
“Litter” means any:

paragraph.text: Waste material;
Refuse;
Garbage;
Trash;
Debris;
Dead animal; or
Other discarded material.

subsection.text: “Lot” means a parcel of land, including a part of a subdivision, that:

paragraph.text: Is used or is intended to be used as a building site; and
Is not intended to be further subdivided.

subsection.text: “Multiuse sewerage system” means a sewerage system that:

paragraph.text: Serves only 1 lot;
Serves a number of individuals;
Has a treatment capacity of more than 5,000 gallons a day; and
Is not publicly owned or operated.

subsection.text: “Multiuse water supply system” means an individual water supply system that:

paragraph.text: Has the capacity to supply more than 5,000 gallons of water a day; and
Serves a number of individuals.
“Proposed county plan” means a county plan that:

subparagraph.text: Has been adopted by the county governing body; and
Has not been approved by the Department.

paragraph.text: “Proposed county plan” includes any proposed amendment or revision of the county plan.

subsection.text: “Sewage” means any human or animal excretion, street wash, domestic waste, or industrial waste.

paragraph.text: “Sewerage system” means:

subparagraph.text: The channels used or intended to be used to collect and dispose of sewage; and
Any structure and appurtenance used or intended to be used to collect or prepare sewage for discharge into the waters of this State.

paragraph.text: “Sewerage system” includes any sewer of any size.
“Sewerage system” does not include the plumbing system inside any building served by the sewerage system.

subsection.text: “Solid waste acceptance facility” means any sanitary landfill, incinerator, transfer station, or plant whose primary purpose is to dispose of, treat, or process solid waste.

paragraph.text: “Solid waste disposal system” means any publicly or privately owned system that:

subparagraph.text: Provides a scheduled or systematic collection of solid waste;
Transports the solid waste to a solid waste acceptance facility; and
Treats or otherwise disposes of the solid waste at the solid waste acceptance facility.

paragraph.text: “Solid waste disposal system” includes each solid waste acceptance facility that is used in connection with the solid waste disposal system.
“Subdivision” means any division of a tract or parcel of land into at least 2 lots, for the purpose of sale or building development.
“Subdivision” includes any change in street lines or lot lines.
Except as provided in paragraph (4) of this subsection, “subdivision” does not include any division of land into parcels of more than 3 acres, if the division:

subparagraph.text: Is for agricultural purposes; and
Does not involve any new street or easement of access.

paragraph.text: In Carroll County, “subdivision” does not include:

subparagraph.text: Any division of land into parcels of more than 3 acres, if the division:

sub-subparagraph.text: Is for agricultural purposes; and
Does not involve any new street or easement of access; or

subparagraph.text: A remainder parcel of land of 25 acres or more that exists as a result of the division of a large parcel into at least 2 smaller parcels, provided that any occupied dwelling on the remainder parcel is serviced by a properly functioning sewerage disposal system and potable water supply.

paragraph.text: “Water supply system” means a publicly or privately owned or operated:

subparagraph.text: Source and the surrounding area from which water is supplied for drinking or domestic purposes; and
Structure, channel, or appurtenance used or intended to be used to prepare water for use or to deliver water to a consumer.

paragraph.text: “Water supply system” does not include the plumbing system inside any building that is served by the water supply system.

subsection.text: Unless the operation of a water supply system would interfere with a cleanup or remediation action of the Department, this subtitle does not prohibit the installation or operation of a water supply system that is used only to supply water for purposes other than human or animal consumption.
If a county is exempt from the provisions of this subtitle, the county may not receive funds from the sanitary facilities fund.

Any rule or regulation adopted under this subtitle does not limit or supersede any other county, municipal, or State law, rule, or regulation that provides greater protection to the public health, safety, or welfare.
Each county shall have a county plan or a plan with adjoining counties that:

paragraph.text: Is approved by the Department;
Covers at least the 10-year period next following adoption by the county governing body; and
Deals with:

subparagraph.text: Water supply systems;
Sewerage systems;
Solid waste disposal systems;
Solid waste acceptance facilities; and
The systematic collection and disposal of solid waste, including litter.

subsection.text: Except as provided in § 9-515 of this subtitle, each county governing body shall review its county plan at least once every 3 years in accordance with a schedule set by the Department.
Each county governing body shall adopt and submit to the Department a revision or amendment to its county plan if:

paragraph.text: The governing body considers a revision or amendment necessary; or
The Department requires a revision or amendment.
Before a county governing body adopts any revision or amendment to its county plan or adopts a new county plan, the governing body shall:

subparagraph.text: Conduct a public hearing on the county plan, revision, or amendment that may be conducted jointly with other public hearings or meetings; and
Give the principal elected official of each municipal corporation that is affected notice of the county plan, revision, or amendment at least 14 days before the hearing.

Notice of the time and place of the public hearing, together with a summary of the plan, revision, or amendment, shall be published in at least 1 newspaper of general circulation in the county once each week for 2 successive weeks, with the first publication of notice appearing at least 14 days before the hearing.
Notice of the public hearing may be a part of the general notice listing all other items to be considered during the public hearing or meeting.

subsection.text: To the extent that the incorporation will promote the public health, safety, and welfare, each county plan shall incorporate all or part of the subsidiary plans of each town, municipal corporation, sanitary district, privately owned facility, or local, State, or federal agency that has existing or planned development in that county.
If the governing body of each county that is affected adopts a subsidiary plan for a multicounty area, the county may incorporate in its county plan all or part of the subsidiary plan.
In addition to the other requirements of this subtitle, each county plan shall:

paragraph.text: Provide for the orderly expansion and extension of the following systems in a manner consistent with all county and local comprehensive plans prepared under Title 1, Subtitle 4, Title 3, or Title 21 of the Land Use Article, Article 25A, § 5(X) of the Code, and Article 25B, § 13 of the Code:

subparagraph.text: Community water supply systems and multiuse water supply systems;
Community sewerage systems and multiuse sewerage systems; and
Solid waste disposal systems and solid waste acceptance facilities;

paragraph.text: Provide for the sizing and staging of facilities construction that is consistent with the county plan;
Show compliance with paragraphs (1) and (2) of this subsection by using graphic and tabular information;
Provide:

subparagraph.text: For sewage treatment facilities that are adequate to prevent the discharge of any inadequately treated sewage or other liquid waste into any waters; or
Otherwise for safe and sanitary treatment of sewage and other liquid waste;

paragraph.text: Provide for facilities that are adequate to treat, recover, or dispose of solid waste in a manner that is consistent with the laws of this State that relate to air pollution, water pollution, and land use;
Contain adequate information about:

subparagraph.text: The existing sewage treatment capacity in each drainage basin or sewage treatment plant service area in the county;
The present level of use of sewage treatment plants in each drainage basin; and
Projections for use of sewage treatment plant capacity based on:

sub-subparagraph.text: Outstanding building permits and subdivision plats if the county has subdivision authority; or
Zoning commitments if the county does not have subdivision authority;

paragraph.text: Taking into account all relevant planning, zoning, population, engineering, and economic information and all State, regional, municipal, and local plans, describe, with all practical precision, those parts of the county that reasonably may be expected to be served in the next 10 years by any:

subparagraph.text: Community water supply system;
Multiuse water supply system;
Community sewerage system;
Multiuse sewerage system;
Solid waste disposal system; and
Solid waste acceptance facility;

paragraph.text: Set procedures for identifying and acquiring, on a time schedule that conforms to the time requirement in paragraph (7) of this subsection, any rights–of–way or easements that are necessary for any:

subparagraph.text: Community water supply system;
Multiuse water supply system;
Community sewerage system;
Solid waste disposal system; or
Solid waste acceptance facility;

paragraph.text: Taking into account all relevant planning, zoning, population, engineering, and economic information and all State, regional, municipal, and local plans, describe, with all practical precision, any parts of the county in which it is not reasonably foreseeable to have service in the next 10 years by any:

subparagraph.text: Community water supply system;
Multiuse water supply system;
Community sewerage system;
Multiuse sewerage system;
Solid waste disposal system; and
Solid waste acceptance facility;

paragraph.text: Set a time schedule and a proposed method for financing the construction and operation of each planned:

subparagraph.text: Community water supply system;
Multiuse water supply system;
Community sewerage system;
Solid waste disposal system; and
Solid waste acceptance facility;

paragraph.text: Set forth the estimated cost of constructing and operating each planned:

subparagraph.text: Community water supply system;
Multiuse water supply system;
Community sewerage system;
Solid waste disposal system; and
Solid waste acceptance facility;

paragraph.text: Indicate:

subparagraph.text: Any source of supply from the waters of this State;
The approximate amount of water to be withdrawn from the waters of this State; and
The quantity and quality of waste to be discharged into the waters of this State;

paragraph.text: Describe, in accordance with the provisions of this subtitle, each area in the county where:

subparagraph.text: A community water supply system must be provided;
A multiuse water supply system may be installed and used;
An individual water supply system may be installed and used for an interim period until a planned community water supply system is available;
An individual water supply system may be installed and used indefinitely;
A community sewerage system must be provided;
A multiuse sewerage system may be installed and used;
Except as provided in § 9–517 of this subtitle, an individual sewerage system may be installed and used for an interim period until a planned community sewerage system is available;
An individual sewerage system may be installed and used indefinitely;
A community solid waste disposal system must be provided; or
A community solid waste acceptance facility must be provided for use by residents of the described area during an interim period until a planned community solid waste disposal system is available;

paragraph.text: Except as provided in § 9–515 of this subtitle, provide for amendment or revision of the county plan at least once every 2 years in accordance with a schedule adopted by the Department;
Designate an appropriate agency of the county to be responsible for creating a workable plan:

subparagraph.text: To keep the environment of the county free of solid waste, including litter; and
To prevent scenic pollution of both public and private property in the county;

paragraph.text: By July 1, 1987, treat each publicly owned community sewerage system as a separate entity for fiscal purposes within the local operating agency;
Document compliance with and report on actions taken and plans to enforce §§ 12–605 and 12–606 of the Business Occupations and Professions Article;
For a county with a population greater than 150,000 according to the latest Department of Planning projections, include a recycling plan by July 1, 2014 that:

subparagraph.text: Provides for a reduction through recycling of at least 35% of the county’s solid waste stream by weight or submits adequate justification, including economic and other specific factors, as to why the 35% reduction cannot be met;
Provides for recycling of the solid waste stream to the extent practical and economically feasible, but in no event may less than a 15% reduction be submitted; and
Requires full implementation of the recycling plan by December 31, 2015; and

paragraph.text: For a county with a population less than 150,000 according to the latest Department of Planning projections, include a recycling plan by July 1, 2014 that:

subparagraph.text: Provides for a reduction through recycling of at least 20% of the county’s solid waste stream or submit adequate justification, including economic and other specific factors, as to why the 20% reduction cannot be met;
Provides for recycling of the solid waste stream to the extent practical and economically feasible, but in no event may less than a 10% reduction be submitted; and
Requires full implementation of the recycling plan by December 31, 2015.

subsection.text: A plan created under subsection (a)(15) of this section may include the use of prisoners from the State correctional system or from county jails or detention centers.

The recycling reductions of 35% and 20% provided in subsection (a)(18) and (19) of this section are not intended to be the maximum percentage that a county can achieve. A county that can practically and economically achieve a higher rate of recycling is encouraged to submit a recycling plan for a higher percentage.

If a county with a population less than 150,000 increases to a population of above 150,000, the county shall have 2 years to revise the recycling plan to be consistent with the recycling goals under subsection (a)(18) of this section.

paragraph.text: The governing bodies of 2 or more counties may adopt a regional recycling plan to comply with subsection (a)(18) or (19) of this section.

A regional recycling plan which otherwise satisfies the requirements of this subtitle for each of the participating counties shall constitute the county recycling plan for each county which participates in the plan.
Except as provided in paragraphs (2) and (3) of this subsection, before a county governing body may adopt a county plan or a revision or amendment to the county plan:

subparagraph.text: The county governing body shall submit the county plan, revision, or amendment to each official planning agency that has jurisdiction in the county, including any comprehensive planning agency with areawide jurisdiction, for review and comment within a 30–day period for consistency with planning programs for the area; and

The county planning agency shall certify that the plan, revision, or amendment is consistent with the county comprehensive plan prepared under Title 1, Subtitle 4 or Title 3 of the Land Use Article, Article 25A, § 5(X) of the Code, or Article 25B, § 13 of the Code.

paragraph.text: In Montgomery County and Prince George’s County, the review and comments of the Maryland–National Capital Park and Planning Commission in accordance with § 9–516 of this subtitle constitute full compliance with the requirement for review by an official planning agency under this subsection.

subparagraph.text: This paragraph applies only in St. Mary’s County.

A new public sewerage system or an expansion of an existing public sewerage system, or a new water supply system or an expansion of an existing water supply system, may not be allowed in St. Mary’s County unless the adoption, revision, or amendment to the county plan containing the public sewerage system or water supply system:

sub-subparagraph.text: Is reviewed by the St. Mary’s County Planning Commission in conformity with the provisions of this paragraph; and
Is approved by the Board of County Commissioners or, subject to subparagraph (v) of this paragraph, the Commissioners’ designee.

The County Commissioners or the Commissioners’ designee may not approve the adoption, revision, or amendment of the county plan that contains a new public sewerage system or an expansion of an existing public sewerage system, or a new water supply system or an expansion of an existing water supply system, until the Planning Commission:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: Conducts a complete review of the county plan; and
Holds, or arranges to be held, at least one public hearing on the county plan.

sub-subparagraph.text: The Planning Commission may delegate the responsibility of holding a public hearing under this subparagraph to county staff as directed by the County Commissioners.

subparagraph.text: In its review and recommendation to the County Commissioners or the Commissioners’ designee, the St. Mary’s County Planning Commission shall consider and make specific findings of fact with respect to the following objectives and policies of the county plan that contains a new public sewerage system or an expansion of an existing public sewerage system, or a new water supply system or an expansion of an existing water supply system:

sub-subparagraph.text: Compatibility with the Comprehensive Land Use Plan;
Planning and zoning issues;
Population estimates;
Engineering;
Economics;
State, regional, and municipal plans; and
Comments received from other agencies in the county.

subparagraph.text: The County Commissioners may only appoint a designee under this subsection for purposes of considering amendments to the county plan containing a public sewerage system or water supply system in growth areas shown on an adopted Comprehensive Land Use Plan.

subsection.text: Each county governing body shall submit to the Department:

paragraph.text: Progress reports on the development of its county plan; and
A report of its review conducted at least every 2 years, including any revision or amendment of the county plan that has been adopted.

If the Secretary determines that a county governing body has failed to submit a timely and adequate report of its review of its county plan or any required revision or amendment of its county plan to the Department, the Secretary shall give the county governing body a written notice of:

subparagraph.text: The county’s failure to submit a report; or
Any specific inadequacy in the county’s plan.

paragraph.text: If within 90 days of this notice a county does not submit its report or an adequate revision or amendment of its plan to the Department, the Secretary:

subparagraph.text: May not issue any permit to install or alter a water supply system, sewerage system, or solid waste disposal system in that county under § 9–204 of this title;
Shall give the county notice of its right to administrative review by the Secretary under this subsection; and
Shall give the county notice of its right to appeal the Secretary’s decision to the Board of Review.

subsection.text: When a county governing body submits its proposed county plan or a proposed revision or amendment of its county plan to the Department, the Department may:

paragraph.text: Approve the proposal;
Disapprove the proposal;
If the part approved includes all of the required elements of a county plan, approve the proposal in part and disapprove it in part; or
Modify or take other appropriate action on the proposal.

subsection.text: Before the Department approves or disapproves, in whole or in part, a proposed county plan or a proposed revision or amendment of a county plan, the Department shall submit the proposal:

paragraph.text: To the Department of Natural Resources for advice on natural resources matters;
To the Department of Planning for advice on the consistency of the proposal with the local master plan and other appropriate matters; and
To the Department of Agriculture for advice on the impact of water and sewerage service and solid waste facilities on productive or potentially productive agricultural land.

Except as otherwise provided in this subsection, the Department shall approve, disapprove, or partially approve and partially disapprove each proposed county plan or proposed revision or amendment to a county plan within 90 days after the proposal is submitted to the Department.
For good cause and after notice to the county involved, the Department may extend the 90-day review period of paragraph (1) of this subsection for an additional 90 days.

subsection.text: If the Department does not disapprove, in whole or in part, a proposed county plan or a proposed revision or amendment of a county plan within the review period provided in subsection (c) of this section, the proposal is approved.

paragraph.text: Before the Department takes any action under subsection (a) of this section, a county may use its proposed county plan or proposed revision or amendment of its county plan at the county’s own risk, if the county governing body has adopted the proposed county plan, revision, or amendment.
After the county governing body adopts the proposed county plan, a person shall follow the provisions of that plan except to the extent that the Department modifies or disapproves that plan.

subsection.text: If the Department disapproves, in whole or in part, a proposed county plan or a proposed revision or amendment of a county plan, the Department shall give the county a written notice of disapproval that states the reasons for disapproval.

At any time up to 6 months after a county receives the notice of disapproval, the county governing body may ask the Secretary to reconsider the disapproval in accordance with the rules and regulations of the Department.

section.text: As provided in § 9-218 of this title, a county may finance in part the cost of preparing its county plan or any revision or amendment of its county plan.

subsection.text: In addition to the powers set forth elsewhere in this subtitle, the Department may:

paragraph.text: Conduct surveys and research to carry out the provisions of this subtitle; and
Specify the location for any sewage treatment facility discharge point that is included in any county plan.

subsection.text: In addition to the duties set forth elsewhere in this subtitle, the Department shall adopt rules and regulations:

paragraph.text: To carry out the provisions of this subtitle;
To control, limit, or prohibit the installation and use of:

subparagraph.text: Water supply systems; and
Sewerage systems;

paragraph.text: To require that, before installation of individual water supply systems or individual sewerage systems, consideration be given to:

subparagraph.text: Present and future population density;
Size of parcels;
Contour of the land;
Porosity and absorbency of the soil;
Ground water conditions;
Availability of water from unpolluted aquifers;
Type of construction of community water supply systems;
Type of construction of community sewerage systems;
Size of the proposed development; and
Any other pertinent factors;

paragraph.text: To require that, giving consideration to the factors in item (3) of this subsection, areas be served by community facilities if the Department finds them to be reasonably necessary:

subparagraph.text: By installation of the community water supply system, community sewerage system, or solid waste disposal system; and
By connection of all premises to or service to all premises by the community water supply system, community sewerage system, or solid waste disposal system;

paragraph.text: To require that community water supply systems, community sewerage systems, and solid waste disposal systems be constructed to allow the connection of those systems to a larger system, if that larger system becomes available;

To allow a person to install an individual water supply system or an individual sewerage system in any area where a community water supply system or a community sewerage system is not available or required to be installed in the area if:

subparagraph.text: The Department finds that the individual system is adequate and safe for use before a community system is scheduled to be available in the area; and
The individual system is constructed in the most economical and convenient way to permit connection to a community system in the area, and the person guarantees the connection to a community system:

sub-subparagraph.text: When the county governing body where the area is located sets a time; and
In accordance with this subtitle, any rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle, and any other State law or county requirement by:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: Posting a bond to secure actual construction and installation of the systems with satisfactory surety for the benefit of the county governing body; or
Making any other arrangement that the Department considers necessary and adequate to carry out the provisions of this subtitle;

paragraph.text: If a solid waste disposal system is not available or required to be installed in any area as provided in item (4) of this subsection, to allow a person to provide a solid waste acceptance facility in the area without a systematic collection and transportation system;

To require that, before issuance of a permit for construction of a community or multiuse sewerage system, a financial management plan sufficient to ensure the dependable and safe operation of the system has been adopted within the county plan and approved by the Department; and
To require that:

subparagraph.text: Before issuance of a permit for construction of a privately owned community water supply system that will serve 4 or more residential lots or 2 or more other lots, the applicant has proposed a financial management plan sufficient to ensure the dependable and safe operation of the system, and the plan has been approved by the Department; and
The applicant shall comply with the plan as approved by the Department.

section.text: Unless they conform to the county plan or revision or amendment of the county plan, the following systems and facilities may not be installed or extended:

paragraph.text: A water supply system;
A sewerage system;
A solid waste disposal system; and
A solid waste acceptance facility.

subsection.text: A county may remove a proposed solid waste acceptance facility from the county plan if:

paragraph.text: The owner of the proposed solid waste acceptance facility fails to apply to the Department for a new permit within 1 year of inclusion in the plan;
The owner of the proposed solid waste acceptance facility fails to apply to the Department for a renewal in accordance with § 10-226(b) of the State Government Article;
The Department denies a permit for the proposed solid waste acceptance facility in its final decision; or
The proposed solid waste acceptance facility is not constructed within 10 years after receiving a permit.

subsection.text: For the purposes of subsection (a)(1) of this section, a new permit does not include a permit application for expansion or major modification of an existing facility.

This section may not be construed to allow the county to remove a proposed solid waste acceptance facility if the solid waste acceptance facility is necessary to provide adequate capacity for the disposal of solid waste generated within the county in accordance with § 9-505 of this subtitle.
In this section, “building permit” means any permit that allows any building construction and is issued by any State or local authority.

paragraph.text: A State or local authority may not issue a building permit unless:

subparagraph.text: The water supply system, sewerage system, or solid waste acceptance facility is adequate to serve the proposed construction, taking into account all existing and approved developments in the service area;

Any water supply system, sewerage system, or solid waste acceptance facility described in the application will not overload any present facility for conveying, pumping, storing, or treating water, sewage, or solid waste;

Except for essential public services, after January 1, 1992, the county in which the proposed construction is located has an approved recycling plan under § 9–505 of this subtitle and § 9–1703 of this title; and

Except for essential public services, after January 1, 1994, the county in which the proposed construction is located has met the recycling reductions submitted in an approved recycling plan under § 9–505 of this subtitle and § 9–1703 of this title.

paragraph.text: A water supply system, sewerage system, or solid waste acceptance facility referenced in a subdivision plat shall conform to the applicable county plan.
If an allocation of water or wastewater is needed, and before a State or local authority may issue a building permit, the State shall:

subparagraph.text: Have an allocation of water and wastewater from the county whose facilities are affected by the proposed building construction; or
Show evidence of being able to provide an acceptable on–site sewage disposal system or well system until an allocation becomes available, or on a permanent basis if the State elects.

paragraph.text: The county shall timely review any State request for an allocation of water or wastewater, and report its findings to the State within 45 days from the date of such request.

The Department may grant a waiver from the sanctions of subsection (b)(1)(iii) and (iv) of this section if the county demonstrates to the satisfaction of the Secretary that it cannot achieve the recycling goal due to unforseen or emergency circumstances beyond the county’s control.

subparagraph.text: In the event that sanctions are imposed under this subsection, and the county submits an application for removing the sanctions, the Secretary shall promptly approve or deny the application.
In the event that the Secretary has neither approved nor denied the application within 30 days of its submission, the application shall be deemed approved and the sanctions shall be removed.

subsection.text: To apply for a building permit, an applicant shall:

paragraph.text: Submit an application to a State or local authority on the form that the authority requires; and
Provide any information that the authority reasonably requires to comply with subsection (b) of this section.

A State or local authority may not record or approve a subdivision plat unless any approved facility for conveying, pumping, storing, or treating water, sewage, or solid waste to serve the proposed development would be:

subparagraph.text: Completed in time to serve the proposed development; and
Adequate to serve the proposed development, once completed, without overloading any water supply system, sewerage system, or solid waste acceptance facility.

paragraph.text: Each water supply system, sewerage system, and solid waste acceptance facility in a subdivision shall:

subparagraph.text: Conform to the applicable county plan; and
Take into consideration all present and approved subdivision plats and building permits in the service area.

paragraph.text: If an allocation of water or wastewater is needed, and before a State or local authority may record or approve a subdivision plat, the State shall:

subparagraph.text: Have an allocation of water and wastewater from the county whose facilities are affected by the proposed development; or
Show evidence of being able to provide an acceptable on–site sewage disposal system or well system until an allocation becomes available, or on a permanent basis if the State elects.

paragraph.text: The county shall timely review any State request for an allocation of water or wastewater, and report its findings to the State within 45 days from the date of such request.

subsection.text: To apply for approval of a subdivision plat, an applicant shall:

paragraph.text: Submit an application to the appropriate State or local authority on the form that the authority requires; and
Provide any information that the authority reasonably requires to comply with subsection (d) of this section.

section.text: In Baltimore County or Carroll County, the county approving authority may grant an exception to the county plan that allows a person to install an individual water supply system or an individual sewerage system for an individual residence if the Secretary or a designee of the Secretary:

paragraph.text: Finds that this exception to the county plan is justified and necessary to alleviate extreme hardship; and
Approves the exception to the county plan.

If the Harford County governing body does not approve and incorporate in its county plan all or part of the subsidiary plans of each town, municipal corporation, and sanitary district in Harford County, the Harford County governing body shall send to the Department a written notice of:

subparagraph.text: This action; and
The specific reasons for this action.

paragraph.text: If the Harford County governing body or the governing body of a town, municipal corporation, or sanitary district in Harford County requests, the Department may:

subparagraph.text: Arbitrate the dispute; and
Decide whether to approve and incorporate all or part of this subsidiary plan in the Harford County plan.

subsection.text: In Harford County, except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, a building permit or a zoning permit may not be issued for a new subdivision in an area where a community water supply system or a community sewerage system is scheduled to be built within 10 years under the county plan, unless there is a county approved water supply system and a county approved sewerage system for the subdivision.

On their unanimous consent, the Harford County Health Officer, the Director of Planning and Zoning for Harford County, and the Director of Public Works for Harford County may recommend a waiver to the County Executive for his approval from the provisions of subsection (b) of this section if:

paragraph.text: Any lot created is a residential lot with a minimum size of 60,000 square feet;
A septic reserve area with a minimum size of 20,000 square feet is established and recorded on the final plan;
The subdivision site is shown in the comprehensive water and sewer plan for the 5-year to 10-year construction category;

The responsible agencies conclude that the failure to install an approved sewerage collection system at the subject time on the subject property is not detrimental to the overall county water and sewer system; and
The subdivision site and all the lots in the subdivision site meet other local guidelines to include applicable health, environmental, and physical characteristics including, but not limited to:

subparagraph.text: Minimum lot width at building line of 150 feet;
Maximum slope in septic reserve area of 15 percent;
Percolation rate between 2 and 20 minutes; and
Soils within septic reserve areas with slight to moderate limitations for homes with septic systems.

subsection.text: Before adopting any amendment or revision to the county water and sewer plan, the Harford County governing body shall determine whether a subdivision site or lot that has been granted a waiver under subsection (c) of this section shall be included in the amended or revised county plan.

In the planning for water supply systems, sewerage systems, and solid waste disposal systems in its county plan, the Harford County governing body shall consider estimates of population density for Harford County.
This section applies only in Montgomery County and Prince George’s County.
The county council of each county shall at least once every 3 years:

paragraph.text: Prepare a county plan;
Prepare, review, and revise, as the county council considers necessary, a separate statement of objectives and policies to be achieved and implemented by the county plan in the county; and
Consider the following in the statements of objectives and policies of the county plans:

subparagraph.text: Planning;
Zoning;
Population estimates;
Engineering;
Economics; and
State, regional, municipal, local, and area plans.

subsection.text: To achieve the objectives and policies set by the county council, the county executive of each county shall:

paragraph.text: Prepare a preliminary draft of the county plan;
From time to time review and, as the county executive or county council considers necessary, prepare amendments to the county plan including revisions to service area category designations; and
Submit to the county council for the county council’s consideration, revision, modification, comment, and approval:

subparagraph.text: The draft; and
Any revision or amendment to the draft.

subsection.text: The county executive of each county shall prepare and submit to the county council:

paragraph.text: A final draft of the county plan to conform to the action of the county council in approving the draft; and
A final revision or amendment to the county plan that takes into consideration any significant change in the intervening planning or development in the county.

subsection.text: At least 30 days before the date set for a public hearing under subsection (f) of this section, the county council of each county shall submit its final draft or the final draft of any revision or amendment of the county plan for recommendation to:

paragraph.text: The Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission; and
The Maryland-National Capital Park and Planning Commission.

subsection.text: The county council of each county shall:

paragraph.text: Hold a public hearing on:

subparagraph.text: Its final draft of the county plan; and
The final draft of any revision or amendment to the county plan; and

paragraph.text: Publish a notice of the time and place of the public hearing at least 10 days before the hearing in a newspaper of general circulation in the county.

After the public hearing in each county, the county council shall review, may amend as the county council considers necessary, and shall adopt the county plan or the revision or amendment to the county plan.
The adoption of the county plan or a revision or amendment of the county plan by the county council of the county is not final until 10 days after the action adopting it.
During the 10-day period provided by paragraph (2) of this subsection, the county executive may:

subparagraph.text: Review the county plan or any revision or amendment to the county plan; and
Recommend for the consideration of the county council whatever change to the county plan or any revision or amendment to the county plan that the county executive considers necessary or desirable.

subsection.text: After the time periods required for adoption under this section, the county council of each county shall submit to the Department, as required by § 9-506(b) and (c) of this subtitle:

paragraph.text: The county plan; or
Any revision or amendment to the county plan.

subsection.text: This section applies only in Montgomery County and Prince George’s County.

The Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission and the Maryland-National Capital Park and Planning Commission shall provide any information and assistance requested by the county council or the county executive for preparing, reviewing, adopting, revising, or amending a county plan.
The county council and county executive of each county, the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission, and the Maryland-National Capital Park and Planning Commission shall adopt procedures for:

paragraph.text: Requesting information or assistance under this section;
Responding to the request; and
Setting a reasonable timetable for response to a request.

subsection.text: The Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission shall provide any requested information about the comprehensive plan for water supply systems and sewerage systems in each county as to:

paragraph.text: Engineering;
Design;
Present and future capacities;
Available service projections;
Fiscal elements; and
Annual revisions of this information.

subsection.text: The Maryland-National Capital Park and Planning Commission shall provide any requested information to each county as to:

paragraph.text: Population;
Growth projections;
Planning factors; and
Other developmental standards.

section.text: In Montgomery County or Prince George’s County, the comprehensive plan for water supply systems and sewerage systems may allow the installation and use of an individual sewerage system for an interim period until the necessary sewerage transmission and treatment capacity in the area is available to provide adequate community sewerage service if:

paragraph.text: A community sewerage system otherwise is required in the area; but
Access to a community sewerage system is prohibited by an order of:

subparagraph.text: The Department;
Montgomery County;
Prince George’s County; or
The Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Commission” means the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission.
“Health officer” means the health officer for Prince George’s County.
“Issuing authority” means any one of the following authorities that is authorized to issue or approve a permit:

subparagraph.text: The Department;
The health officer;
The Montgomery County department designated by the Montgomery County government; or
The Prince George’s County Health Department.

paragraph.text: “Permit” means a permit issued or approved by the issuing authority for Montgomery County or Prince George’s County to install, connect to, or use an individual septic system.

subsection.text: This section applies only in Montgomery County and Prince George’s County.
In each county, a person shall have a permit from an issuing authority before the person may install, connect to, or use an individual septic system.
An applicant for a permit shall submit an application to the issuing authority on the form that the issuing authority requires.

paragraph.text: The health officer and the Montgomery County department designated by the Montgomery County government shall:

subparagraph.text: Submit each application for a permit to the Commission; and
Notify the Commission if there is more than one application for a permit in an area or subdivision of each county when:

sub-subparagraph.text: The original permit application is submitted to the Commission; or
This fact reasonably becomes known to the health officer.

paragraph.text: This subsection does not apply to an area of each county in which a community sewerage system is not planned within 10 years under the county’s comprehensive plan for sewerage systems.

Within 30 days after the Commission receives an application under subsection (e)(1) of this section, the Commission shall review the application and comment to the health officer, in writing, on the application.
If there is more than one application for a permit in an area or subdivision of each county, the Commission may group these applications together for purposes of review and comment.
In its review and comments under this subsection, the Commission shall include:

subparagraph.text: A determination of the location of the nearest collection line of a community sewerage system;
The capacity, feasibility, cost, and engineering conditions or requirements for an extension of this collection line; and
If available, an estimate of the time required for this extension.

paragraph.text: The issuing authority shall issue a permit to any applicant who meets the requirements of this subtitle.
If the Commission does not respond as required by subsection (f) of this section, and if the permit otherwise complies with this section, the local health officer may issue the permit.
The issuing authority shall include on each permit that the issuing authority issues a requirement that the holder of a permit shall notify, in writing, any buyer or lessee of the permitted property:

subparagraph.text: That the permitted property is served by an individual septic system;
Of the conditions, estimate of time, and other factors that concern the subsequent extension of a community sewerage system to the permitted property; and

If applicable, that the Commission did not review and comment on the application for a permit because the permitted property was in an area of the county in which at the time of the application a community sewerage system was not planned within 10 years under the county’s comprehensive plan for sewerage systems.

paragraph.text: The health officer and the Montgomery County department designated by the Montgomery County government:

subparagraph.text: Shall adopt rules and regulations to carry out the provisions of this subsection; and
May require the holder of a permit to record the information required by paragraph (1) of this subsection in the land records of the county in which the permitted property is located.

subsection.text: A State or local authority that violates any provisions of § 9-512(b) or (d) of this subtitle is liable for a civil penalty not exceeding $100 to be collected in a civil action brought by the Department in the circuit court for any county. Each day a violation continues is a separate violation under this section.
A civil penalty imposed under this section does not bar any other applicable relief or penalty.

paragraph.text: An applicant who violates § 9-510(b)(9) of this subtitle, or who violates any regulation adopted under § 9-510(b)(9) of this subtitle, is liable for a civil penalty not to exceed $500 per violation to be collected in a civil action filed by the Department in the circuit court for any county.
Each day a violation continues under this subsection constitutes a separate violation of this subsection.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Bond” means any bond, note, or other evidence of indebtedness or obligation that a district is authorized to issue under this subtitle.

paragraph.text: “Cost”, as applied to any project, includes the cost of and all expenses incident to the construction, acquisition, improvement, or placement in operation of a project, including the cost and expenses of:

subparagraph.text: The purchase price of a project;
The cost of acquiring all the capital stock of a corporation that owned a project;
Amounts paid to discharge obligations of the owner of a project, if paid to vest title to a project in the district;
Any interest in real or personal property acquired in connection with it;
Financial, technical, professional, engineering, and legal services;

Plans, specifications, surveys, estimates of costs and revenues, feasibility or practicability reports, machinery, equipment, administrative expenses, and other expenses that are necessary and incident to the financing authorized for the construction, acquisition, improvement, or placement in operation of a project; and
Financing the project, including finance charges and interest before, during, and for 1 year after completion of construction.

paragraph.text: “Cost”, as to any obligation or expense that is incurred before the bonds are issued, also includes the cost and expense of engineering services, estimates of costs and revenues, and any other technical or professional services that may be used in the construction, acquisition, or improvement of a project.
“District” means an entity that is created under this subtitle.
“District” includes a board, body, or commission that assumes the principal functions of a district that is created under this subtitle and later abolished.

subsection.text: “Governing body” means the body or board that is authorized to enact ordinances or resolutions for a county.
“Improvement” means any construction, repair, replacement, extension, or betterment of a project.
“Independent system” means a water system, sewerage system, or solid waste disposal system that:

paragraph.text: Is not operated by a sanitary commission or a municipality; and
