subsection.text: The Dorchester County Sanitary District, Inc., may:

paragraph.text: Construct, buy, own, hold, lease, repair, maintain, improve, and operate a shared facility; and
Contract with any person, any agency of the federal government or this State, or any municipality for services that relate to the facility.

subsection.text: The shared facility may be built only:

paragraph.text: Outside an incorporated area of Dorchester County; and

subparagraph.text: Outside a service area; or
If inside a service area, to serve territory that the Sanitary Commission determines is not feasible to serve with an existing project.

subsection.text: The shared facility may not serve more than 14 single family residences or their equivalent.
The owners of property in territory that may be served by a shared facility may file a written petition with the Sanitary Commission that requests the Sanitary Commission:

paragraph.text: To build a shared facility; and
To designate a shared facility area.

subsection.text: The petition shall include:

paragraph.text: Plans for the proposed shared facility that will enable the Sanitary Commission to determine the cost and feasibility of the proposed shared facility; and
A map of the proposed shared facility area.

subsection.text: The petitioners shall provide, at their own expense, the map and plans required by this section.
Within 90 days from the date the complete petition is filed, the Sanitary Commission shall decide on the petition.
In deciding on a petition, the Sanitary Commission may designate a shared facility area if the Sanitary Commission finds that:

paragraph.text: The proposed shared facility is necessary for the public health, safety, and welfare of the residents of Dorchester County who would be affected by the proposed shared facility; and
It is feasible:

subparagraph.text: To construct the proposed shared facility; and
To establish the proposed shared facility area.

paragraph.text: If the Sanitary Commission denies the petition, the petitioners, within 30 days after the denial, may appeal to the Dorchester County Commissioners.
The Dorchester County Commissioners:

subparagraph.text: Shall determine whether the proposed shared facility meets the applicable standards of this section; and
May affirm, modify, or reverse the decision of the Sanitary Commission.

subsection.text: When a petition is approved by the Sanitary Commission or the Dorchester County Commissioners, the Sanitary Commission shall:

paragraph.text: Adopt a resolution that:

subparagraph.text: Provides for construction of the shared facility; and
Designates the boundaries of the shared facility area; and

paragraph.text: File the resolution among the Dorchester County land records.

subsection.text: The Sanitary Commission shall propose and, with the approval of the Dorchester County Commissioners, given after a public hearing, shall adopt rules and regulations to carry out the provisions of this subtitle that relate to shared facilities.
These rules and regulations shall include provisions for:

paragraph.text: Classification of properties in the shared facilities area; and
Levy of benefit assessments in accordance with this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Dorchester County Commissioners may advance funds to the Dorchester County Sanitary District, Inc., to meet the organizational and preliminary costs of establishing and constructing the shared facility.
From the first revenues received from benefit assessments made for the shared facility, the Sanitary Commission shall repay advances made under this section.
In accordance with the rules and regulations that the Dorchester County Commissioners approve:

paragraph.text: The Sanitary Commission shall make benefit assessments on the property in a shared facility area in an amount that is enough to:

subparagraph.text: Pay the principal and interest on each bond issued and any other obligation incurred by the Sanitary Commission in constructing the shared facility; and
Pay any other costs incurred in building the shared facility; and

paragraph.text: The Sanitary Commission may establish reasonable charges on each parcel in the shared facility area.
The Sanitary Commission shall give to the owner of each parcel in the shared facility area written notice of:

subparagraph.text: The class and subclass of the parcel;
The benefit assessment for the parcel; and
The time and place of the hearing to which the owner is entitled under this section.

paragraph.text: The Sanitary Commission shall mail the notice to the owner at the last known address of the owner on the Dorchester County tax assessment records.

subsection.text: The Sanitary Commission shall give each property owner an opportunity for a hearing before the Sanitary Commission.
After the hearing, the Sanitary Commission may adjust the classification or benefit assessment as appropriate.

The Sanitary Commission shall make the levy of each benefit assessment the Sanitary Commission determines under this section so that the levy is effective for the July 1 that follows the first March 31 that occurs on or after the date:

paragraph.text: Construction is completed on the shared facility; or
The shared facility is acquired.

subsection.text: While unpaid, benefit assessments and other charges are a lien on the parcel for which made.
The lien granted by this subsection is subordinate only to State taxes and municipal taxes.

paragraph.text: As to each lien that arises against a parcel in the shared facility area, the Sanitary Commission shall keep a public record that:

subparagraph.text: Identifies the owners of the parcel;
Describes the parcel and gives any lot number of record that applies to the parcel; and
Shows the amount of the lien.

paragraph.text: The Sanitary Commission shall file the record of liens with the Clerk of the Circuit Court for Dorchester County, for filing among the land records for Dorchester County.
The record of liens shall be legal notice of all existing liens in the shared facility area.
To enforce the collection of unpaid benefit assessments or other charges that are at least 60 days overdue, the Sanitary Commission, at any time, may:

subparagraph.text: Sue any person who was an owner of record of the parcel at any time since the benefit assessment was last paid; or
File a bill in equity to enforce a lien through a decree of sale of property against any person who was an owner of record of the parcel at any time since the benefit assessment was last paid.

paragraph.text: When recorded, the lien shall be legal notice to any person who has any interest in a parcel.

subsection.text: Subject to the limitations and requirements of this subtitle, the sanitary commission and the member counties of the district may pledge the full faith and credit of the district and its members and issue bonds in the name of the district to pay the cost of a project in the amount estimated when the resolution authorizing the bond issue was adopted.
The issuance of bonds under this subtitle is not subject to any condition or limitation of law that is not in this subtitle.

section.text: A district may not issue for a service area any bonds that, when added to the outstanding and unpaid bonds already issued for that service area, would result in a total bond issuance that exceeds 25 percent of the total value of property in the service area, as assessed for county taxation.

subsection.text: Before a district issues any bonds, the sanitary commission shall:

paragraph.text: Adopt a resolution that proposes the issuance of the bonds; and
Submit the resolution to the governing body of each member county of the district.

subsection.text: If the governing body of each member county approves the resolution, the district may issue the bonds in accordance with this subtitle.
Before a district issues any bonds:

paragraph.text: The sanitary commission shall make the determinations required by this section; and
After the sanitary commission makes the determinations, the district shall issue the bonds in accordance with the determinations.

subsection.text: The sanitary commission:

paragraph.text: Shall determine the form of the bonds;
Shall determine the manner of execution of the bonds;
Shall determine the denominations of the bonds;
Shall determine the place, which may be any bank or trust company, where the principal and interest of the bonds will be paid;
Shall determine whether interest coupons will be attached to the bonds and, if so, the form of the coupons;
May determine whether the bonds will be issued in:

subparagraph.text: Coupon form;
Registered form; or
Coupon form and registered form;

paragraph.text: May determine whether coupon form bonds will be registered as to:

subparagraph.text: Principal; or
Principal and interest;

paragraph.text: May determine a method for reconverting into coupon form bonds any bonds that are registered as to principal and interest;
May determine whether the district will redeem bonds before maturity, and if so, shall specify:

subparagraph.text: The terms and conditions the sanitary commission will impose as to redemption before maturity; and
The method the sanitary commission will use in determining the prices the district will pay to redeem bonds before maturity;

paragraph.text: Shall determine any other condition, term, or provision as to the bonds that the sanitary commission is required to make under this subtitle; and
May determine any other condition, term, or provision as to the bonds that the sanitary commission is allowed to make under this subtitle.

section.text: Bonds issued under this subtitle shall:

paragraph.text: Be dated;
Bear interest at the rate or rates that the sanitary commission determines;
Bear the seal of the district;
Be signed for the district;
Bear maturity dates that:

subparagraph.text: Are determined by the sanitary commission; and
Are not more than 40 years from the date of issue; and

paragraph.text: Subject to the limitation on liability of each member county of a multiple county district under § 9-696 of this subtitle, be endorsed by each member county as follows: “The payment of interest when due and the principal at maturity is guaranteed by .......... (name of member county), Maryland”.

subsection.text: An officer of the district shall sign the bonds for the district.
Within 10 days after the sanitary commission submits the bonds to a member county for endorsement, the endorsement of the member county guaranteeing the bond shall be signed by:

paragraph.text: The clerk or secretary of the governing body of the member county; and

subparagraph.text: The chief executive officer of the member county; or
Another officer of the member county authorized by a resolution of the governing body of the member county to sign the endorsement.

subsection.text: The validity of a signature or facsimile of a signature made under this section is not affected by the fact that the individual whose signature is on the bond no longer holds the office that authorized the individual to sign the bond, even if the bond is delivered after that individual leaves the office.
In the manner that the sanitary commission determines to be in the best interest of the district and the member counties, a district may sell bonds issued under this subtitle:

paragraph.text: At public or private sale; and
At a price that meets the requirements of this section.

subsection.text: The district may not sell bonds at a price so low that the effective rate of interest is greater than the rate of interest that the sanitary commission has determined for the bonds.
The effective interest rate of the bonds shall be computed:

paragraph.text: Without regard to any premium that might be paid to redeem the bonds before maturity; and
Otherwise in accordance with standard tables of bond values.

section.text: Bonds issued under this subtitle are:

paragraph.text: Fully negotiable within the meaning of and for all the purposes of Title 8 of the Commercial Law Article; and
Exempt from all State, county, and city taxation.

subsection.text: Before the definitive bonds are available for delivery to bond holders, the district may issue:

paragraph.text: Interim receipts for payment for the bonds; or
Temporary bonds with or without coupons.

subsection.text: The interim receipts or temporary bonds may be exchanged for definitive bonds when the definitive bonds are available.

section.text: A sanitary commission may provide for the replacement of bonds that are mutilated, destroyed, or lost.

subsection.text: A district may use the proceeds from bonds issued under this subtitle only:

paragraph.text: To pay costs incurred for the projects for which the bonds were issued; or
In accordance with this section.

subsection.text: The district shall disburse the proceeds as the sanitary commission provided in its authorizing resolution.

paragraph.text: If the proceeds from bonds issued under this subtitle are insufficient to pay the costs incurred for the projects for which the bonds were issued, the district may issue additional bonds to make up the deficit.
Unless the sanitary commission provided otherwise in its authorizing resolution, bonds issued under this subsection:

subparagraph.text: Are deemed to be from the same series that originally was issued for the project; and
Shall be repaid without preference to or priority for the bonds that already were issued for the project.

subsection.text: If the proceeds from bonds issued under this subtitle exceed the costs incurred for the projects for which the bonds were issued and if the authorizing resolution so requires, the district shall use the surplus to retire bonds of the same series.
If the proceeds from bonds issued under this subtitle exceed the costs incurred for the projects for which the bonds were issued and if the authorizing resolution does not otherwise require:

paragraph.text: The district shall use the surplus to pay the next payment of principal on the bonds;

The sanitary commission shall adopt a resolution that authorizes the use of the surplus to pay for other projects that are in the same service areas as the projects for which the bonds were issued and then use the surplus in accordance with the resolution; or
The district shall use the surplus to cancel bonds of the same series by buying the bonds on the open market at a price that:

subparagraph.text: Does not include a premium of more than 5 percent of the par value; and
The sanitary commission determines to be in the best interests of the district and the member counties served by the projects for which the bonds having excess proceeds were issued.

section.text: In accordance with the provisions of this subtitle that generally govern the issuance of bonds, any district may issue refunding bonds to refund, pay, or discharge the principal or interest of:

paragraph.text: Any other bond issued under this subtitle; and
Any other indebtedness incurred to acquire or construct a project.

subsection.text: To retire bonds issued under this subtitle, each year, the sanitary commission, as to each series of outstanding bonds, shall determine or estimate:

paragraph.text: The principal and interest that will be due on that series through the end of the next full taxable year for property taxes in the member counties; and

The amount of benefit assessments that will be collected on projects for which that series was issued and the amount of any other funds that will be available to that series through the end of the next full taxable year for property taxes in the member counties.

subsection.text: At least 60 days before the taxable year for property taxes, the governing body of each member county shall certify to the sanitary commission the total valuation of all taxable property in each service area in that member county.

If, after making the estimate of necessary funds under this section, the sanitary commission determines that there will be insufficient benefit assessments or other funds available to pay the principal and interest referred to in subsection (a) of this section, the sanitary commission shall:

paragraph.text: Compute the deficiency as to each service area in the district; and

On the basis of the tax base information supplied by the member county under this section, certify to each member county the tax rate that will be required in each service area in that member county to meet the deficiency.

The governing body of each member county shall impose on all real property in each service area in that member county, and may impose on personal property in the service area, a property tax that is sufficient to pay a deficiency specified in subsection (c) of this section.

If, after the imposition made under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the deficiency is still unpaid, the governing body of each member county shall impose on all real and personal property in that member county a property tax that is sufficient to pay the remaining deficiency.
In Allegany County:

subparagraph.text: The governing body of the county shall levy a property tax on all real property within a sanitary district that is abutted or served by a sanitary sewer or water line; and
The Sanitary Commission shall certify to the governing body of the county a complete list of all real property within a district that is abutted or served by the sanitary sewer or water line.

subsection.text: If property tax collections made under this section in a fiscal year are insufficient to meet a deficiency under subsection (c) of this section, the governing body of each member county, in accordance with subsection (d)(1) of this section, shall impose, for the next fiscal year, property taxes sufficient to make up the insufficient collections.
All property taxes levied under this section:

paragraph.text: Have the status of county taxes; and
Shall be collected as county taxes.

subsection.text: At least every 60 days, the tax collecting authorities for each member county shall pay to the district the property taxes collected under this section.
The district shall pay, when due, the principal and interest on bonds:

paragraph.text: First, from all other funds available, under this subtitle, for that purpose; and
Then, if necessary, from tax revenues received under this section.
The district shall deposit the excess tax revenues in a bank in a member county where the service area from which the tax revenues were received is located.
The deposit shall be to the joint credit of the member county and the district.

section.text: From the proceeds of the sale of bonds under this subtitle, the district may pay, on those bonds, interest that does not exceed 1 year’s interest.

If bonds issued under this subtitle are guaranteed by more than 1 member county, the liability of each member county on its guarantee is in proportion to the assessable base of that part of the property of the county that is in the service areas for which the bonds were issued as that proportion relates to the assessable base of all property in all the service areas for which the bonds were issued.

subsection.text: Each person who has a duty to act in the payment of principal and interest on bonds issued under this subtitle shall perform promptly the act that is required.

paragraph.text: Before a series of bonds is issued under this subtitle, the governing body of each member county that will be affected by the series shall advance to the district not more than $25,000.
From the first proceeds available from the sale of the bonds, the district shall repay the advances made by the member counties.

subsection.text: Unless the approval is required under this subtitle, a district is not required to obtain the approval of any entity before it issues bonds.
The provisions of Article 31, §§ 9 through 11 of the Code do not apply to bonds issued under this subtitle.
Before a person may dig in or do any other construction on any way in a service area, the person shall obtain from the sanitary commission approval of the digging or construction.
To obtain approval, the person shall file with the sanitary commission a plan for the digging or construction that shows the depth and location of each:

paragraph.text: Conduit;
Main;
Pipe;
Pole; and
Other structure.

subsection.text: If approval of the plans has been obtained from the sanitary commission, before a person may do any digging or construction different from the approved plans, the person shall:

paragraph.text: Submit a new plan that shows the changes in the information required for the original plan; and
Obtain approval from the sanitary commission to do the digging or construction according to the new plan.

subsection.text: If any obstruction has been constructed in, on, or under a way in violation of this section and if the sanitary commission is required to move that obstruction to build or operate a project:

paragraph.text: The district may move the obstruction and charge the cost of moving the obstruction to:

subparagraph.text: The person who constructed or installed the obstruction; or
Any successor in interest to that person;

paragraph.text: The owner of the obstruction is not entitled to compensation under this subtitle for moving the obstruction; and
The district is not liable for damage done to the obstruction.

subsection.text: Before beginning work on the plumbing system on any property in a service area, a person shall:

paragraph.text: Obtain from the district a permit to do the plumbing work;
Pay to the district the permit fee that the sanitary commission requires; and
Allow the sanitary commission to inspect the plumbing work.

subsection.text: Before connecting the plumbing system of any property to a water pipe or sewer pipe operated by the district, a person shall:

paragraph.text: Obtain from the district a permit to make the connection; and
Comply with any additional conditions that the sanitary commission requires.

subsection.text: A person may not:

paragraph.text: Interfere with an inspection made under authority of § 9-606 of this subtitle;
Violate § 9-661 of this subtitle by failing:

subparagraph.text: To maintain at least 1 sanitary toilet and wash basin as a part of any plumbing system that is used on any parcel after it is connected to a connector; or
To disconnect and close each cesspool, sink, drain, and privy on a parcel after it is connected to a connector;

paragraph.text: Violate a water conservation order;
Construct or operate an independent system in violation of § 9-664 of this subtitle;
Fail to move an obstruction in violation of § 9-669 of this subtitle;
Fail, in violation of § 9-697(a) of this subtitle, to perform any act required of that person in paying principal or interest on bonds issued under this subtitle;
Use, for any purpose other than repaying in accordance with this subtitle, any funds that, under this subtitle, are required to be used to pay principal and interest on bonds;
Violate § 9-698 of this subtitle;
Operate, or make any connection to a fire hydrant, unless the act is done:

subparagraph.text: With written permission of the sanitary commission; or
By a fire department in discharge of its duties; or

paragraph.text: Deface, damage, or obstruct a fire hydrant.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $100 or imprisonment in jail not exceeding 30 days or both.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Municipal authority” means:

paragraph.text: The mayor and council of a municipality;
The town commissioners of a municipality; or
Any other governing body of a municipality.

subsection.text: “System” means:

paragraph.text: A water supply system;
A sewerage system;
A drainage system; or
A refuse disposal system.

subsection.text: Except for Subtitles 2, 5, and 9 of this title, any act or part of an act that is inconsistent with the provisions of Part II of this subtitle is repealed to the extent of the inconsistency.
The provisions of Part II of this subtitle do not affect any power or duty of:

paragraph.text: The Secretary;
The Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission;
The Anne Arundel County Sanitary Commission;
The Baltimore County Metropolitan District; or
Baltimore City.

section.text: A municipal authority may:

paragraph.text: Construct a system in a municipality;
Extend or alter an existing system;
Maintain and operate a system constructed, extended, altered, or acquired under this subtitle;

Make a contract or an agreement with another municipal authority, or with any sanitary commission, sanitary district, county, State, or federal authority about the construction, alteration, maintenance, or operation of a system;

In order to exercise any power set out in this subtitle with regard to any part of any system, acquire by purchase, in fee or as an easement, from any owner, or if the owner objects, by condemnation, any property inside or outside the municipality, including:

subparagraph.text: Land;
Structures;
Buildings;
Watercourses;
Water rights; and
Any privately owned system;

paragraph.text: Do any work necessary to carry out any activity under item (1), (2), or (3) of this section, including:

subparagraph.text: Preliminary work;
Setting compensation for and appointing a workforce; and
Entering a highway to work on a system, water main, sewer, drain, or related equipment, if the municipal authority:

sub-subparagraph.text: Has a permit to do the work;
Leaves the highway in a condition at least as good as that existing before entry; and
Pays all costs for cleanup and repair;

paragraph.text: Establish street lines and grades, or grant approval to any person to establish street lines and grades, for the proper construction, establishment, or extension of any water, sewerage, or drainage system under the control of the municipal authority; and
Withhold water, sewerage, or drainage service from any property that abuts on any street for which a person establishes lines and grades without the approval of the municipal authority.

subsection.text: Whenever a municipal authority acquires any property by condemnation under this subtitle, the proceedings shall be in accordance with this section and Title 12 of the Real Property Article.

Notwithstanding any appeal or other proceeding by a defendant, the municipal authority may enter and take possession of the condemned property at any time at least 10 days after the return and recordation of the judgment if the municipal authority pays to the clerk of court:

paragraph.text: The amount of the award;
All costs to date; and
All taxes to date.

subsection.text: In addition to the requirements of § 9-706 of this subtitle, whenever a municipal authority acquires a privately owned system under this subtitle, the provisions of this section apply.
If a municipal authority takes possession of a privately owned system, the municipal authority:

paragraph.text: May extend, alter, maintain, or operate the acquired system together with the municipal system;
Shall subject the property served by the acquired system to the same benefit assessment as property served by the municipal system;
May compensate any owner of property served by the acquired system for any payment by the property owner toward the construction of the acquired system; and

Shall subject an owner or the agent of the owner of property served by the acquired system to the same rules, regulations, and penalties as any owner or the agent of the owner of property served by the municipal system.

subsection.text: If a municipal authority considers any part of the privately owned system unfit for incorporation into the municipal system, the municipal authority may disregard the unfit part of the privately owned system and extend the municipal system to serve the property served by the unfit part of the privately owned system.
The provisions of Part II of this subtitle that apply to a system constructed by the municipal authority apply to the system acquired or extended by the municipal authority under this section.
A municipal authority shall:

paragraph.text: Construct and provide at its own expense for any water main or sanitary sewer constructed or established under Part II of this subtitle, a water service pipe or sewer connection that extends from the water main or sewer to the property line of each lot that abuts on a street or right-of-way in which the water main or sewer is laid; and
When the municipal authority declares that a water main or sewer is complete and ready for use, notify each owner of abutting property that the owner shall:

subparagraph.text: Connect all spigots or hydrants, toilets, and waste drains with the water main or sewer, within a reasonable time as determined by the municipal authority; and
Install adequate spigots or hydrants, toilets and waste drains if:

sub-subparagraph.text: There are no fixtures or drains; or
The municipal authority believes that the existing fixtures or drains are improper or inadequate.

subsection.text: To prevent any use of or any injury to the public health, each owner of property that is connected with a sewer shall abandon, close, and leave, in the manner that the municipal authority directs, any:

paragraph.text: Cesspool;
Drain;
Privy; or
Well that is determined by the municipal authority to be polluted or a menace to health.
After notice from the municipal authority, if a property owner in Frederick County fails to comply with the provisions of this section, the municipal authority may:

subparagraph.text: Have any necessary connections made;
Cause any cesspool, drains, or privy to be closed and abandoned; and
Charge the property owner with the cost of the connection or closing or both.

paragraph.text: For purposes of this subsection, the costs:

subparagraph.text: Are a lien against the affected property until paid; and
May be collected in the same manner as county or municipal taxes.

subsection.text: If any structure in, over, or under a public street, road, or alley in any county or municipality obstructs any work on a system, the municipal authority shall:

paragraph.text: Give the person in control of the structure notice of the obstruction; and
Order the person in control of the structure to take any action necessary, within a time specified in the order, to enable the work to continue.

subsection.text: After the time specified in the order for abating the violation, a person who is served with an order under this section may not violate that order.

If any pipe or conduit laid under a public highway by a person in accordance with the terms of any permit issued or any plan approved under § 9-710 of this subtitle obstructs construction of any water main, sewer, or drain, the municipal authority shall remove or readjust the obstructing structure.
The municipality shall pay the cost of any necessary changes made under this section.
A person shall hold a permit issued by the municipal authority before the person may lay any pipe or conduit under any public highway in a municipality.
The municipal authority shall issue a permit to lay any pipe or conduit under a public highway in the municipality if:

paragraph.text: The person intending to lay the pipe or conduit submits to the municipal authority an adequate plan for the installation, including the size, type, and location of any pipe or conduit to be laid; and
The municipal authority approves the plan.

subsection.text: A person shall obtain the approval of the municipal authority for any proposed deviation from the approved plan before the person may deviate from the plan.
If a person lays a new pipe or conduit without a permit, or not in accordance with the approved plan or an approved deviation from the plan, the municipal authority shall:

paragraph.text: Give the person reasonable notice of the violation; and
Order the person to remove or readjust any pipe or conduit within a time specified in the order.

subsection.text: After the time specified in the order for abating the violation, a person who is served with an order under this section may not violate that order.
A municipal authority may issue bonds when and in the amounts needed to provide funds for all or part of a system’s:

paragraph.text: Design;
Construction;
Extension;
Alteration;
Purchase; or
Condemnation.

subsection.text: The bonds issued under this subtitle:

paragraph.text: May be issued without previous legislative authority;
May be outstanding in addition to the total indebtedness otherwise permitted by law;
May be of any type and denomination determined by the municipal authority, so long as no bonds mature later than 50 years from the date of issue;
Shall be exempt forever from any State, county, or municipal taxation; and
Shall be a lien on all property within the municipality that issues them.
Before issuing bonds under Part II of this subtitle, a municipal authority shall submit to a referendum of the voters of the municipality the question of whether to issue the bonds.
The referendum shall be held at:

subparagraph.text: Any regular municipal election; or
A special municipal election, provided that the voters are given at least 20 days’ notice of the election.

paragraph.text: The referendum ballot shall include the words “for ... bonds” and “against ... bonds”.
If a majority of the votes cast are “for ... bonds”, the municipal authority may issue the bonds.
If a majority of the votes cast are “against ... bonds”, the municipal authority:

subparagraph.text: May not issue the bonds; but
May submit the question at any later regular or special municipal election as provided under this section, until a majority of the votes cast is “for ... bonds”.

subsection.text: While any bonds issued under Part II of this subtitle are outstanding, the municipal authority annually shall levy a tax against all of the assessable property served within the municipality to pay the principal and interest on the bonds.
The tax shall be:

paragraph.text: Sufficient to pay:

subparagraph.text: When due, the principal and interest on the bonds; or

The part of the principal or interest on the bonds that is not paid for by the levy of the annual front-foot assessment under § 9-713 of this subtitle or by the service charges collected under § 9-714 of this subtitle; and

paragraph.text: Treated the same as any other municipal tax in every respect, including as to:

subparagraph.text: Priority rights;
Interest;
Penalties; and
Manner of determination, levy, and collection.

paragraph.text: Each person involved in the levy or collection of the taxes shall perform the duties promptly and properly.
A person may not use any funds collected under this section for any purpose other than the payment of principal and interest on the bonds.

subsection.text: To pay all or any part of the principal or interest on or to retire any outstanding bonds issued under Part II of this subtitle, the municipal authority may levy an annual front–foot assessment against any property that abuts on any street, road, alley, or right–of–way in which a water pipe, sewer, or drain is laid, or from which refuse is collected.
To set front–foot assessment rates, the municipal authority may:

paragraph.text: Classify any property according to its use;
Determine a fair and reasonable frontage length for:

subparagraph.text: Any corner lot fronting on more than one street;
Any irregular shaped lot fronting on more than one street;
Any shallow lot fronting on more than one street;
Any agricultural property; or
Any small acreage; and

paragraph.text: Change the classifications or the front–foot assessment rates from year to year, but the rate for all property assessed in the municipality for any year shall be uniform within each classification.
The municipal authority shall notify each owner of assessed property in writing as to:

subparagraph.text: The classification of the property;
The amount of the assessment; and
The time and place for a hearing on the classification of the property and the benefit charges assessed against the property.

paragraph.text: The classification of the property and the benefit charges assessed against the property shall be final, subject only to modification at the hearing.
The benefit charges are in default if not paid within 60 days after the date of levy.
The levy bears interest at the rate of 1 percent a month for each month after the time the benefit charges are in default.
The front–foot assessment charges are a first lien on the assessed property, subject only to prior State and county charges.
The municipal authority may enforce the lien by filing in an appropriate court a complaint for a judgment against the property owner and for execution on the judgment.

subsection.text: The municipal authority may provide terms for the extinguishment by property owners of annual front–foot benefit charges, if the extinguishment arrangement provides for the necessary payments on the outstanding bonds.
A municipal authority may set, collect, and, if necessary, modify service rates to provide funds:

paragraph.text: To pay all or part of the principal and interest on bonds issued under Part II of this subtitle; and
To pay for the cost of maintenance, repair, and operation, including overhead expenses and depreciation allowance, of systems constructed under Part II of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The service rates shall be:

paragraph.text: Chargeable against all property served by any system under the ownership of the municipal authority; and
Collectible against the owner of the property served, in the same manner as other debts are collectible at law.

subsection.text: The municipal authority may set:

paragraph.text: The time for payment; and
The penalties for nonpayment.

subsection.text: To carry out any official duty under Part II of this subtitle, a representative of a municipal authority, at any reasonable time, may enter on any private property or into any building that is within the jurisdiction of the municipality.
An owner, tenant, or agent of the owner or tenant may not:

paragraph.text: Refuse to grant entry to any representative of the municipal authority who asks to enter on private property or into a building under this section; or
Interfere with the carrying out of any official duty of any representative of any municipal authority under this section.

section.text: A municipal authority may adopt rules and regulations:

paragraph.text: To provide for the maintenance and operation of any system under its control; and

To govern the installation and alteration of all water supply, plumbing, and drainage arrangements on private property, including requirements for obtaining a permit and paying a reasonable charge before doing any work on any water supply, plumbing, or drainage system.

section.text: A person who violates any provision of or fails to perform any duty imposed by Part II of this subtitle, or who violates any provision of or fails to perform any duty imposed by a rule, regulation, order, or permit adopted or issued under Part II of this subtitle, is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $100 or imprisonment not exceeding 30 days in the county jail, or both.
In Part III of this subtitle, “political subdivision”:

paragraph.text: Means any public body of this State that owns or operates any water or sewerage system, including:

subparagraph.text: A county;
A commission;
A district; or
A municipal corporation; and

paragraph.text: Does not include the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission.

subsection.text: The powers granted to political subdivisions by Part III of this subtitle are supplementary to any other powers of the political subdivisions.
This section does not:

paragraph.text: Invalidate any procedures initiated or completed by any political subdivision before June 1, 1972; or
Limit or modify any provision of any general or local law effective before June 1, 1972.

subsection.text: To provide funds for the payment of principal and interest on indebtedness that is incurred to finance any water or sewerage system, a political subdivision may:

paragraph.text: Establish a reasonable charge that is not less than the actual cost, payable to the political subdivision, for connection with a water or sewerage system; and

Set an annual assessment, payable to the political subdivision, on all property, improved or unimproved, that abuts on any street, road, lane, alley, or right-of-way in which there is a water main or sewer.

subsection.text: Except for special provisions that apply only in certain political subdivisions, the provisions of §§ 9-655 through 9-658 of this title govern the imposition of assessments under this section.

Subject to any charter provisions of a chartered county or municipal corporation, any political subdivision may establish reasonable rates for water service, and reasonable charges for sewer upkeep and sewer service to provide funds for:

paragraph.text: Maintenance, repair, and operation of any water or sewerage system; and
Payment of all or part of the principal and interest on any indebtedness that is incurred to finance any water or sewerage system.

subsection.text: The rates and charges are chargeable against all property that is connected to any water or sewer pipe that the political subdivision owns or supervises.
Subject to any necessary modification and to the provisions of this section, the rates and charges shall be uniform throughout each water or sewerage district.
The rates for water service shall:

paragraph.text: Be based on estimates of the amount of water used by the types of users specified in the rates; and
Consist of:

subparagraph.text: A minimum charge based on the size of the meter on the water connection leading to the property; and
A charge for water used, based on the amount of water passing through the meter during the period between the last 2 readings.

paragraph.text: At its own expense, the political subdivision shall place a meter on each water connection.

If the political subdivision does not have meters available to install in all property that is connected to the system in a locality, the political subdivision shall charge a flat rate to all property in which meters are not installed.

The political subdivision shall send bills for water service to the property, the property owner, or the property owner’s designee for each property served on a monthly, quarterly, or semiannual basis.
The bills are payable at the office of the political subdivision on receipt.
If any bill remains unpaid after 30 days from the date the bill is sent, the political subdivision shall:

subparagraph.text: Notify the owner of the property served, in writing, that the bill is in arrears and that water service will be discontinued;
Leave the notice on the owner’s property or mail the notice to the last known address of the owner; and

Discontinue water service to the property until the owner pays the bill and a reconnection charge reasonably related to the cost of reconnection, as established by ordinance of the governing body of the county or municipal corporation in which the water service is provided.

paragraph.text: If any bill remains unpaid after 60 days from the date of sending the notice:

subparagraph.text: The bill and the penalty imposed under paragraph (3)(iii) of this subsection shall be collectible from the property owner in the same manner and subject to the same interest as taxes are collectible in the county in which the water or sewerage system lies; and
The water service charges and all penalties shall be a first lien on the property.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only to property subject to a condominium regime established under Title 11 of the Real Property Article.

Notwithstanding any other law, if the political subdivision directly bills the governing body of a condominium or a person designated by the governing body of a condominium for water or sewer usage charges for all or a portion of the units in a condominium property, and a charge is in default for at least 60 days, the political subdivision shall post notice conspicuously at or near the entry to the common area of the condominium.
The political subdivision may enter onto the common area of a condominium property at a reasonable time to post the notice required under this subsection.

section.text: The charge for the upkeep on sewers shall be:

paragraph.text: Collected annually; and
A first lien on any property connected to any sewer pipe the political subdivision owns or supervises.

subsection.text: The political subdivision shall:

paragraph.text: Select a reasonable basis for imposing the sewer service charge; and
Collect the sewer service charge once, twice, or four times a year.

subsection.text: If any bill for sewer service remains unpaid after 60 days from the date the bill was sent:

paragraph.text: The bill shall be collectible from the owner of the property served in the same manner and subject to the same interest as taxes are collectible in the county in which the water or sewerage system lies; and
The sewer service charges shall be a first lien on the property.

subsection.text: If a bill for sewerage service is unpaid for 45 days after being sent, a political subdivision may disconnect water service to the property.
Before disconnecting water service under this section, the political subdivision shall provide notice:

paragraph.text: By mail sent to the last known address of the owner of the property; or
By posting the notice on the premises of the property served.
This subsection applies if a political subdivision:

subparagraph.text: Provides sewerage service to a property; but
Does not provide water service to the property and water service is provided to the property by another political subdivision or by a private water company.

paragraph.text: If a political subdivision advises another political subdivision or a private water company that a bill for sewerage service is unpaid for 45 days after being sent, subject to the notice provisions under subsection (b) of this section, the political subdivision or private water company informed of the unpaid bill may disconnect water service to the property.

Before reconnecting water service, a political subdivision may require full payment of the sewerage bill plus a reconnection charge reasonably related to the cost of reconnection, as established by regulation of the political subdivision.
A private water company may apply a reasonable reconnection charge, in accordance with the ratemaking requirements of Title 4 of the Public Utilities Article, when it reconnects water service.

subsection.text: This subsection does not preclude the use of any other procedure available to a political subdivision to collect unpaid sewerage charges.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only to property subject to a condominium regime established under Title 11 of the Real Property Article.

Notwithstanding any other law, if the political subdivision directly bills the governing body of a condominium or a person designated by the governing body of a condominium for water or sewer usage charges for all or a portion of the units in a condominium property, and a charge is in default for at least 60 days, the political subdivision or private water company informed of the unpaid bill shall post notice conspicuously at or near the entry to the common area of the condominium.
The political subdivision may enter onto the common area of a condominium property at a reasonable time to post the notice required under this subsection.

section.text: Before setting or modifying a rate, charge, or assessment under this section, for any water or sewerage system it constructs or acquires, the political subdivision shall:

paragraph.text: Give prompt notice of the proposed rate, charge, or assessment in at least 1 newspaper of general circulation in the area of the water or sewerage system; and
Conduct a public hearing on the necessity or advisability of the proposed rates, charges, or assessments.

subsection.text: In this subtitle, the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Development” means:

paragraph.text: Planning;
Acquisition by gift, purchase, lease, or eminent domain;
Construction;
Reconstruction;
Improvement; or
Extension.

subsection.text: “Governing body” includes any body or board that is in charge of the finances of a municipality.
“Municipality” means any municipal corporation of this State.
“Resolution” means any resolution or ordinance adopted by any governing body.
“Revenue” includes, unless the context requires otherwise:

paragraph.text: The revenue currently derived from any existing sewerage facility that is being developed; and
The revenue to be derived from any subsequent developments to the sewerage facility.

subsection.text: “Sewerage facility” means all or any part of any plant, property, works, system, or facility that is used or useful in connection with the collection, treatment, or disposal of sewage, waste, garbage, or stormwater.
The powers granted by this subtitle are:

paragraph.text: Supplemental to the powers granted by any general, special, or local law; and
Not restricted by any debt or tax rate limitation in any general law, local law, or municipal charter.

subsection.text: Any municipality may engage in the development of any sewerage facility under this subtitle regardless of any general, special, or local law that:

paragraph.text: Provides for the development of similar facilities;
Requires approval by the voters of any municipality for the development of the sewerage facility; or
Contains any other requirements, restrictions, limitations, or provisions regarding the development of the sewerage facility.

subsection.text: Any municipality may issue bonds under this subtitle to finance the development of any sewerage facility regardless of:

paragraph.text: Any general, special, or local law that provides for the issuance of bonds for similar purposes;
Any general, special, or local law that requires approval by the voters of the municipality for the issuance of bonds;
An unfavorable vote by the voters of the municipality if the Department or a court of competent jurisdiction has ordered the development of the sanitary facility; or
Any other requirements, restrictions, limitations, or other provisions contained in any general, special, or local law.

subsection.text: If any provision of this subtitle is inconsistent with any general, special, or local law, the provision of this subtitle controls.

section.text: It is the policy of this State that each municipality that engages in the development of any sewerage facility under this subtitle shall manage the sewerage facility as economically and efficiently as possible:

paragraph.text: To promote the health and welfare of the inhabitants of the municipality and of this State by preventing, reducing, or eliminating the pollution of the waters of this State; and
To provide the services of the sewerage facility to consumers at the lowest possible cost.

subsection.text: In addition to the powers granted to the municipality by any general, special, or local law, and independent of any control by the Public Service Commission of Maryland, a municipality may:

paragraph.text: Subject to subsection (c)(1) of this section, engage in the development of a sewerage facility:

subparagraph.text: Wholly inside the corporate boundary line;
Wholly outside the corporate boundary line; or
Partly inside and partly outside the corporate boundary line;

paragraph.text: Acquire by gift, purchase, lease, or eminent domain, in connection with the development of a sewerage facility:

subparagraph.text: Land;
Land rights; or
Water rights;

paragraph.text: Accept from any federal agency loans or grants for the development of sewerage facilities and make agreements with that agency about the loans or grants;
Operate and maintain any sewerage facility for the use and benefit of:

subparagraph.text: The municipality;
The residents of the municipality; or
Residences or places of business that are outside the corporate boundary line of the municipality, but are:

sub-subparagraph.text: Inside this State; and
Inside a radius of 10 miles from the corporate boundary line of the municipality;

paragraph.text: Set rates and collect fees, benefit assessments, and other charges for the services, facilities, and commodities provided by each sewerage facility;
Designate an agency of the municipality:

subparagraph.text: To provide the sewerage facility services, facilities, and commodities; and
To collect the fees, benefit assessments, and other charges; and

paragraph.text: Make and perform any contract with any industrial establishment:

subparagraph.text: For the municipality to provide, operate, and maintain sewerage facilities to reduce or eliminate water pollution caused by any discharge of industrial waste by the industrial establishment; and

For the industrial establishment periodically to pay to the municipality amounts determined by the governing body of the municipality to be at least sufficient to compensate the municipality for the cost of providing, operating, and maintaining the sewerage facility or the part of the sewerage facility that serves the industrial establishment.

subsection.text: Through their governing bodies, any 2 or more municipalities may:

paragraph.text: Make and perform contracts and agreements with each other about sewerage facility:

subparagraph.text: Development;
Financing; and
Operation; and

paragraph.text: Agree or contract with each other:

subparagraph.text: To provide for a board, commission, or other body to supervise, operate, and generally manage the sewerage facility;
To specify the powers and duties of the board, commission, or body; and
To set the compensation of the members of the board, commission, or body.

paragraph.text: A municipality may not construct a sewerage facility wholly or partly inside the corporate boundary line of another municipality except with the consent of the governing body of the other municipality.
A municipality may not operate a sewerage facility:

subparagraph.text: For gain or profit; or
Primarily as a source of revenue to the municipality.

subsection.text: By resolution, the governing body of any municipality may authorize the issuance of bonds under this subtitle to finance, wholly or partly, the cost of the development of any sewerage facility. In the determination of the cost, the governing body may include:

paragraph.text: Actual and estimated costs of issuing the bonds;
Engineering expenses;
Inspection expenses;
Fiscal expenses;
Legal expenses; and
Interest estimated to accrue, during construction and for 6 months after construction, on money borrowed or expected to be borrowed under this subtitle.

subsection.text: The resolution:

paragraph.text: May be adopted at the meeting at which the resolution is introduced;
May be adopted by a majority of all members of the governing body who are in office when the resolution is introduced; and
Is effective immediately on adoption.

subsection.text: The authorizing resolution may provide that the bonds shall contain a recital that they are issued under this subtitle.
The authorizing resolution shall state that the interest on bonds issued under this subtitle shall be payable twice a year.
The authorizing resolution or any subsequent resolution may provide that the bonds issued under this subtitle:

paragraph.text: Be in 1 or more series;
Bear a certain date or dates;
Be executed in a certain manner;
Contain certain terms, covenants, and conditions;
Be in coupon or registered form, or both;
May mature at a certain time or times, but not later than 40 years from their respective dates of issuance;
Be payable in a certain medium of payment;
Be payable at a certain place or places;
Carry certain registration privileges; and
Be subject to certain terms of redemption.

subsection.text: The provisions of this subtitle and any resolution that authorizes the issuance of bonds under this subtitle are a contract between the municipality and the bondholder.
The authorizing resolution may contain covenants as to:

paragraph.text: The disposition of the proceeds of sale of the bonds;
The disposition of the revenue of the sewerage facility for which the bonds are issued, including:

subparagraph.text: The pledging to the punctual payment of the bonds issued under this subtitle and of the interest on those bonds as they become due an amount sufficient to pay the bonds and interest on an equal or priority basis from all or part of the revenue of all or part of the existing or planned sewerage facility; and
The creation and maintenance of reasonable reserves, from all or part of the revenue, for the payment of the bonds issued under this subtitle and of the interest on those bonds;

paragraph.text: The issuance of additional bonds payable from the revenue of the sewerage facility;

The transfer from the general funds of the municipality to the account of the sewerage facility of an amount equal to the cost of providing the municipality or any of its departments, boards, or agencies with the services, facilities, and commodities of the sewerage facility;
The insurance to be carried on the sewerage facility and the disposition of insurance money;
The operation and maintenance of the sewerage facility;
The books of account of the sewerage facility and the inspection and audit of the books; and
The terms and conditions on which the bondholders or any trustee for the bondholders may petition the circuit court for the appointment of a receiver for the sewerage facility.
On petition of the bondholders or a trustee for the bondholders, the circuit court may appoint for a sewerage facility a receiver who may:

subparagraph.text: Enter and take possession of the sewerage facility;
Operate and maintain the sewerage facility;
Set sewerage facility rates, fees, or charges; and
Collect, receive, and apply all revenue of the sewerage facility.

paragraph.text: By mandamus or other appropriate suit, action, or proceeding in any court of competent jurisdiction, any bondholder may enforce:

subparagraph.text: The duties under this subtitle of the municipality and its governing body and officers; and
The resolutions adopted under this subtitle.

paragraph.text: Except for bonds issued under this subtitle and sold to the United States or to any agency, instrumentality, or corporation of the federal government, any bond issued under this subtitle shall be sold:

subparagraph.text: At public sale;
After advertisement; and
At a price that is not less than par.

paragraph.text: Any bond issued under this subtitle may be sold, at a price that is not less than par, to the United States or to any agency, instrumentality, or corporation of the federal government at private sale.

subsection.text: The governing body of the municipality that issues the bonds may:

paragraph.text: Issue, to any purchaser of a bond, an interim receipt or certificate pending preparation of the definitive bond; and
Determine the form and provisions of the interim receipt or certificate.

subsection.text: Any bond and interim receipt or certificate issued under this subtitle is:

paragraph.text: Fully negotiable within the meaning of and for all the purposes of Title 8 of the Commercial Law Article; and
Forever exempt from State, county, or municipal taxation.
Any bond issued under this subtitle that bears the signatures of the officers in office on the date the bond is signed is a valid and binding obligation notwithstanding that:

subparagraph.text: At the time of delivery of or payment for the bond, any or all of the signers are no longer officers of the municipality; or
Any proceeding that relates to the development of the sewerage facility for which the bond is issued is invalid or irregular.

paragraph.text: A signature may be by facsimile as provided in § 2-303 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

subsection.text: A recital in the bond that the bond is issued under this subtitle is conclusive evidence of:

paragraph.text: The validity of the bond; and
The regularity of the issuance of the bond.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, the general credit and taxing powers of any municipality are pledged to the payment of any bonds issued by the municipality under this subtitle.
A holder of a bond issued under this subtitle may not compel the exercise of the taxing power of the municipality to pay the bond or the interest on the bond, if:

paragraph.text: A covenant in the authorizing resolution so limits the liability of the municipality; and
The bond recites in substance that:

subparagraph.text: The bond and the interest on the bond are payable from the revenue pledged to the payment of the bond; and
The bond does not constitute a debt of the municipality within the meaning of any constitutional or statutory limitation.

subsection.text: In accordance with the provisions of this subtitle and the authorizing resolution, all bonds of the same issue:

paragraph.text: Subject to the prior and superior rights of outstanding bonds, claims, or obligations, may have a prior and paramount lien on the revenue of the sewerage facility, over and ahead of:

subparagraph.text: All bonds of any subsequent issue payable from the revenue;
Any claims of any nature subsequently arising against the revenue; and
Any obligations of any nature subsequently incurred against the revenue;

paragraph.text: May be equally and ratably secured by a lien on the revenue, without priority because of:

subparagraph.text: Number;
Date of bonds;
Date of sale;
Date of execution; or
Date of delivery; and

paragraph.text: In the manner and to the extent set forth in the authorizing resolution, including a provision for the subordination of fewer than all the bonds, may be subordinated and junior in standing, with respect to the payment of principal and interest and the security for the payment, to any other bonds that the authorizing resolution designates.

subsection.text: To assure that each sewerage facility always remains self-supporting, the governing body of a municipality that issues bonds under this subtitle shall set, collect, and whenever necessary revise reasonable rates, fees, benefit assessments, or charges for the services, facilities, and commodities of the sewerage facility.
The rates, fees, benefit assessments, or charges shall be set so as to produce revenue and reserves that are at least sufficient:

paragraph.text: To pay, when due, all bonds and the interest on the bonds, for the payment of which the revenue is pledged, charged, or otherwise encumbered; and
To provide for all expenses of operation and maintenance of the sewerage facility.

subsection.text: Any municipality that issues bonds under this subtitle for the development of any sewerage facility may appropriate or expend the revenue from the sewerage facility for:

paragraph.text: Paying, when due, all bonds and the interest on the bonds, for the payment of which the revenue is pledged, charged, or otherwise encumbered;
Providing for all expenses of operation and maintenance of the sewerage facility;
Paying and discharging the principal and interest on any notes, bonds, or other obligations:

subparagraph.text: Not issued under this subtitle, but for payment of which the revenue of the sewerage facility is pledged, charged, or encumbered; or
Issued to finance the development of the sewerage facility, but which do not constitute a lien, charge, or encumbrance on the revenue of the sewerage facility; and

paragraph.text: Providing a reserve for improvements to the sewerage facility.

subsection.text: Any municipality may transfer the revenue of any sewerage facility to the general funds of the municipality only after the municipality has made adequate provision for the purposes set out in subsection (a) of this section.
Any municipality may issue refunding bonds to refund, pay, or discharge the principal and interest on all or any part of the outstanding bonds:

paragraph.text: Issued by the municipality to finance the development of all or part of the sewerage facility; and
In arrears or about to become due.

subsection.text: The provisions of this subtitle that concern authorization and issuance of bonds apply to authorization and issuance of refunding bonds.

section.text: This subtitle may be cited as “The Sewerage Facilities Bond Act”.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Authority” means:

paragraph.text: A body politic and corporate that is created under this subtitle; or
If that body is abolished, the unit that:

subparagraph.text: Succeeds to the principal functions of that body; or
Is given by law the powers under this subtitle of the former body.

subsection.text: “Board” means the governing body of an authority.

paragraph.text: “Bond” means any note, bond, or other evidence of indebtedness or obligation that an authority may issue under § 9-932 of this subtitle.
“Bond” includes refunding bonds and joint cost and refunding bonds.
“Cost” means:

subparagraph.text: The purchase price of a project; or
Any expense necessary or incident to financing, acquiring, improving, or constructing a project, or to placing a project in operation.

paragraph.text: “Cost” includes:

subparagraph.text: Any obligation or expense that an authority incurs, before the authority issues a bond under this subtitle, to acquire, improve, or construct a project, including an obligation or expense for:

sub-subparagraph.text: An engineering study;
An estimate of cost;
An estimate of revenue; or
Any other technical or professional service; and

subparagraph.text: The cost of a project, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: Acquiring all of the stock of a corporation that owns the project;
Discharging the obligations of the corporation to vest title to all or part of the project in the authority;
Acquiring any real property, right, easement, franchise, permit, machinery, or equipment;
Any improvement;
Any finance charge;
Any interest charge before, during, or for 1 year after completion of construction of the project;

Any engineering or legal service, plan, specification, survey, estimate of cost, estimate of revenue, or other item necessary to determine the feasibility or practicability of acquiring, improving, or constructing the project; and
Any administrative expense.

subsection.text: “Federal agency” means:

paragraph.text: The United States government; or
Any agency of the United States government.

subsection.text: “Governing body” means the unit of a political subdivision that is authorized by law to enact laws for the political subdivision.
“Improvement” means the construction, repair, replacement, or betterment of, or additions to, a project:

paragraph.text: To place or maintain the project in proper condition for safe, efficient, and economic operation; or
To meet requirements for service in areas that:

subparagraph.text: May be served by the authority; and
Are not currently being served.

subsection.text: “Law” includes any enactment, order, resolution, or ordinance of a political subdivision.
“Political subdivision” means any county, municipal corporation under Article XI-E of the Maryland Constitution, sanitary district, or other political subdivision of this State.

“Project” means all or part of any water system or sewerage system, or any combination of all or parts of water systems or sewerage systems, that is owned, constructed, or operated by an authority under this subtitle.
“Sewage” means water-carried waste that is created in and carried away or to be carried away from any private or public building.

paragraph.text: “Sewerage system” means:

subparagraph.text: Any plant, system, facility, or property that can:

sub-subparagraph.text: Carry sewage away;
Collect sewage;
Dispose of sewage;
Neutralize sewage; or
Prepare sewage for discharge; and

subparagraph.text: Any integral part of the plant, system, facility, or property.

paragraph.text: “Sewerage system” includes the following parts of a sewerage system:

subparagraph.text: An appurtenance.
A conduit.
A disposal field.
A drainage ditch.
Any equipment.
A force main.
An intercepting sewer.
A lagoon.
A lateral sewer.
An outfall sewer.
A pipeline.
A pumping station.
A sewage treatment plant.
A sewer pipe.
A surface water intercepting ditch.
A trunk sewer.

paragraph.text: “Sewerage system” includes any related property, property right, or franchise.
“Water system” means:

subparagraph.text: Any plant, system, facility, or property that can supply or distribute water; and
Any integral part of the plant, system, facility, or property.

paragraph.text: “Water system” includes the following parts of a water system:

subparagraph.text: An appurtenance.
A dam.
Any equipment.
A filtration plant.
An intake.
A lateral.
A pumping station.
A purification plant.
A reservoir.
A standpipe.
A valve.
A water distribution system.
A water hydrant.
A water main.
A water meter.
A water source.
A water supply system.
A well.

paragraph.text: “Water system” includes any related property, property right, or franchise.

subsection.text: To accomplish the purposes of this subtitle, the provisions of this subtitle:

paragraph.text: Are full and complete authority without regard to the provisions of any other law; and
Shall be liberally construed.

subsection.text: However, this subtitle does not restrict the control that the Department of the Environment and the Department of Natural Resources may exercise over an authority.
This subtitle:

paragraph.text: Provides an additional and alternative method to accomplish the purposes of this subtitle;
Is supplemental and additional to powers contained in other laws; and
Does not derogate any existing power.

section.text: This subtitle does not apply to:

paragraph.text: Montgomery County; or
Prince George’s County.

section.text: An authority:

paragraph.text: Is an instrumentality that exercises public and essential government functions;
Provides for the public health and welfare; and
May acquire, hold, construct, extend, repair, improve, operate, or lease as a lessor or lessee 1 or more projects that are wholly or partly within 1 or more of the member political subdivisions.

section.text: By law, the governing bodies of 1 or more political subdivisions may create an authority as provided in this subtitle.

subsection.text: Each incorporating political subdivision shall include in the law that creates an authority the articles of incorporation for the authority.
The articles of incorporation shall include:

paragraph.text: An appropriate name for the authority, which includes the word “authority”;
A statement that the authority is formed under this subtitle;
The name of each incorporating political subdivision;
The name, address, and term of office for each member of the 1st board of directors of the authority;
If the governing body of any incorporating political subdivision determines that its members are the board of directors of the authority, a statement to this effect; and
The purpose of the authority.

subsection.text: The officers of each incorporating political subdivision shall sign, acknowledge, and file the articles of incorporation for record with the State Department of Assessments and Taxation.

paragraph.text: The State Department of Assessments and Taxation shall:

subparagraph.text: Receive the articles of incorporation;
Mark the date and time of receipt to the articles; and
Issue a certificate of approval for any articles that comply with this subtitle.

paragraph.text: When the State Department of Assessments and Taxation issues a certificate of approval, the authority:

subparagraph.text: Begins to exist as a public body politic and corporate;
Is conclusively considered to be lawfully and properly created;
May exercise its powers under this subtitle; and
Has the right to exist as a corporation for a term of 50 years.

paragraph.text: In this section, “articles of amendment” means a document that proposes or adopts an amendment to the articles of incorporation of an authority.
“Articles of amendment” includes a document that restates the articles of incorporation.

subsection.text: An authority may amend its articles of incorporation in accordance with this section:

paragraph.text: To adopt a new name; or
To change, enlarge, or diminish its powers, duties, and purposes.
To amend its articles of incorporation, the board of directors of an authority shall adopt a resolution that proposes the amendments.
If the articles of incorporation are to be replaced, the resolution shall contain the language of the new articles of incorporation.
If any provision in the articles of incorporation is to be added, deleted, or amended, the resolution shall contain the language of the entire amended provision.
The resolution shall direct submission of the amendment to the governing body of each member political subdivision.
After the board of directors submits the amendment to the governing body of each member political subdivision, the governing body shall adopt or reject the amendment by law.

subsection.text: Articles of amendment under this section shall include:

paragraph.text: The name and location of the principal office of the authority;
The complete amendment; and
A statement that the amendment:

subparagraph.text: Was proposed by the board of directors of the authority; and
Was adopted by the governing body of each member political subdivision.

subsection.text: If the governing body of each member political subdivision adopts the amendment:

paragraph.text: Two authorized officers of the authority shall:

subparagraph.text: Sign and acknowledge articles of amendment under the seal of the authority; and
Verify under oath the matters and facts set forth in the articles of amendment; and

paragraph.text: The authority shall file the articles of amendment for record with the State Department of Assessments and Taxation.
The State Department of Assessments and Taxation shall:

subparagraph.text: Receive the articles of amendment;
Mark the date and time of receipt to the articles of amendment; and
Issue a certificate of approval for any articles of amendment that comply with this subtitle.

paragraph.text: When the State Department of Assessments and Taxation issues a certificate of approval, the articles of amendment:

subparagraph.text: Are in full force and effect; and
Are conclusively deemed to be lawfully and properly adopted.

subsection.text: When an authority is organized and elects its initial officers, the secretary of the authority shall file for record with the State Department of Assessments and Taxation:

paragraph.text: The name and address of each officer of the authority; and
The location of the principal office of the authority.

subsection.text: Within 10 days after any change in location of the principal office of the authority, the secretary of the authority shall file notice of the new location with the State Department of Assessments and Taxation.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in this section, if an authority has 2 or more members, any of the member political subdivisions may withdraw from the authority.
Any political subdivision may join the authority.

subsection.text: After an authority that has 2 or more member political subdivisions incurs an obligation, the member political subdivisions may not withdraw from the authority.

paragraph.text: By law, the governing body of a political subdivision shall show its intention to withdraw from or join an existing authority.

If, by resolution, the board of directors of an authority consents to the withdrawal of a political subdivision from the authority, the following persons shall sign and acknowledge articles of withdrawal:

subparagraph.text: The authorized officers of the withdrawing political subdivision; and
The authorized officers of the authority.

paragraph.text: If, by resolution, the board of directors of an authority consents to the addition of a political subdivision as a member of the authority, the following persons shall sign and acknowledge articles of joinder:

subparagraph.text: The authorized officers of the joining political subdivision;
The authorized officers of the authority; and
After they are authorized by law of the governing bodies of their respective political subdivisions, the authorized officers of the political subdivisions that are then members of the authority.

subsection.text: Articles of joinder under this section shall include, for the joining political subdivision, all of the information required under § 9-907(b) of this subtitle, including the name, address, and term of office of the 1st member of the board of directors of the authority from the joining political subdivision.
The officers of the authority shall file articles of withdrawal or articles of joinder under this section for record with the State Department of Assessments and Taxation.

paragraph.text: The State Department of Assessments and Taxation shall:

subparagraph.text: Receive the articles of withdrawal or articles of joinder;
Mark the date and time of receipt to the articles; and
Issue a certificate of approval for any articles that comply with this subtitle.

paragraph.text: When the State Department of Assessments and Taxation issues a certificate of approval, the articles of withdrawal or articles of joinder:

subparagraph.text: Are in full force and effect; and
Are conclusively considered to be lawfully and properly adopted.

subsection.text: An authority may terminate its existence after the authority:

paragraph.text: Pays or provides for payment of the principal of and interest on each bond that the authority issued;
Settles any other claim against the authority; and
Has the approval by law of the governing body of each member political subdivision.

subsection.text: To terminate its existence, an authority shall:

paragraph.text: Comply with the provisions of this section; and
File articles of dissolution for record with the State Department of Assessments and Taxation.

subsection.text: The articles of dissolution shall include:

paragraph.text: A statement that requests the termination of the existence of the authority;
A statement that the authority has:

subparagraph.text: Paid or provided for payment of the principal of and interest on each bond that the authority issued; and
Settled each other claim against the authority; and

paragraph.text: The signatures of the authorized officers of the authority.
If the articles of dissolution comply with this subtitle, the State Department of Assessments and Taxation shall:

subparagraph.text: Note the termination of existence of the authority on the records of the Department; and
Issue a certificate of approval to the board of directors of the authority.

paragraph.text: On approval of the articles of dissolution by the State Department of Assessments and Taxation, the existence of the authority ends.

subsection.text: This section applies to any authority that is incorporated or continued by only 1 political subdivision.
At the election of the governing body of the political subdivision, the board of directors of the authority consists of:

paragraph.text: The members of the governing body of the political subdivision; or
Five citizens of the political subdivision who are appointed by the governing body of the political subdivision.
The term of a director who is also a member of the governing body of the political subdivision is the same as the term of office for the member on the governing body of the political subdivision.
