The term of a citizen director:

subparagraph.text: Begins on the date of appointment; and

Is 5 years, except that the respective terms of the directors serving on the initial board are 1 year, 2 years, 3 years, 4 years, and 5 years from the January 1 after the incorporation of the authority.

paragraph.text: The terms of citizen directors are staggered as required by the terms provided for the 1st directors in paragraph (2)(ii) of this subsection.
At the end of a term:

subparagraph.text: A citizen director continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies; or
A director who is a member of the governing body of the political subdivision ceases to be a director.

paragraph.text: A citizen director who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

At a meeting held at least 1 month before the end of a term of a citizen director, the governing body of the political subdivision that is represented by the citizen director shall designate a successor, who shall be deemed to be appointed at the end of the term.

subsection.text: If a political subdivision joins the authority, the governing body of the joining political subdivision immediately shall appoint 1 director for a term that is the same as the terms of the other directors.
This section applies to an authority that has two or more member political subdivisions.
Except as provided in subsection (g) of this section, the number of directors of the authority is the greater of:

paragraph.text: Five; or
The number of member political subdivisions.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (g) of this section, the articles of incorporation for the authority shall provide for:

paragraph.text: The appointment of directors;
The staggering of their terms; and
Where the number of member political subdivisions is less than five, the apportioning of the directors between or among the member political subdivisions.
The term of a director may not be more than 5 years.
If a vacancy occurs during the term of a director, the governing body of the political subdivision that is represented by the director shall fill the vacancy.

subsection.text: If a political subdivision joins the authority, the governing body of the joining political subdivision immediately shall appoint one director for a term that is the same as the terms of the other directors.
If a political subdivision withdraws from the authority, any director who was appointed to represent the withdrawing political subdivision immediately ceases to be a director.
In Harford County:

paragraph.text: The number of directors of the authority is the greater of:

subparagraph.text: Seven; or
The number of member political subdivisions.

paragraph.text: The articles of incorporation for the authority shall provide for the apportioning of the directors between or among the member subdivisions if the number of political subdivisions is less than seven.
A majority of the full authorized membership of the board of directors of an authority is a quorum to do business.
Unless the bylaws require a larger number, the board may take any action by a majority vote of the directors present at a validly called meeting.

subsection.text: The board shall determine the times and places of its meetings.

paragraph.text: A citizen director is entitled to the compensation set by:

subparagraph.text: The governing body of the single political subdivision that incorporated or continues the authority; or
The governing bodies of the member political subdivisions.

paragraph.text: However, the compensation for a citizen director may not be increased or decreased during the term of the director.
A director who is also a member of the governing body of a political subdivision may not receive compensation for service as a director.

subsection.text: The board may:

paragraph.text: Set the number of officers, agents, and employees that the board considers proper;
Set the powers, duties, and compensation for these employees; and
Elect or appoint any director as an officer, agent, or employee.

section.text: In addition to the powers set forth elsewhere in this subtitle, an authority may:

paragraph.text: Do anything necessary or convenient to carry out the purposes of this subtitle;
Adopt bylaws to regulate the affairs of the authority and conduct the business of the authority;
Have, use, alter, or abandon a corporate seal;
Sue, be sued, complain, and defend in all courts;
Maintain an office at any place that the authority determines; and
Manage the properties and business of the authority.

subsection.text: An authority may not use any of its powers under this subtitle to construct, improve, maintain, or operate a project that in any way duplicates or competes with an existing public or private utility that serves substantially the same purposes.

paragraph.text: By law, the governing bodies of the member political subdivisions may limit the projects that the authority may begin. If a limitation is made, the authority may not begin a project that is not authorized.
If the governing bodies of the member political subdivisions do not limit the projects that the authority may begin, the authority has all of the powers granted by this subtitle.
The governing body of a political subdivision that has created an authority under this subtitle may not create any other authority to serve any part of the same area.
Unless the governing body of every other member political subdivision consents by law, a member political subdivision may not create or join in the creation of any other authority.

section.text: For the purposes of operation and financing, an authority may combine any water system and sewerage system into a single project.

subsection.text: The board of directors of an authority may:

paragraph.text: Acquire, lease as a lessee, hold, and use any interest in any property or franchise that is necessary or desirable to carry out the purposes of the authority;
Sell, lease as a lessor, transfer, or otherwise dispose of any interest in any property or franchise of the authority; and
Acquire any right in land or water right in connection with land by gift, purchase, or eminent domain.

subsection.text: To condemn an interest in property that is owned by a political subdivision, an authority must obtain the consent of the governing body of the political subdivision.

section.text: Subject to reasonable local police regulation that is established by the governing body of any political subdivision that has jurisdiction in the area, an authority may enter on, use, occupy, or dig up any street, road, highway, or public or private land that is necessary to acquire, construct, or maintain a project.

subsection.text: When the owner of any property connects the property with a project operated by an authority, the authority may charge a reasonable tapping fee.
The tapping fee is in addition to any charges that the authority makes for rental or use of its projects.

section.text: An authority may accept:

paragraph.text: From a federal agency, any grant to aid in the construction, acquisition, or operation of a project; and
From any source, aid or a contribution of money, property, labor, or any other thing of value for any stated purpose.

section.text: If a political subdivision that is not a member of an authority annexes real property that is served by the authority, the authority may continue to do business on and exercise jurisdiction over its properties and facilities over its annexed real property as long as:

paragraph.text: Any bond or indebtedness of the authority in effect at the time of the annexation remains outstanding or unpaid; or
Any contract or other obligation of the authority in effect at the time of the annexation continues in force.

subsection.text: Each authority shall:

paragraph.text: Keep a complete record of its receipts and expenditures;
Employ a certified public accountant to audit its books and accounts;
Keep a detailed audit and financial statement of its accounts available and open for public inspection at its principal office during business hours; and
File annually a certified copy of the detailed audit and financial statement with the governing body of each member political subdivision.
In person or by authorized agents, the governing body of any member political subdivision may examine and audit the books and records of the authority.
An examination or audit under this subsection is without cost to the authority.

section.text: An authority may issue its bonds to pay any part of the cost of a project of the authority.

subsection.text: The issuance of a bond under this subtitle is not subject to conditions or limitations in any other law of this State.
Sections 8-201, 8-206, and 8-208 of the State Finance and Procurement Article do not apply to any refunding bond issued under this subtitle.
A bond issued under this subtitle:

paragraph.text: Is not a pledge of the faith and credit of this State or any of its political subdivisions; and

Shall say on its face that neither the faith and credit of this State nor the faith and credit of any of its political subdivisions is pledged to the payment of the principal of or interest on the bond.

subsection.text: The issuance of a bond under this subtitle does not obligate this State or any of its political subdivisions directly, indirectly, or contingently:

paragraph.text: To levy any tax; or
To make any appropriation for payment of the bonds, except from funds pledged in accordance with this subtitle.

section.text: A bond issued under this subtitle is a security:

paragraph.text: In which any person who conducts a banking business, investment business, or insurance business, any fiduciary, any other person, or any public officer or agency of this State or of any political subdivision may invest funds, including capital that:

subparagraph.text: Is in the control of the person, officer, or agency; or
Belongs to the person, officer, or agency; and

paragraph.text: That may be deposited with and received by any officer or agency of this State, or any political subdivision, or any officer of a political subdivision, for any purpose for which the deposit of bonds or other obligations of this State is authorized by law.

section.text: By resolution of its board of directors, an authority may:

paragraph.text: Issue bonds of the authority;
Secure the payment of the bonds by pledge or deed of trust of all or any part of the revenue of the authority;
Either before or after the issuance of bonds, make any agreement that the authority considers advisable with:

subparagraph.text: A purchaser or holder of the bonds; or
Any other person in connection with the bonds; and

paragraph.text: Provide generally for:

subparagraph.text: The security for the bonds; and
The rights of the holders of the bonds.

subsection.text: An authority may issue bonds under this subtitle without:

paragraph.text: Obtaining the approval or consent of any unit of the State government; or
Doing anything not specifically required by this subtitle.

subsection.text: An authority may sell bonds under this subtitle at public or private sale and at a price the authority determines is in the best interests of:

paragraph.text: The authority; and
The political subdivision that is to be served.

subsection.text: This section applies only in Allegany County, Dorchester County, and the town of Middletown in Frederick County.

paragraph.text: An authority may not issue bonds unless the question of issuance of the bonds is submitted to the registered voters who reside within the geographical area served by the authority.

The governing body and the board of election supervisors in each political subdivision shall do whatever is necessary and proper to submit the question to a referendum of the qualified voters of the political subdivision.

subsection.text: A qualified voter at a referendum under this section is an individual who:

paragraph.text: Lives within the geographic area served by the authority; and
Is qualified and registered to vote in State and county elections in the area.
The board of directors of the authority shall set the date for the referendum.
Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, the Election Law Article governs the conduct of the referendum.

subsection.text: The appropriate board of election supervisors shall print the words “For the bond issue” and “Against the bond issue” on each ballot at a referendum under this section.

paragraph.text: If a majority of the qualified voters who vote on the question vote “For the bond issue”, the authority may issue the bonds.
If a majority of the qualified voters who vote on the question vote “Against the bond issue”, the authority may not issue the bonds.

subsection.text: A referendum under this section does not prevent an authority from submitting the same or a similar question at another referendum that is held at a later time.

paragraph.text: Before the preparation of definitive bonds, an authority may issue interim receipts or temporary bonds with or without coupons.
Issuance of interim receipts or temporary bonds is subject to the restrictions that govern the issuance of definitive bonds.

subsection.text: Interim receipts or temporary bonds are exchangeable for definitive bonds when the definitive bonds are executed and available for delivery.
An authority may provide for the replacement of any bond that is lost, destroyed, or mutilated.
If an authority considers it necessary, the authority may include any limitation or restriction on the issuance of additional bonds:

paragraph.text: In the resolution that provides for the issuance of bonds of the authority; or
In any trust agreement that secures the bonds.

subsection.text: If a resolution or trust agreement places any limitation or restriction on the issuance of additional bonds, the authority shall honor the limitation or restriction when the authority issues additional bonds.

section.text: By resolution of its board of directors, an authority may provide for the issuance of:

paragraph.text: Refunding bonds to refund any bonds of the authority that were issued under this subtitle and are outstanding; or
A single issue of bonds to:

subparagraph.text: Pay the cost of a project or of the improvement, extension, or reconstruction of or additions to a project; and
Refund bonds that:

sub-subparagraph.text: Were issued under this subtitle and are outstanding; and
Have matured, are subject to redemption, or can be retired.

subsection.text: To secure any bond issued under this subtitle, an authority may enter into a trust agreement with a corporate trustee, which may be:

paragraph.text: A trust company; or
A bank that has the powers of a trust company.

subsection.text: In the resolution or trust agreement that authorizes the authority to issue bonds, the authority:

paragraph.text: May pledge or assign the revenues to be received from the operation of any project for which the bonds are issued;

In the case of bonds that finance a sewerage system, and to the extent allowed under § 9-946 of this subtitle, may pledge or assign as security for the bonds the revenues to be received from the water system of the authority;
May not convey or mortgage any part of a project;
May include reasonable, proper, and lawful provisions for protecting and enforcing the rights and remedies of bondholders, including:

subparagraph.text: Covenants stating the duties of the authority to acquire, construct, improve, maintain, operate, repair, and insure any project for which the bonds are issued;
Provisions for the custody, protection, and use of the funds of the authority; and
Provisions for the employment of consulting engineers in connection with the construction or maintenance of any project for which the bonds are issued;

paragraph.text: May state the rights and remedies of bondholders and, in the case of a trust agreement, of trustees;
May restrict the individual right of action of a bondholder in any way that is customary in a trust agreement or trust indenture that secures bonds or debentures of a corporation; and
May include any other provision that the authority considers to be reasonable and proper for the security of bondholders.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, an authority may provide for:

paragraph.text: Payment of the proceeds of the sale of its bonds and payment of any revenue of the authority to any officer, board, or depositary that the authority designates as custodian of the proceeds and revenues; and
Disbursement of the proceeds and revenues with any safeguards and restrictions that the authority determines.

subsection.text: An authority may treat any expense that is incurred in carrying out the provisions of a resolution or trust agreement under this section as a part of the cost of operation of the project.
A resolution or trust agreement that provides for the issuance of or secures bonds under this subtitle may:

paragraph.text: Include any of the provisions in subsections (c) through (f) of this section; and
Require the authority to adopt resolutions or take any other lawful action that is necessary to enforce those provisions.

subsection.text: If a resolution or trust agreement includes any of the provisions of subsections (c) through (f) of this section, the authority may adopt resolutions and take any other lawful action that is necessary to enforce those provisions.

If the owner, tenant, or occupant of a parcel of land is obligated to pay rates, fees, or charges for the use of or services furnished by any project of an authority, the authority may require the owner, tenant, or occupant to deposit with the authority, before the use is made or the services are furnished, a reasonable amount:

paragraph.text: To insure payment of the rates, fees, or charges; and
To be applied to payment of any delinquent rates, fees, or charges.

subsection.text: If the owner, tenant, or occupant of a parcel of land does not pay any rate, fee, or charge for the use of or services furnished by any project of an authority within 30 days after the rate, fee, or charge becomes due and payable, the authority, at the end of the 30-day period, may:

paragraph.text: Disconnect the parcel of land from the water system or sewerage system of the authority or otherwise suspend services; and
Recover the amount of the rate, fee, or charge that is delinquent, plus interest:

subparagraph.text: In a civil action; or
By foreclosure of the lien for the rate, fee, or charge.

subsection.text: If any rate, fee, or charge for the use of or services furnished to a lot or parcel of land by a sewerage system that is owned, constructed, or operated by an authority under this subtitle is not paid within 30 days after the rate, fee, or charge becomes due and payable, the owner, tenant, or occupant of the parcel of land shall stop disposing of sewage or industrial wastes from the parcel of land directly or indirectly into the sewerage system until the rate, fee, or charge, plus interest, is paid.

paragraph.text: If the owner, tenant, or occupant of a parcel of land does not stop disposing of sewage or industrial wastes as required by subsection (e) of this section, any political subdivision or person who supplies or sells water for use on the parcel of land shall stop supplying or selling the water within 5 days after receiving notice of the delinquency from the authority.

If a political subdivision or person does not stop supplying or selling water for use on a parcel of land as required by paragraph (1) of this subsection, the authority may shut off the supply of water to the parcel of land.

section.text: Subject to any restriction in the resolution or trust agreement that provides for the issuance of or secures the bonds of an authority, any holder of the bonds, any holder of any coupons from the bonds, or any trustee under a trust agreement that secures the bonds may:

paragraph.text: Enforce in any civil action any right granted by the resolution or trust agreement or by any law of this State; and

Compel the performance of any duty imposed on the authority or an officer of the authority by this subtitle or by the resolution or trust agreement, including setting, charging, and collecting rates, fees, and charges for the use of or services furnished by any project.

subsection.text: An authority shall pay the principal of and interest on its bonds only from the funds from which this subtitle authorizes payment.
For any bond that an authority issues, the authority:

paragraph.text: Shall place the date of issue on the bond;
Shall set the maturity date for the bond, which shall be any time up to 40 years from the date of issue; and
May provide for the redemption of the bond before maturity:

subparagraph.text: At the option of the authority; and
At a price and on terms and conditions that the authority fixes before it issues the bond.

subsection.text: A bond or certificate that otherwise conforms to this section is valid and sufficient for all purposes whether or not the officer whose signature or a facsimile of whose signature is on the bond or certificate is still an officer when the bond or certificate is delivered.
An authority:

paragraph.text: Shall determine the form of its bonds; and
May issue its bonds in coupon or registered form or both.

subsection.text: An authority shall determine:

paragraph.text: The manner of execution of its bonds;
The denominations of its bonds; and
The places for payment of the principal of and interest on its bonds, which may be any bank or trust company.

subsection.text: A bond issued under this subtitle is fully negotiable as provided in Title 8 of the Commercial Law Article.
An authority may provide for:

paragraph.text: The registration of any coupon bond as to:

subparagraph.text: Principal only; or
Both principal and interest; and

paragraph.text: The reconversion into a coupon bond of any bond that is registered as to both principal and interest.

subsection.text: An authority shall:

paragraph.text: Use the proceeds of any bond that it issues only to pay for the project for which the bond was issued; and
Disburse the proceeds of any bond in the manner and under any restrictions that the authority provides in the resolution or trust agreement that authorizes the issuance of or secures the bond.

If, for any reason, the proceeds of an issue of bonds are less than the cost of the project for which the authority issued the bonds, the authority may issue additional bonds, in a manner similar to that followed in issuing the original bonds, to provide the amount of the deficit.
Unless otherwise provided in the resolution or trust agreement that authorizes the issuance of or secures the original bonds, additional bonds issued under this subsection:

subparagraph.text: Are of the same issue as the original bonds; and
Are entitled to payment from the same fund, without any preference or priority being given to the original bonds.

subsection.text: If the proceeds of an issue of bonds exceed the cost of the project for which the authority issued the bonds, the authority shall deposit the surplus to the credit of the reserve account or sinking fund for the bonds.

An authority may enter into any contract that the authority determines is necessary or incidental to the exercise of its powers or the performance of its duties under this subtitle, including a contract with:

paragraph.text: Any federal agency, this State, any agency of this State, any political subdivision, or any person:

subparagraph.text: Providing for or relating to furnishing the services and facilities of a project of the authority; or

In connection with the services and facilities of a water system or sewerage system that is owned or controlled by the federal agency, this State, the agency of this State, the political subdivision, or the person;

paragraph.text: Any person, political subdivision, or public authority of this or any adjoining state for the construction and operation of a project that is located partly in this State and partly in the adjoining state; and
Any federal agency or political subdivision relating to:

subparagraph.text: The use by the authority of the services or facilities of any water system or sewerage system that is not owned or operated by the authority; or
The use by the federal agency, political subdivision, or residents of the political subdivision of:

sub-subparagraph.text: Any project acquired or constructed by the authority under this subtitle; or
The services or facilities of the project.

subsection.text: A contract under this section:

paragraph.text: Is subject to any provision, limitation, or condition that is contained in:

subparagraph.text: A resolution of the authority that authorizes the authority to issue bonds; or
A trust agreement that secures bonds of the authority;

paragraph.text: May provide for the collection of fees, rates, or charges for the services and facilities furnished to a political subdivision or any of its residents, and may provide that the collection be done:

subparagraph.text: By a political subdivision or any agent of a political subdivision; or
By any agent of an authority; and

paragraph.text: May provide for the enforcement of any delinquent charge.

subsection.text: Any law that is enacted by a political subdivision under a contract under this section:

paragraph.text: Is not repealable if any bond to which the contract relates is outstanding and unpaid; and
Is for the benefit of the bondholders.

subsection.text: A contract under this section and any law of a political subdivision that is enacted under the contract shall provide that the total of any rates, fees, and charges is sufficient to pay all of the obligations that are assumed by the other party to the contract.
An authority may set, charge, and collect rates, fees, and charges in connection with each of its projects to provide funds that, with any other available funds, are sufficient at all times:

paragraph.text: To pay:

subparagraph.text: The expenses of the authority;
The cost of construction, extension, repair, improvement, maintenance, and operation of each facility and property of the authority;

The cost of maintenance, repair, and operation of each project for which the authority issued bonds under this subtitle, including the creation of reserves for the maintenance, repair, operation, replacement, depreciation, and necessary extensions of the project; and
The principal of and interest on all bonds of the authority whenever due and payable, including the creation of reserves to provide a margin of safety; and

paragraph.text: To fulfill the terms of any agreement that is made with:

subparagraph.text: A purchaser or holder of any bond of the authority;
A political subdivision that is incorporated or is a member of the authority; or
A political subdivision that is or will be served by the authority.

subsection.text: An authority may:

paragraph.text: Set rates, fees, and charges for the services and facilities of its water system that are sufficient to pay:

subparagraph.text: The cost of maintenance, repair, and operation of its sewerage system; and
The principal of and interest on bonds that the authority issues for its sewerage system; and

paragraph.text: Subject to prior pledges of surplus revenue, pledge any surplus revenue of its water system for the purposes stated in item (1) of this subsection.
An authority may base rates, fees, and charges for the services and facilities of its sewerage system on:

subparagraph.text: The quantity of water used;
The amount of the water bill;
The number and size of sewer connections;
The number and kind of plumbing fixtures in use in the premises that are connected with the sewerage system;
The number or average number of individuals who reside in, work in, or are otherwise connected with the premises that are connected with the sewerage system;
The type or character of the premises that are connected with the sewerage system;
Any other factor that affects the use of the facilities furnished; or
Any combination of these factors.

paragraph.text: If any premises obtain all or part of their water from a source other than a public water system, an authority may charge the premises for sewerage services:

subparagraph.text: By gauging or metering; or
In any other manner that the authority approves.

subsection.text: An authority may base rates, fees, and charges for any of its other services and facilities on any factor that the authority determines to be reasonable and proper.
The rates, fees, and charges of an authority shall be:

paragraph.text: Reasonable;
Uniform by class; and
Determined solely by the authority.
Any person who questions whether the rates, fees, or charges of an authority are reasonable or uniform may sue the authority:

subparagraph.text: In the circuit court for the county in which the project is located; or
If the project is located in 2 or more counties, in the circuit court for the county in which the principal office of the project is located.

paragraph.text: The circuit court has exclusive jurisdiction to determine the reasonableness and uniformity of the rates, fees, and other charges of an authority.

section.text: If the sewage or other waste that a manufacturing, commercial, or industrial plant or other building or premises discharges into a sewerage system is, because of its character, an unreasonable burden on the sewerage system, the authority that owns, operates, or maintains the sewerage system may:

paragraph.text: Impose an additional charge on the owner, tenant, or occupant of the plant, building, or premises; or
Require the owner, tenant, or occupant of the plant, building, or premises, before it discharges its sewage or other waste, to treat the sewage or waste in a manner that the authority determines.

subsection.text: An authority may use data that a political subdivision furnishes under this section to calculate the rates, fees, and charges of the authority for sewer services to a consumer of water.

By the 15th day of the month after the month in which the political subdivision issues water bills, and at the request of the authority, each member political subdivision shall submit to the authority:

paragraph.text: A list of the water meter readings on which the water bills were based; or
A statement of the amounts of the water bills.

subsection.text: An authority has a lien on real estate:

paragraph.text: For:

subparagraph.text: The amount of any fee, rent, or charge, including a tapping fee, imposed on an owner, tenant, or occupant of the real estate for the use and services of a project of the authority; and
Any accrued interest on the fee, rent, or charge; and

paragraph.text: From the time when the fee, rent, or charge is due and payable.

subsection.text: A lien under this section is superior to any interest of an owner, tenant, or occupant of the affected real estate.

A lien under this section binds or affects a subsequent bona fide purchaser of the real estate who purchases for valuable consideration and without actual notice of the lien only after the amount of the lien is entered in a lien register that is:

paragraph.text: Furnished for this purpose by and at the expense of the authority; and
Kept among the land records of the county where the real estate is located.
The clerk of the circuit court in the county where the real estate is located:

subparagraph.text: Shall keep and make available for public inspection any lien register that an authority provides to the clerk under this section;
Shall record and index in the lien register any entry that the authority certifies; and
Is entitled to a fee of 5 cents for each entry that the clerk makes under this section.

paragraph.text: To record a lien under this section, an authority shall pay to the clerk of the circuit court a fee of 5 cents for each entry.
The amount of the fee paid for recording a lien shall be added to the amount of the lien.
To discharge a lien under this section, a person shall pay to the authority:

subparagraph.text: The total amount of the lien; and
Any interest that has accrued on the lien to the date of payment.

paragraph.text: When a person discharges a lien under this subsection, the authority shall deliver to the person a certificate of payment.

When a person presents a certificate of payment to the clerk of the circuit court in the county where the real estate is located, the clerk, without any fee, shall record the discharge of the lien in the lien register.

subsection.text: In this section, “abutting lot” means a parcel of land:

paragraph.text: That abuts on a street or other public way that contains a sanitary sewer that is part of, is served by, or may be served by the sewerage system of an authority; and
On which a building has been constructed for residential, commercial, or industrial use.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, when an authority acquires or constructs a sewerage system under this subtitle, the authority, by rule, regulation, or resolution, may require each owner of an abutting lot to:

paragraph.text: Connect with the sewerage system of the authority each building that is constructed for residential, commercial, or industrial use on the abutting lot; and
Stop using any other method for the disposal of sewage or other polluting matter.

subsection.text: The authority may not require the owner of an abutting lot to connect any building on the abutting lot if the abutting lot is served by a facility for the disposal of sewage or other polluting matter that was constructed and is operated in accordance with standards set or approved by the Secretary.

Whenever this section requires a person to connect a building to the sewerage system of an authority, the person shall make the connection in accordance with the rules and regulations of the authority.
The rules and regulations of an authority may set a reasonable charge for making a connection under this section.

A political subdivision that owns or operates a water system may contract with an authority as provided in subsection (b) of this section to shut off the supply of water to any premises that are connected with any sewerage system of the authority.

If the owner, tenant, or occupant of any premises described in subsection (a) of this section fails, within the time stated in the contract, to pay any rate, fee, or charge for the use or services of the sewerage system of an authority, the authority may shut off the supply of water to the premises.

paragraph.text: Notwithstanding any other law, the governing body of a political subdivision may transfer jurisdiction over, lease, lend, give, sell, or convey to an authority, on the request of the authority, with or without consideration, any of the following:

subparagraph.text: Any facility;
Any right or interest in a facility;
Any property that appertains to a facility;
Any real property; or
Any right or interest in real property.

paragraph.text: The authority shall use property transferred or conveyed under this subsection in connection with the construction, extension, repair, improvement, maintenance, or operation of 1 or more projects of the authority.
The transfer or conveyance shall be on terms and conditions that the governing body of the political subdivision determines to be in the best interests of the political subdivision.

If the land is necessary or desirable in connection with the construction, extension, repair, improvement, maintenance, or operation of any project, this State consents to the use by an authority of any land that is:

subparagraph.text: Owned or controlled by this State; and

sub-subparagraph.text: Below the high-water mark of any waters of this State; or
In the right-of-way of any State highway.

paragraph.text: The State Highway Administration must approve the use of land that is in any State highway right-of-way.

section.text: After an authority pays or provides for the payment of the principal of and interest on each bond that is secured by a pledge of the revenue of a project, and subject to any agreement that concerns the operation or disposition of the project, the authority may convey the project to its member political subdivisions.
In addition to the powers set forth elsewhere in this subtitle, a political subdivision may:

paragraph.text: Contract with an authority:

subparagraph.text: For the collection, treatment, or disposal of sewage; and
With respect to any matter or thing concerning which the authority may contract with the political subdivision under this subtitle; and

paragraph.text: Lend money to an authority to pay the organization and preliminary expenses of the authority, on condition that the loan is repaid out of the proceeds of the 1st bond issue of the authority.

subsection.text: An authority is not required to pay any tax or assessment on:

paragraph.text: Any project; or
The income from any project.

subsection.text: This State, any political subdivision, and any other public agency in this State may not tax:

paragraph.text: Any bond that is issued under this subtitle;
The transfer of the bond; or
Any income from the bond, including any profit on the sale of the bond.

subsection.text: Any money that an authority receives under this subtitle as proceeds from the sale of bonds or as revenues is a trust fund that the authority shall hold and apply only as provided in this subtitle.

The resolution or trust agreement that provides for the issuance of or secures bonds of an authority shall provide that any officer to whom, or any bank, trust company, or other fiscal agent to which, the authority pays any money received under this subtitle shall:

paragraph.text: Act as trustee of the money; and
Hold and apply the money:

subparagraph.text: For the purposes of this subtitle; and
Subject to any provision of the resolution or trust agreement.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Certification” means certification by the Department under this subtitle.
“Person” includes any state, county, municipal corporation, federal agency, or special taxing area.
“Public drinking water system” has the meaning stated in the federal Safe Drinking Water Act for “public water system”.
“Water quality laboratory” means any person who, by any method, examines a public drinking water system:

paragraph.text: To determine whether it complies with the federal Safe Drinking Water Act or State standards for public drinking water; or
To produce laboratory information for enforcement of the federal Safe Drinking Water Act or State standards for public drinking water.

section.text: The provisions of this subtitle that require the payment of a fee for certification or renewal of a certification do not apply to any county or municipal corporation in this State.

subsection.text: The Department shall:

paragraph.text: Adopt rules and regulations to carry out the provisions of this subtitle;
Establish a proficiency testing program to test the performance of any water quality laboratory; and
Set standards for:

subparagraph.text: Demonstrating satisfactory performance in a proficiency testing program; and
Conducting the program.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall have each water quality laboratory inspected at least triennially.

section.text: A water quality laboratory shall be certified by the Department before the water quality laboratory may be operated in this State.
To qualify for certification, a water quality laboratory shall:

paragraph.text: Meet the standards and qualifications the Department sets; and
Comply with the rules and regulations that the Department adopts under this subtitle.

section.text: Any person who wishes to operate a water quality laboratory shall:

paragraph.text: Submit to the Department, on the form the Department requires, an application for certification of the water quality laboratory; and
Pay to the Department the application fee set by the Department.

section.text: Before certifying any water quality laboratory, the Secretary shall have the water quality laboratory inspected.
The Department shall certify any water quality laboratory that meets the requirements of this subtitle.
While it is effective, certification under this subtitle authorizes the certified water quality laboratory to:

paragraph.text: Be operated; and
Test well water for State standards.

subsection.text: A certification expires on the first anniversary of its effective date unless the certification is renewed for a 1–year term as provided in this section.

At least 1 month before a certification expires, the Department shall send to the certified water quality laboratory, by first–class mail to the last known address of the water quality laboratory, a renewal notice that states:

paragraph.text: The date on which the current certification expires;
The date by which the renewal application must be received by the Department for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the certification expires; and
The amount of the renewal fee.

subsection.text: Before the certification expires, the certified water quality laboratory may renew its certification for an additional 1–year term if the water quality laboratory:

paragraph.text: Otherwise is entitled to be certified;
Pays to the Department the renewal fee set by the Department; and
Submits to the Department a renewal application on the form that the Department requires.

subsection.text: The Department shall renew the certification of each water quality laboratory that meets the requirements of this subtitle.

section.text: If the water quality laboratory meets the renewal requirements of this subtitle, the Secretary shall reinstate the certification of a water quality laboratory the certification of which has not been renewed for any reason.

subsection.text: A water quality laboratory certification is not transferable.
Each certified water quality laboratory shall display its certificate of certification conspicuously in the place of business of the certified water quality laboratory.

If a water quality laboratory located outside of this State examines any of the public drinking water of this State, the results of that examination may not be accepted by this State unless the water quality laboratory is certified under this subtitle.
A person who operates a water quality laboratory in another state and who wishes to have the water quality laboratory certified in this State shall:

paragraph.text: Submit to the Department, on the form that the Department requires, an application for certification of the water quality laboratory;

Show to the satisfaction of the Department that the water quality laboratory meets at least the minimum standards and qualifications adopted by the Department under this subtitle for water quality laboratories in this State; and
Pay to the Department the application fee set by the Department.

subsection.text: A water quality laboratory that is in another state and is certified under this subtitle may renew its certification in accordance with the provisions of this subtitle.

section.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of § 9-1017 of this subtitle, the Secretary may reprimand or revoke or suspend the certification of any water quality laboratory that:

paragraph.text: Fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain a certification;
Fraudulently or deceptively uses a certification;
Fails to meet substantially the standards and qualifications adopted by the Department under this subtitle; or
Fails to comply with the rules and regulations adopted by the Department under this subtitle.

subsection.text: Before the Secretary takes any action under § 9-1016 of this subtitle, the Secretary shall give the water quality laboratory against which the action is contemplated:

paragraph.text: Written notice of the charges filed against it; and
An opportunity for a hearing before the Secretary.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with the Administrative Procedure Act.
Any person aggrieved by a final decision of the Secretary in a contested case under this subtitle may take a direct judicial appeal.
The appeal shall be made as provided for judicial review of final decisions in the Administrative Procedure Act.

section.text: A person may not operate or attempt to operate a water quality laboratory in this State unless the water quality laboratory is certified by the Department.

Unless the water quality laboratory the person operates is certified under this subtitle, a person may not represent to the public by title, by description of services, methods or procedures, or otherwise that the person operates a certified water quality laboratory.
A person may not:

paragraph.text: Sell or fraudulently obtain, or provide or aid in selling or fraudulently obtaining or providing, a certification issued under this subtitle; or
Operate as a certified laboratory under a certification that is unlawfully or fraudulently obtained or unlawfully issued.

section.text: A person who violates any provision of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both.
This subtitle may be cited as the “Maryland Water Quality Laboratory Certification Act”.

subsection.text: In Garrett County, before constructing on private property a building that will need a septic tank disposal system, the person who proposes to construct the building shall obtain a septic tank permit from the Garrett County Health Department.
An applicant for a septic tank permit under this section shall submit to the Garrett County Health Department:

paragraph.text: An application on the form that the Garrett County Health Department requires; and
A plan for the septic tank system.

subsection.text: Before issuing a septic tank permit, the Garrett County Health Department may inspect the site of the proposed septic tank.
If it approves the application, the Garrett County Health Department shall issue a septic tank permit.
A person may not build a septic tank in violation of this section.
A person who violates subsection (e) of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $100.
This section applies to charges for sewer service or solid waste disposal service provided in Worcester County by any State, county, or municipal agency that does not also provide water services.
If a bill for sewer service or solid waste disposal service remains unpaid for 30 days after being sent, the agency providing that service:

paragraph.text: After giving written notice, may stop the service; and
Before restoring the service, may require payment of the entire unpaid bill plus $5.

subsection.text: The notice required by this section shall be:

paragraph.text: Left on the premises served; or
Mailed to the last known address of the owner of the premises served.

subsection.text: Unpaid sewer charges, including any penalty, shall be:

paragraph.text: A first lien against the property; and
Collectible as taxes.

subsection.text: In this section, “public agency” means:

paragraph.text: Any State, county, or municipal authority;
Any public drainage commission;
Any public sewerage commission;
Any public water commission; or
Any sanitary district created under Subtitle 6 of this title.
A public agency may make a contract or an agreement with the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission:

subparagraph.text: To connect any drainage, sewerage, or water system of that public agency with facilities of the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission;
To buy water from or sell water to the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission;
To accept drainage or sewage from the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission; and
To send drainage or sewage to the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission.

paragraph.text: A public agency may make any other agreement with the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission to aid in the building or operation of any drainage system, sewerage system, or water system built or operated by the public agency or the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission.

subsection.text: The powers granted in this section are in addition to and not limited by any other powers granted to a public agency.
The Department may establish a privatization program for performing soil percolation tests in one or more counties in the State.
In order to be eligible to participate in the program established under subsection (a) of this section a person shall:

paragraph.text: Be a sanitarian licensed in the State or a qualified professional who meets standards at least as stringent as the State sanitarian licensing requirements;
Have demonstrated experience in working with on-site sewage disposal systems; and
Meet any other requirements established by the local health department to ensure the quality of testing performed under the program.

subsection.text: The health department for any county seeking to establish a privatization program under this section shall work with the Department to implement the program.
The Department may adopt regulations to implement the privatization program.
This section applies only in Carroll County.
There is an on-site and small Community Wastewater Disposal Fund in the Carroll County Health Department.

The Carroll County Health Department shall use the Fund to provide grants to persons to correct existing or potential public health hazards through innovative or alternative on-site sewage disposal systems and eligible small community self-help projects.

The Fund shall consist of 10% of all soil evaluation fees that the Carroll County Health Department has collected and retained and deposited into the Fund as authorized under § 3-202 of the Health - General Article.

Notwithstanding any other provision of law to the contrary, any unexpended moneys in the Fund may not be transferred or revert to the General Fund of the State, but shall remain in the Fund to be used for the purposes specified in subsection (c) of this section.

section.text: The governing body of Howard County may enact local laws governing the installation and use of multiuse sewerage systems that are not inconsistent with State law.
The Howard County governing body may require the recipient of a permit to install a multiuse sewerage system to post a performance bond before installing the multiuse sewerage system.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Nitrogen removal technology” means the best available technology for the removal of nitrogen.
“On–site sewage disposal system” means a sewage treatment unit, collection system, disposal area, and related appurtenances.

subsection.text: A person may not:

paragraph.text: Install, or have installed, on property a person owns in the State in the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays Critical Area, an on–site sewage disposal system to service a newly constructed building, unless the on–site sewage disposal system utilizes nitrogen removal technology; or

Replace or have replaced, an existing on–site sewage disposal system on property a person owns in the State in the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays Critical Area, unless the replacement on–site sewage disposal system utilizes nitrogen removal technology.

Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection and in accordance with § 9–1605.2(h) of this title, the Department shall assist homeowners in paying the cost difference between a conventional on–site sewage disposal system and a system that utilizes nitrogen removal technology with money from the Bay Restoration Fund, if sufficient funds are available.

In calendar years 2010, 2011, and 2012, the Department shall assist homeowners by paying 100% of the cost difference between a conventional on–site sewage disposal system and a system that utilizes nitrogen removal technology with money from the Bay Restoration Fund, if the homeowner:

subparagraph.text: Is required under subsection (b)(2) of this section to replace an existing on–site sewage disposal system with an on–site sewage disposal system that utilizes nitrogen removal technology; and
Has a failing on–site sewage disposal system.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, a person who violates subsection (b) of this section is subject to the civil and administrative penalties and the enforcement mechanisms provided in §§ 9–334 through 9–342 of this title.
The penalties imposed under this section may not exceed $8,000.
The Department shall adopt regulations to implement this section.

The regulations adopted in accordance with paragraph (1) of this subsection shall include provisions to ensure that appropriate management measures are provided for the operation and maintenance of nitrogen removal technology.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Nitrogen removal technology” has the meaning stated in § 9–1108 of this subtitle.
“On–site sewage disposal system” has the meaning stated in § 9–1108 of this subtitle.
“Vendor” means a person that sells, offers for sale, or distributes on–site sewage disposal systems that utilize nitrogen removal technology.

In accordance with subsection (c) of this section, the Department shall evaluate and rank all best available nitrogen removal technologies for on–site sewage disposal systems to advise local governments and residents of the State of approved technologies that qualify for funding under § 9–1605.2(h)(2) of this title.
The Department shall:

subparagraph.text: Make available the evaluation and ranking of all best available nitrogen removal technologies required under this section on the Department’s Web site; and

Provide the evaluation and ranking of all best available nitrogen removal technologies to a county, municipality, or resident of the State in any correspondence relating to approved technologies that qualify for funding under § 9–1605.2(h)(2) of this title.

subsection.text: The Department shall evaluate and rank all best available nitrogen removal technologies for on–site sewage disposal systems based on:

paragraph.text: The total amount of nitrogen reduction the technology can achieve;
The total cost of the technology, including the estimated annual cost of operation and maintenance, including electricity costs;
The cost per pound of the nitrogen reduction; and
Any other information the Department determines is necessary.

subsection.text: Beginning June 1, 2011, and every 2 years thereafter, the Department shall request information from vendors necessary to carry out the requirements of this section.
In this section, “individual sewerage system” means a privately owned system of sewers, piping and treatment tanks or other facilities that:

paragraph.text: Serves only a single lot for the disposal of sewage; and
Discharges to the surface waters of the State.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, a person may not install an individual sewerage system in the State.

Subject to the Department’s approval, a person may install an individual sewerage system in the State for residential use if an existing on–site sewage disposal system fails and cannot be repaired or replaced by any means.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Community sewerage system” means a publicly or privately owned sewerage system that serves at least two lots.

“Controlling authority” means a unit of government, a body public and corporate, or an intercounty agency authorized by the State, a county, or a municipal corporation to provide for the management, operation, and maintenance of a community sewerage system, shared facility, or multiuse sewerage system.
“Shared facility” means a sewerage system that:

subparagraph.text: Serves more than one:

sub-subparagraph.text: Lot and is owned in common by the users;
Condominium unit and is owned in common by the users or by a condominium association;
User and is located on individual lots owned by the users; or
User on one lot and is owned in common by the users;

subparagraph.text: Is located wholly or partly on any of the common elements of a condominium; or
Serves a housing cooperative or other multiple ownership cooperative.

subsection.text: This section may not be construed as requiring a local jurisdiction to:

paragraph.text: Be a controlling authority; or
Authorize or allow the use of a shared facility or a community sewerage system within the local jurisdiction.

subsection.text: A shared facility or community sewerage system may be approved only if the system:

paragraph.text: Is managed, operated, and maintained by:

subparagraph.text: A controlling authority; or
A third party under contract with the controlling authority; and

paragraph.text: Discharges:

subparagraph.text: To the surface waters of the State in accordance with a permit issued under § 9–323 of this title;

By way of land application under a nutrient management plan required under § 8–803.1 of the Agriculture Article that assures 100% of the nitrogen and phosphorus in the applied effluent will be taken up by vegetation; or
By way of an on–site sewerage system.

subsection.text: In this section, “rural zone” means an area of Montgomery County designated as a Rural Zone, Rural Cluster Zone, Rural Density Transfer Zone, Rural Neighborhood Cluster Zone, or Rural Service Zone as described in the Montgomery County Code Zoning Ordinance.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, in Montgomery County, an on–site sewage disposal system or well located in a rural zone may only serve one additional lot or parcel that has been subdivided from a single property on which the on–site sewage disposal system or well is located under an on–site sewage disposal system easement or well easement, respectively, provided that:

subparagraph.text: The property on which the on–site sewage disposal system or well is located does not have an existing on–site sewage disposal system easement or well easement;
The subdivision of the property was made in accordance with a State or county agricultural land conservation program if the property is subject to an agricultural land conservation easement; and
Only one on–site sewage disposal system easement may serve only one subdivided lot or parcel.

paragraph.text: An easement for an on–site sewage disposal system or well under paragraph (1) of this subsection may be granted from the original parcel to a new lot or parcel being created and the easement must not be granted to any lot or parcel that did not originate from the same original parcel.

subsection.text: An on–site sewage disposal system or well under subsection (b)(1) of this section may not:

paragraph.text: Serve land that is designated by the State or the governing body of Montgomery County as a special protection area; or
Decrease the land available for agricultural production by more than 4,000 square feet.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Abandon” means to discontinue the use of a well permanently.
“Board” means the State Board of Well Drillers.
“Owner” means a person who has the right to drill into, produce, and appropriate the production of water, for the owner, for another person, or for both of them.

“Underground water” means a supply of water that may be developed by any type of well or spring from beneath the surface of the ground whether the water flows from the well or spring by natural force or is withdrawn by pumping, other mechanical device, or artificial process.
“Well” means a hole made in the ground:

paragraph.text: To explore for groundwater;
To obtain or monitor groundwater;
To inject water into any underground formation from which groundwater may be produced; or
To transfer heat to or from the ground or groundwater, if the hole:

subparagraph.text: Extends more than 20 feet below the surface of the ground; and
Is not a well for obtaining geothermal resources under § 5-601 of this article.

subsection.text: “Well driller” means a person who is in charge of:

paragraph.text: Making, altering, repairing, or sealing a well; or
Installing, altering, repairing, or disconnecting well system equipment.

section.text: A well is considered to be abandoned if:

paragraph.text: It is in such a state of disrepair that its continued use for the purpose of obtaining ground water is impracticable; or
It has been disconnected permanently from any water supply system or irrigation system.

section.text: This subtitle does not limit the powers of any State unit that has jurisdiction of and supervision over the public and drinking water supplies of this State.
This subtitle denies any municipality, county, or other political subdivision of this State the right to adopt and enforce any additional rule or regulation that relates to construction of wells.

subsection.text: The Department shall adopt rules and regulations for the construction of wells.
The rules and regulations may recognize a variation:

paragraph.text: In the primary use or construction of wells; and
Of the materials penetrated in different localities.

subsection.text: Before the Department adopts any rule or regulation that relates to the construction of wells, the Department shall submit the proposed rule or regulation to the Board for comment.

Notwithstanding any provisions to the contrary, a county board of health, delegated by the Department of the Environment to implement a well inspection program, may collect a fee for the issuance of well permits required under § 9-1306 of this subtitle. However, a county health department may not collect a fee for test or irrigation wells.

The Department shall adopt regulations to require that whenever the Department tests water from a well used for domestic purposes the following information shall be given to a person who requests the test and to any other person for whose benefit the test is requested:

paragraph.text: A certificate of potability;
The complete results of the test, whether the test requested is bacteriological or chemical in nature; and
The name, address, and telephone number of the appropriate agency of local government that the person may contact for an explanation of the test results.

subsection.text: The regulations shall apply to any person or unit of State or local government that tests the water from a well.
Except as indicated in subsection (b) of this section, a person may not drill a well in this State unless the Department issues a permit to drill the well.

A person who has not been issued a permit by the Department may, after having notified the county board of health and a municipality if the temporary dewatering device will be located inside the municipality’s corporate boundary line or if the temporary dewatering device will be located 1 mile or less outside the municipality’s corporate boundary line, install a temporary dewatering device to facilitate the installation of underground utilities if the device:

paragraph.text: Is installed 30 feet or less below the ground surface;
Is not located in any trench used for the installation of underground utilities;
Contains no mechanical pumping equipment below the surface; and
Is removed no more than 30 days after installation.

subsection.text: A person installing a temporary dewatering device under subsection (b) of this section shall restore the subsurface conditions of the installation area as nearly as possible to the conditions that existed before the installation.
In applying for a permit to drill a well, the well driller shall:

paragraph.text: Give the Department any information the Department requires; and
Notify a municipality if the well will be drilled inside the municipality’s corporate boundary line or if the well will be drilled 1 mile or less outside the municipality’s corporate boundary line.

subsection.text: As a condition to issuing a permit to drill a well, the Department may require that samples of the materials encountered in drilling the well be preserved and submitted to the Department.

subparagraph.text: A county board of health may establish a permit fee to defray county expenses in inspecting wells, collecting water samples, and issuing certificates of potability.
For an interim certificate of potability, a county board of health shall accept initial test results prepared by a private State certified laboratory.
The fee may be charged before a permit required under § 9–1306 of this subtitle is issued.

Except as provided in subparagraph (iii) of this paragraph, the fee may not exceed $160 per well or $160 per cluster of wells to be used exclusively to transfer heat to or from the ground or groundwater.
In Anne Arundel County only:

sub-subparagraph.text: Subject to item 2 of this subparagraph, the fee charged shall be set so as to produce funds to reflect the actual cost of inspecting wells, collecting water samples, and issuing certificates of potability by the Anne Arundel County Board of Health; and
For a well drilled to replace an existing well the fee charged shall be no more than 50% of the fee as calculated under item 1 of this subparagraph.

paragraph.text: A permit shall be issued within a reasonable period of time after receipt of the application and shall be valid for a period of 12 months from the date of issuance by the approved delegated permitting authority.

subsection.text: A county board of health may waive a fee for a well that is drilled to replace a well not in conformity with the regulations adopted under § 9–1305 of this subtitle.

section.text: On completion of the drilling of any well, the well driller shall file a final report with the Department. The report shall include:

paragraph.text: The log of each well;
The size and depth of each well;
The diameters and lengths of casing and screen installed;
The static and pumping levels;
The yield of each well; and
Any other information relating to the construction or operation of the well that the Department requires.

subsection.text: The owner of any well shall maintain it in accordance with the rules and regulations of the Department.
On abandoning any existing well or test hole, the well owner shall:

paragraph.text: Notify the Department; and
Effectively seal and fill the well or test hole in accordance with the rules and regulations of the Department.

section.text: An owner of a pumping well or flowing well may not discharge or permit the discharge from the well of water that is allowed to run to waste and not put to useful service.

subsection.text: A person who violates any provision of this subtitle or of any rule or regulation adopted under this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to:

paragraph.text: For a first offense, a fine not exceeding $500 or imprisonment not exceeding 3 months or both; or
For a subsequent offense, a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both.

subsection.text: The Department may bring an action for an injunction against any person who violates any provision of this subtitle or any rule, regulation, or permit adopted or issued under this subtitle. In any action for an injunction under this subsection, any finding of the Department after a hearing is prima facie evidence of each fact the Department determines.
A person is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $10,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 6 months or both if the person:

paragraph.text: Knowingly makes any false statement, representation, or certification in any application, record, report, plan, or other document filed or required to be maintained under this subtitle or any rule, regulation, or permit adopted or issued under this subtitle; or

Falsifies, tampers with, or knowingly renders inaccurate any monitoring device or method required to be maintained under this subtitle or any rule, regulation, or permit adopted or issued under this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Attorney General shall take charge of, prosecute, and defend on behalf of this State every case arising under the provisions of this subtitle, including the recovery of penalties.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Innovative and alternative septic system” means any new, experimental, or nonconventional technology that is added to or used in place of a conventional septic or other on-site sewerage system.
“Innovative and alternative septic system” includes but is not limited to:

subparagraph.text: A sand mound septic system;
A septic tank-sewerage evapotranspiration system that is powered by solar energy;
A septic tank-filter cloth trench system; and
Any other innovative on-site sewerage disposal technology that is developed in the future.

subsection.text: “Program” means the Innovative and Alternative Septic System Grant Program.

section.text: There is an Innovative and Alternative Septic System Grant Program in the Department.

subsection.text: The purpose of the Program is to make State grants to political subdivisions of this State who, in turn, will make grants to owners of improved properties with failed systems and owners of previously recorded land that has failed a soil percolation test to install and experiment with innovative and alternative septic systems on the land in order to develop additional types of on-site systems that can be utilized.
The Office of Environmental Programs in the Department shall manage and supervise the Program.
The Department may make grants to political subdivisions of this State under the Program from funds provided in the State budget.
Each political subdivision of this State shall make grants from the money received from the Department to eligible persons who apply under this subtitle.

The State grants awarded by each political subdivision may not exceed 87.5 percent of the anticipated cost of the innovative and alternative septic system, except that grants for systems allowing the development of unimproved properties may not exceed 50 percent.
The Secretary:

paragraph.text: Shall adopt rules and regulations to carry out the provisions of this experimental Program under this subtitle;
Shall request demographic, land use, fiscal impact, or other pertinent information from the Department of Planning or any community planning agency; and
Shall prepare and submit a report to the Governor that describes the activities of the Program and makes recommendations to improve the Program.

subsection.text: The political subdivisions of this State shall administer the Program according to the rules and regulations adopted by the Department.
To be eligible for State funds from a political subdivision under the Program, an applicant shall:

paragraph.text: Own property in this State that:

subparagraph.text: Has an existing failed septic system; or
Is unimproved, was platted before 1972, and has failed percolation testing requirements;

paragraph.text: Have made a good faith effort to obtain approval of or to utilize a conventional septic system;
Agree to conditions of experiment as outlined by the Office of Environmental Programs; and
Only apply for 1 grant to serve 1 home site to upgrade an existing system or to improve 1 unimproved site with a new home and innovative and alternative septic system.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to the development of an unimproved parcel of land that is proposed to be subdivided into building lots.

If the statement “all toilets on this property are required to be waterless toilets approved by the Maryland Department of the Environment” is recorded in the land use covenant or deed for a parcel of property, the Department may:

paragraph.text: Authorize reductions in initial disposal system size;
Establish the amount of the reductions on a case by case basis; and
Prohibit the installation or use of conventional plumbing fixtures where a reduction has been authorized under paragraphs (1) and (2) of this subsection.

subsection.text: The Department may adopt regulations to implement the provisions of this section.

section.text: In this subtitle, “cleaning agent” means a laundry detergent, dishwashing compound, household cleaner, metal cleaner, degreasing compound, commercial cleaner, industrial cleaner, phosphate compound, or other substance that is intended to be used for cleaning purposes.
This subtitle does not apply to a cleaning agent that is:

paragraph.text: A detergent used in dairy, beverage, or food processing cleaning equipment;
A phosphoric acid product, including a sanitizer, brightener, acid cleaner, or metal conditioner;
A detergent used in hospitals, veterinary hospitals or clinics, or health care facilities or in agricultural production;
A detergent used by industry for metal cleaning or conditioning;
Manufactured, stored, or distributed for use or sale outside of the State;
Used in any laboratory, including a biological laboratory, research facility, chemical laboratory, and engineering laboratory; or
Used in a commercial laundry that provides laundry services for a hospital, health care facility, or veterinary hospital.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a person may not use, sell, manufacture, or distribute for use or sale within the State any cleaning agent that contains more than 0.0 percent phosphorus by weight expressed as elemental phosphorus except for an amount not exceeding 0.5 percent phosphorus that is incidental to manufacturing.

Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, a person may use, sell, manufacture, or distribute for use or sale a cleaning agent that contains greater than 0.0 percent phosphorus by weight, but does not exceed 8.7 percent phosphorus by weight that is:

paragraph.text: A detergent used in a commercial dishwashing machine; or
A substance the Secretary, by rule and regulation, excludes from the 0.0 percent phosphorus limitation of subsection (a) of this section based on a finding that compliance with this section would:

subparagraph.text: Create a significant hardship on the user; or
Be unreasonable because of the lack of an adequate substitute cleaning agent.

paragraph.text: A person may not use, sell, manufacture, or distribute for use or sale within the State any detergent for use in a household dishwashing machine that contains more than 0.5 percent phosphorus by weight.

After July 1, 2013, a person may not use, sell, manufacture, or distribute for use or sale within the State any detergent for use in a commercial dishwashing machine that contains more than 0.5 percent phosphorus by weight.

subsection.text: The Department shall adopt rules and regulations to carry out the provisions of this subtitle.
The Department shall enforce this subtitle.

paragraph.text: Any person who uses a cleaning agent in violation of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $100.

subparagraph.text: Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, any person who sells, distributes, or manufactures a cleaning agent in violation of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000.

Any person who knowingly sells or distributes for use or sale within the State a detergent for use in a household dishwashing machine in violation of § 9–1503(c) of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to:

sub-subparagraph.text: For a first offense, a fine not exceeding $1,000; or
For a second or subsequent offense, a fine of not less than $1,000 and not exceeding $25,000.

subsection.text: The Department may seize any cleaning agent held for sale or distribution in violation of this subtitle. The seized cleaning agents are considered forfeited.
Unless the context clearly requires otherwise, in this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Administration” means the Maryland Water Quality Financing Administration.
“Bay Restoration Fund” means the Bay Restoration Fund established under § 9–1605.2 of this subtitle.

“Biological nutrient removal” means a biological nutrient removal technology capable of reducing the nitrogen in wastewater effluent to not more than 8 milligrams per liter, as calculated on an annually averaged basis.
“Board” means the Board of Public Works.

“Bond” means a bond, note, or other evidence of obligation of the Administration issued under this subtitle, including a bond or revenue anticipation note, notes in the nature of commercial paper, and refunding bonds.

“Bond resolution” means the resolution or resolutions of the Director, including the trust agreement, if any, authorizing the issuance of and providing for the terms and conditions applicable to bonds.
“Borrower” means a local government or a person as defined in § 1–101(h) of this article who has received a loan.
“Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays Nonpoint Source Fund” means the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays Nonpoint Source Fund established under § 9–1605.3 of this subtitle.
“Community sewerage system” means a publicly or privately owned sewerage system that serves at least two lots.
“Director” means the Director of the Administration.
“Drinking Water Loan Fund” means the Maryland Drinking Water Revolving Loan Fund.
“Eligible costs” means the costs identified under § 9–1605.2(i) of this subtitle.
“Enhanced nutrient removal” means:

paragraph.text: An enhanced nutrient removal technology that is capable of reducing the nitrogen and phosphorus concentrations in wastewater effluent to concentrations of not more than 3 milligrams per liter total nitrogen and not more than 0.3 milligrams per liter total phosphorus, as calculated on an annually averaged basis; or

If the Department has determined that the concentrations under item (1) of this subsection are not practicable for a wastewater facility, the lowest average annual wastewater effluent nitrogen and phosphorus concentrations that the Department determines are practicable for that facility.

subsection.text: “Equivalent dwelling unit” means a measure of wastewater effluent where one unit is equivalent to:

paragraph.text: If a local government or billing authority for a wastewater facility has established a definition for “equivalent dwelling unit” on or before January 1, 2004, the average daily flow of wastewater effluent that the local government or billing authority has established to be equivalent to the average daily flow of wastewater effluent discharged by a residential dwelling, which may not exceed 250 gallons; or

If a local government or billing authority has not established a definition for “equivalent dwelling unit” on or before January 1, 2004, or if a local government or billing authority has established a definition that exceeds 250 gallons of wastewater effluent per day, an average daily flow of 250 gallons of wastewater effluent.

subsection.text: “Facility” means a wastewater facility or all or a portion of a water supply system as defined in § 9–201(u) of this title.
“Federal Safe Drinking Water Act” means Title XIV of the Public Health Service Act, P.L. 93–523, as amended, 42 U.S.C. § 300f, et seq., and the rules and regulations promulgated thereunder.
“Federal Water Pollution Control Act” means the Water Pollution Control Act of 1972, P.L. 92–500, as amended, 33 U.S.C. § 1251, et seq., and rules and regulations promulgated thereunder.
